reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs was originally going to be a direct sequel in the True Crime series many years before actually coming out. Thankfully, this never came to fruition. After a few changes, and a few publishers later, Sleeping Dogs came to be. Some will say it is the spiritual successor to the True Crime series. I'd like to think the connection never happened. Mainly because this game is just that good. Too good to be tied to a deservedly so dead series.

Sleeping Dogs takes place in Hong Kong, and has you playing the role of an undercover cop with ties to a small group of triads, as you work your way up through the ranks, and work from both sides, as a straight up police officer, and an undercover officer playing a triad member who gets in too deep. It's a risky business, but for our main protagonist Wei Shen, it's all part of his life now.

Sleeping Dogs is an open world action game modeled after games like Grand Theft Auto. You can run around freely, drive cars and ride motorcycles, and either take on main and side missions, or do other things as you progress through the game. Sadly, there is not much to do in terms of sandbox play. The world is very nicely detailed, and seems to be alive with the amount of people you will see moving about, but there just is not enough freedom to make this a real sandbox open world game. Most of the things you'll find yourself doing will be set up as part of the game instead. And anything you make up along the way will be few and far in between. Unlike open world games like San Andreas or Just Cause 2, where you can spend countless hours outside of any scripted events, making the game seem like your own little playground. This may be partially due to how constrained the world is. You can wander around streets, and inbetween buildings, and even inside of some, but the world is not as open as I would have liked it to be. Just don't be fooled by how big the map is, as lots of areas can not be accessed outside, due to barriers. Regardless, it is still a pretty big world. Just not ripe for exploration. Hopefully this gets remedied in the sequel.

As for action gameplay, its nice. You won't find yourself using guns often, but when you do, the cover system is decent, and aiming is not too bad. You even get a few max payne style moves, like slo-mo diving thrown in the mix. The star of the combat however would be the hand to hand stuff, which is reminiscent of the Batman Arkham games. You will not be one on one most of the time, but rather one on many. Weaving in and out, doing parries, and a number of nicely animated kicks, punches, and grapples with ease. It's almost like poetry to see it in motion. When you are running from cops, or chasing down the enemy, you'll also find that Wei Shen is a good master of parkour. You don't have a jump button sadly to just jump whenever, but instead the parkour is tied to platforms and obstacles. So you run up to a wall, and Wei Shen will run up and grab a ledge when hit the proper button. He can jump over gaps, slide over obstacles like cars and tables, and more. Again, this is quite nice to see in action.

As for the audio, it's fantastic. You have a nice selection of radio stations, featuring both HK Eastern and Western themed stations, full of commercials, and great music. You also have some amazingly done voice acting, helping to bring the story to life, with a cast of seasoned voice actors and tv and movie stars. The voice acting is also a mix of english and cantonese. Mostly english spoken, but a bit of cantonese here and there for authenticity. Some characters will also only speak in cantonese. While pedestrians will almost always speak in english. But the accents are just right even when spoken in english.

Sleeping Dogs may not be the ticket for anyone wanting a true sandbox open world game, but for those starving for a good action game with an open world set piece, and a great story. Sleeping Dogs is the perfect fix.

reviewText:
What was once shelved and left for dead by Activision is given new life and what would have been the third in the True Crime series is now Sleeping Dogs, exceeding expectations of just about everyone but Square Enix, the new publisher.

Sleeping Dogs is an open world action-adventure(sandbox) game that takes place in China where you play as undercover cop Wei Shen, tasked with infiltrating the Triads. The game has been compared to other games in the genre, most notably, GTA. While similar in gameplay, Sleeping Dogs is no clone. It has an interesting story that should keep you enthralled, coming up in the underworld of a criminal organization, racing across the streets of Hong Kong, shooting it out with rival gang members all while undercover for the HKPD. The gameplay is what you would expect of a game of this scale and caliber. The game will give you plenty to do and will leave you wanting more. Unfortunately, the DLC doesn't quite fill that need.

* You can play with either Keyboard and Mouse or plug in a controller. I tried both input methods and found both options to be enjoyable. Thankfully, that means the choice up to your preference.

Pros:
+Very fun
+Good story
+Solid gameplay

Cons:
-Story is a bit short.
-DLC is lackluster

Overall rating:
8/10

reviewText:
---PLEASE READ BEFORE YOU BUY THE COMPLETE PACKAGE/ALL DLC---


I enjoyed this game when I first bought it new, but never got a chance to finish it. I came back to it and recently bought it again because it was on steam sale. My only complaint is the DLC. PLEASE, be careful and read what the DLCs are and what they give you. Buying the complete DLC package is totally game-breaking. It really hurts my enjoyability of the game because it's way too easy to play now. Here's some things you should avoid the DLC because:
Right out of the tutorial/first few starter missions, you become level 8/10 on triad and cop. Face is I believe 7.
You gain more XP from everything.
You are level 10 (max) in everything by the time you get to the mission that gives you the impounded car (Race Scene mission). Not to mention that the DLC gives you about a dozen cars already before then.
You begin the game with $200,000 in your pocket. One of my best memories of this game is how hard it was to hustle to get money, and how rewarding it was to afford the things you want. Now, before I even get the first starter car, I can afford every car in the game practically.
You receive a lot more money from everything. You will start receiving at least $5,000 from every short mission. $5,000 used to be a lot, now it's chump change with the DLC.
You receive outfits with overpowered stat bonuses. One outfit gives you 60% reduction from all melee damage taken. That makes sense, right? Another outfit (Super Swat) reduces ALL incoming damage by  50%. That is rediculous, even for late game. Some outfits (like the deus ex outfit) even give you guns. Equip the deus ex, agent 47 or any of those outfits and it gives you the fitting weapons (flechette rifle for sarif armor, silenced pistol for agent 47 suit).
You will already own all player homes. I didn't figure this one out until it was too late. I was freeroaming looking for drug busts when I came up on one of the best player homes you can get, the mansion. It was unlocked. I could use it. It was my home already, it even marked it on the map.
There will be absolutely nothing to work for. You get all the free guns, clothes, houses, cars and even money you will need. I currently have about $600,000 and I haven't even gotten to the part where wei is kidnapped.
There are more reasons to avoid some of the DLCs than this. Now, I'm not saying that ALL the dlc are bad. A lot are fun, actually. I enjoy a lot of the ones that add content to the game. However, a lot of them are WAY too game breaking.
DLC YOU SHOULD AVOID:
High Roller Pack (near infinite money, best car. It gives you a nice suit but that's not very important)
The Red Envelope Pack (It adds 20 packages for $50,000 at each Parking Garage in the freeroam world, totalling one million dollars you can get in 10 minutes of driving)
Top Dog Gold/Silver Pack (INSTANTLY gives you a ton of XP in all fields, makes you near max level at beginning of the game)
Square Enix Characters Pack (I do enjoy this pack, but it is something I must warn you about. Gives you deus ex and agent 47 outfits, which come with overpowered outfit bonuses and free guns)
Retro Triad Bundle (The outfit this pack gives you makes you do more damage, gain more triad and face XP, and gives you more melee damage resistence. Overpowered)
Movie Masters Pack (Added this purely because of the Bronze Warrior outfit it gives you. It looks cool, but it's unlore friendly and gives you 60% resistence to melee damage which is overpowered)

I hope this review helped you a bit. Now, I'd like to mention again, these DLCs are fun. They add more opportunities for replay and freeroaming. However, you should avoid getting these if it is your first time playing the game, it honestly ruined most of the fun for me since I was way overpowered at the beginning of the game. The fact that this (mostly) singleplayer game is basically Pay-to-Win makes it deserve my downvote. I hate that I can't love this game, it's one of my favorites, but I must warn you how game breaking the DLC is.

reviewText:
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)

Game Name: Sleeping Dogs
Original Release: 2012
Genre Tags: Sandbox; Action; Third-Person; Martial Arts; Open World; Adult
My Overall Grade: A
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 25-55 hours
Multiplayer Aspect: None
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Strong narrative advocates; Game atmosphere connoisseurs
REVIEWWhy do you not have a pork bun in your hand?

Seriously though, this game is amazing.  It brings nothing particularly innovative or special to the genre of open-world-mayhem sandbox gaming, but what it does offer is high-quality, exciting gameplay and a well-written narrative. Sleeping Dogs is a worthy pick-up for any fans of the genre looking for something new.

You can’t fly jets, grapple-hook atop buildings, drive a tank down a city street, or do some of the other extreme actions that are becoming common in the genre. Sleeping Dogs is more grounded in reality and focuses more on having a believable narrative and atmosphere.  That said, the gameplay is still very enjoyable and there is plenty of extra stuff to do besides playing through the main story. Furthermore, the simple fact it takes place in Hong Kong goes a long way to add a little unique novelty  to the experience (like driving on the left side of the road, entering cars from the right, and just exploring a virtual city that isn't supposed to be in America for once).

It has a well-written story that is quite engaging and is reinforced with decent voice acting.  Combined with the nice graphics and atmospheric gameworld, it results in an excellent overall presentation. It definitely is an experience that feels more authentic than some of the more ridiculous games in the genre.

I definitely recommend to any fan of the genre who is looking for some novelty that they check out this game.

Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

reviewText:
Have you ever imagine an open world game such as GTA IV,a game where you obtain the knowledge of Kung-fu and other eastern martial arts, and a game where you find yourself working as a undercover police simultaneously?

If you did so, what are you waiting to buy this game?
A main story line where you work as an under cover police man in the most dangerous gang organizations in the entire world, the Chinese triads...


Sleeping dogs is a game that combines the power of freedom known in the GTA game series, the use of the environment and knowledge in martial arts to unleash powerful attacks and combos known in many fighting games and most importantly, the perfectly mixed in story line of an under cover police man who will get emotionally attached by his work and the people he interacts with.

But, there are few firearms available...

This is true, this isn't america where everything is solved by gunfights or explosions. This is Hong Kong, where strength and skill is valued and measured in epic, pleasant hand-to-hand combats. But even despite that, the use of firearms will depend on your type of game play, and the game will satisfy that lack of weaponry, in amazing breath-taking missions as you progress in the game.

Isn't Hong Kong a bad choice for a game like this?

Definitely not, Hong Kong is currently one of the most wealthiest places in the world; It has everything from a deep underground gang network, a gym to practice or learn new moves after completing each task, a club for you to interact with other people and to complete other side objectives, to random optional objectives and events that will appear in-game.

How are the graphics and the environment design?

To begin with, the game's designers performed extensive research in Hong Kong to create an accurate portrayal of the city. Art designers spent seven days in Hong Kong, where they studied the city's environment, and took more than 20,000 photos as references for the physical environment in the game. And the result was that many reviewers praised the authenticity and charm of the city in the game.

You mentioned the importance of the story line at the beginning, will this mean that after the game story line is completed, there wont be anything else to do?

No, almost all side quests and task will continue to be there, and the game wont change at all in order to preserve it's longevity.

Should I buy this game? and why?
This game is the perfect for anyone who either likes a good detective main story line, an open world sandbox like the GTA game series, and a similar fighting system seem in many fighting genre games.

I would rate this game 81 out of 100, or 4,5 out of 5,0. A masterpiece in mixing both action and adventure gaming genres into one, simply brilliant and well-balanced without looking lame, but truly epic!

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HFoaG9950sM

Fans of film directors like Johnnie To, Ringo Lam and John Woo will feel right at home in Sleeping Dogs. You take control of Wei Shen, a Hong Kong native who has just returned home after spending some time in the United States. He is working as an undercover cop under superintendent Thomas Pendrew and his handler Raymond Mak in an effort to take down a powerful Triad gang known as the Sun On Yee. Wei's assignment positions him as a lowly thug under the wing of a 'roided out hothead named Winston Chu and follows his ascension to a prominent figure within the Sun On Yee. Things become complicated however, as the line between undercover cop and criminal blurs. Wei becomes deeply entrenched in the criminal underworld, building friendships with his gang-mates while witnessing signs of corruption within the police force. The yarn spun by Sleeping Dogs is solid enough but it's telling stumbles. Pacing is all over the place, and many important elements seem undercooked. Sleeping dogs has issues integrating plot points into missions and providing build up. For example, Winston has a fiancee that is revealed when you have to run a few errands for her as part of a mission. She softens Winston's image and makes him a little more human but, unfortunately she exits the plot just as abruptly as she shows up making her little more than a tool to develop Winston. Thankfully the finale builds in a satisfying way and there are some sections that are really effective and engaging in the middle portion of the tale. Its just a shame that it couldn't be more consistent and better developed.

Being an undercover cop Wei must straddle the line between right and wrong and missions reflect this. Good guy Wei finds time between running errands for the triad to assist a police inspector with some of her cases. Triad missions are strait forward affairs that usually involve collecting protection money, stealing stuff, beating the hell out of other gang members and maybe shooting a few people. Cop cases play out more like multi-stage quest chains commonly associated with RPGs. Wei also earns experience for both a cop skill tree and a triad skill tree. You earn both types of experience in both mission types but being a public menace and destroying public property or killing civilians will take away from the cop experience you can earn in a mission. Throughout the course of Sleeping Dogs Wei hacks cameras, races, sings karaoke, cracks combination locks, plants bugs, triangulates cellphone calls, bets on ♥♥♥♥ fights, plays mahjong poker and picks locks. The game does a great job of mixing these elements up and missions are generally interesting with only a few lame ducks.

All of the aforementioned elements are secondary to the driving, fighting and shooting you will be doing to make your way through the game. The fighting system in this game really shines. Wei relies on strikes, grapples and counters to dispatch his foes. Enemies come in varieties as well, some specialize in strikes and block many of your attacks, grapplers are burly chaps that you want to keep at bay with power strikes, some enemies wield knives and tire irons and later in the game you will find enemies that are really only susceptible to counters. If you want to live in Sleeping Dogs, you will have to prioritize your foes and time your attacks carefully. Your wushu can be supplemented by finding Jade statues that can be returned to the Kung Fu master in the game. These moves are valuable tools and you will find yourself utilizing most of them. They allow you to snap your opponents limbs, deliver powerful blows and disarm your foes. It's a great system and is evolves enough during the course of the game to remain engaging. Driving is similar to other open world games with cars that handle differently based on weight and size. The one unique addition to the driving mechanics is a button that allows you to throw the car sideways by pushing the appropriate button or key and moving in the direction you wish to go. This allows you to ram vehicles that are in hot pursuit of Wei. Motorcycles, scooters and boats are also among the vehicles you will pilot. Shooting is of the cover-based variety and Wei can vault from cover and enter slow motion as well as blind fire. It's solid but the mechanics are not as unique and engaging as the hand to hand combat. In light of this most of the game focuses on hand to hand confrontations.

Sleeping Dogs' interpretation of Hong Kong is an efficiently constructed playground. There is an unusual amount of verticality in this game despite the lack of air vehicles. Wei can climb the ledges and scaffolding around a number of the building and access rooftops. Pedestrian overpasses on the streets also provide access to high places in which numerous collectables are tucked away. Free running is also a part of Sleeping Dogs' bag of tricks. At certain points Wei will have to pursue targets on foot through a gauntlet of barriers and other impediments. These sections involve the player running after them and timing button presses to clear obstacles gracefully, poor timing results in fumbling over an obstacle and loosing ground. The animations for these sections don't flow together as smoothly as those in Assassin's Creed but the extra input required to complete them is a welcome addition that adds a small layer of interactivity in what is usually a passive experience in other games. It's just a shame that the camera is not exactly stellar. It seems to have a knack for being in the wrong place most of the time. Strangely absent is the ability to center the camera with a button press that's so common in third person action games.

On the PC, Sleeping Dogs is a really pleasing game to look at. Square Enix has also made a high resolution texture pack available for those with decent rigs and includes some DX11 features. Hong Kong is wonderfully detailed with neon signs glowing, power lines forming webs overhead, air conditioning fans spinning on the sides of buildings, and plenty of pedestrians and traffic to make the city feel alive. Also, the game wisely uses rain to give everything a nice sheen--as it rains the wet pavement reveals reflections of neon signs and characters appear wet. The handful of interiors are also detailed and pleasing to look at. NPCs are not too detailed and are a little more robotic as a result of a low poly count and the cars are not tremendously detailed but these are technical limitations that are to be expected. The main characters however are richly detailed, making the cutscenes a treat. Skin textures are very detailed and the tattoos that adorn the bodies of the gangsters add quite a bit of character to each of them. You can also customize the clothing that Wei wears and wearing certain combinations of clothing can provide stat benefits. Cloting options are rather varied accounting for both ridiculous looks and strictly business attire.

For a game that was almost canned, Sleeping Dogs is quite impressive. The story fumbles around before ending on a strong note and the camera can be irritating but these faults are offset by great mechanics and strong visuals on the PC. Sleeping Dogs isn't ready to dethrone Grand Theft Auto as the best open world crime game but it's robust mechanics and numerous diversions make it a strong addition to the genre. It appears that Square Enix stuck gold by reviving this dead dog.

reviewText:
Not a stretch of originality to be seen, but that's okay. It's fine if you blatantly skin your gameplay inspiration from some of the best games of the last three years, so long as you pull it off like Sleeping Dogs has.

Combat is a simple, not-so-fluid, homage to Rocksteady's Arkham games. Free motion like a muscular dysfunctional Assassin's Creed and for transport/driving it rips a blank page out of Square Enix's own Just Cause's manual while the narrative is your average hard boiled vice story with an American protagonist. Individually they falter, but as one game they all succeed.

I enjoyed it, and maybe you will too.

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs was a game I bought in Steam's 2013 Autumn Sales, after being curious about this game for a long time and being aware that looking up YouTube footage might have spoiled the story for me, this sale was a good opportunity for me to just gamble on this one.

And it was jackpot for me. Having played Just Cause 2, GTA 1 to 4, Saints Row 3, L.A. Noire and countless other free roaming games, I was completely overwhelmed by how convincing Hong Kong was portrayed in Sleeping Dogs. Hong Kong, which in this review refers to the map in Sleeping Dogs, is a graphically pleasing platform that carries the player through a gritty storyline revolving around Chinese gangsters. Even though the city is small compared to most of the aforementioned free roaming city games, there is a healthy amount of detail put in every square foot of Hong Kong, making the city feel as big as it would have felt in real life. The city dynamics are downright convincing, you will encounter a large amount of variation among the residents, each with their own reason for being on the street. This, and the amounts of interaction provided for the player, is something that at the time of writing is not appreciated enough in the industry.

Sleeping Dogs features oriental themed music to reinforce that atmosphere. The genre of the background music as well as the radio stations vary from hip-hop to classic, all with Chinese roots. Luckily, a great majority of the used vocabulary is English, although you may encounter a Chinese swearword here and there. This is translated in the subtitles and may seem a bit forced, if not out of place. Personally I find it understandable considering a full English or Chinese transcript would've alienated the player from the casting in this context, or otherwise not being able to follow the story at all.

It's important that this appeals to the player as the emphasis of the game heavily lies on the implied Chinese gangster culture. This means that gunplay and car-craze is reduced to a minimum when compared to other games in this genre. Rather than mowing down your enemies it's more common to have to fight people barehanded, the use of several martial arts and enemies with different specialities makes this less linear than it may sound. I wouldn't go as far as calling this game less violent either, if anything, this game deserves its 18+ rating more than the others in its genre.

Having that said, the mechanics of the game definitely require getting used to, luckily this is achieved through a clever tutorial that gradually increases the freedom you have while playing.

To progress through the game there are countless of missions and events to participate in, and not all of these are fun to do. In fact, there's some dreadful shooter-on-rails included. Luckily this wasn't so common that it started to bother me more than I could take but these are things that make Sleeping Dogs far from perfect. It's a missed opportunity to go down in history as a classic, though looking back on what Sleeping Dogs did manage to achieve, it would be greedy to ask for much more. I already feel like a cheapskate having paid so little for what I got.

I greatly enjoyed playing Sleeping Dogs and within the 25 hours I needed to finish the story it has managed to claim a place on my list of all-time favourite games.

[IMPORTANT NOTE: I have played Sleeping Dogs on the highest settings and with HD textures (free DLC). This makes Hong Kong more crowded and makes everything look a lot better. I imagine this influences the experience quite a bit, so make sure to get the most out of your game.]

reviewText:
Being a nerd precludes me from being a gangster, which is why Sleeping Dogs is so much fun. In pure escapist terms, the game lets me renounce my mild, introverted mannerisms and embrace the violent, yet honour-bound way of life as a member of a Chinese Triad organisation. In other words, I get to assume the unfamiliar role of a bad-a$$, and guess what? I love it.

As a pensive nerd, I would quietly apologise and then flee from any threatening bullies. As a righteous member of the Sun-On-Yee however, I could--and frequently would--Dim Mak  anyone, and I mean anyone, that so much as coughed near me. The combat is a lot of fun, reminiscent of the Batman: Arkham series, although not quite as fluid.

The reckless abandon is invigorating when you've spent your life adhering to laws and rules. It helps that the characters and story, whilst clichéd, are likeable and intriguing. Hong Kong as a setting is also quite refreshing.

Be warned, though. The game has issues starting half the time, and I was constantly verifying the game cache to play it.

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs is an open world action-adventure video game developed by United Front Games and Square Enix London. The game has you infiltrating the ranks of the Triads as undercover cop Wei Shen on an island off the mainland of Hong Kong.

Sleeping Dogs places a strong emphasis on hand to hand combat giving you the opportunity to unlock a wide range of different combos to be used while fighting. The combat very closely resembles that of Batman: Arkham City however doesn't feel as smooth, regardless anyone who enjoyed that series will probably enjoy this.

Every now and then you will be required to use a gun, personally I think they should have just focused on Melee combat either way the guns add some extra action" to the game. A cover system is also included to allow you to avoid being shot and an interesting bullet-time mechanic allows you to vault over cover and take out enemies in slow-mo.

For those who like collecting stuff there is a large amount of collectable items in game to find while playing
date: you can also obtain several houses and dozens of clothing items
recommended: vehicles and furniture to customize your character.\n\nSleeping Dogs also features achievements which cover all aspects of the game including DLC content so I suggest
hoursPlayed: if you care for the achievements
voteText:
you also pick up the DLC so you can 100% the game. I took roughly 35-40 hours to 100% the game and should a Steam sale come up I think you should play it too!

Pros

+ Fantastic graphics
+ Interesting story
+ Plenty of content
+ Enjoyable fighting

Cons

- Controls could be better
- Map could be bigger

reviewText:
A very good game, one of my favourites. There are marks that the developers worked hard on this title.

PROS:
- A clever and tough AI system that challenges you if you are new to the game
- Graphics are very nice

CONS:

- Sleeping Dogs Definitive Edition is not available for german players at all.
- The cars are low-poly, you can see the edges on the roof and the details are very undetailled.

I give this game a 7.5/10, since the things you can do in the game are over the top, but as a german player you have no DLCs and no Sleeping Dogs Definitive Edition.

8/10

reviewText:
NOTE: I did not play 400+ hours of this game, it's a Steam bug that multiplied my playtime. I inquired about it but got not response from support.

INTRODUCTION:
Wei Shen a police officer trained in the USA, now working with the Hong Kong Police Department has been sent on a dangerous mission. To infiltrate and gather information on one of the largest and most dangerous Triad Organization in Hong Kong. Will he break under pressure or will he do his duty as one of Hong Kong's finest?

PROS:
+ Nice Graphics: -I like the visuals but you can clearly tell it was developed with consoles in mind. The only redeeming factor on this area is that a free high-texture DLC pack is available for download. The world is adequately populated by NPCs though at times some parts of the City does look empty. It has a day and night system as well as a weather system which adds to the game's atmosphere.

+ Expansive Map: -Though not geographically accurate to the real Hong Kong, the game still provides a massive Island to explore, populated by a number of NPC citizens as well as a number of drivable vehicles. Driving and exploration on this fictional representation of Hong Kong is very fun and oddly calming.

+ Interesting Combat: -The combat focuses primarily on punching people using street style Kung Fu martial arts, taking inspiration on the Batman Arkham games. Extremely violent and extremely satisfying in my opinion. This is further amplified by the fact that wearing different combination of clothing has benefits to your over all performance in hand-to-hand combat.

CONS:
- Very POOR Optimization: -As I said, this game was developed clearly with consoles in mind. Unexplained crashes, errors and FPS drops occur more than I would like. Not game breaking but It can be annoying and disruptive of the otherwise fluid gameplay.

- Story: -Though I found it interesting and fun, it's still rather predictable and rather cliche. Even going so far as to have one (or several), The Godfather" moments. My primary complaint is that there is only one ending to this game and your choices never really affects the ending which makes both "Triad & Police points" a bit useless outside of the combat skill tree.

- Side Quest: -The game has a very good concept of side quest
date:
offering both Police and Triad missions but they clearly weren't either finished or polished. I personally would have liked the "Drug Bust" missions to include proper detective work rather than have the game spoon feed who I should arrest.

CONCLUSION:
PRETTY GOOD. Notwithstanding the fact it's "like GTA"
recommended: Sleeping Dogs is unique in it's own sense. The story has just the right feel to keep you interested and the gameplay offers enough action to keep you satisfied. Though it's current full price is good
hoursPlayed: I'd wait for a sale.\n\nIf you want a break from the fun and mindless violence of GTA
voteText:
Sleeping Dogs can provide a fresh story based alternative.

reviewText:
I very highly recommend this game, particularly when it's on sale.

It's one of the few games I've played in the past few years that I've had trouble putting down. It's essentially an Asian GTA, although feels a lot more arcade-y, in that it's somewhat less realistic (cars in particular control very well compared to GTA) but is arguably more straight-up fun. I don't remember too many segments where you'll have to travel long distances without anything to do, or many particularly tedious tasks.
I think one criticism that some people had was that it got a bit too repetitive. I can see where they're coming from, as many of the missions are more or less kill this bunch of guys". With that said
date: I found the combat incredibly satisfying
recommended: if not a little bit easy on the default difficulty.\n\nHave bought but haven't actually tried the DLC yet. Will probably edit this review once that's done."

reviewText:
This is one of those games that's look like a generic clone of some other series, but that's a huge disservice to Sleeping Dogs.
In a lot of ways, yes, it is GTA with chinese people, but everything about the world set up in this game is fantastic.

Sleeping Dogs has one of the most spectacular open worlds ever made. The graphics are amazing, even by PC standards. Everything feels alive and real, like it's a world that would continue to exist after you close the game. The main story in the game is executed surprisingly well, with characters you will actually care about and a story that makes sense, and is most importantly, interesting.

Instead of generic gunfights, the majority of the game uses a brawling system very similair to the Batman Arkham games, and it's much more satisfying taking down enemies this way than the standard shoot the bad guys" approach. Gunplay does pop up occasionally and while it's not anything special
date: it works and feels decent enough.\n\nIf you want to be immersed in a game's world
recommended: and want to experience more than just a run of the mill story that's an excuse to shoot people
hoursPlayed: give Sleeping Dogs a try."

reviewText:
As someone who is currently living in Hong Kong and growing up watching all those hard-boiled Hong Kong action/triad movies, I must congratulate United Front Games for succeeding in capturing the feel of the city, and instilling the action and story of the movies into this game.

I was skeptical about this game since, on the outside, this game look like a shallow clone of GTA.  But once you start playing it, you would be surprised by the addictive melee combat sequences and the better than average open-world driving mechanism.  And the voice over is really top notch.

Don't forget to download and enable the free high resolution texture pack, if you have the card to run it.  It will make a huge difference!

reviewText:
Attention Steam Library Dwellers, it's time to wake up that dog that has curled up deep within your game collection. Not only does it have Steam Cards, it's also one of the surprisingly good games I've played recently. Yes, you could almost say this was a... sleeper hit.

OK, so that's hopefully got the terrible puns out of the way, now we can get to the crux of the matter. Sleeping Dogs is a game that deserves your attention; while it might be a new IP name wise, it has a storied history as 'True Crime'. However, due to rising costs Activision sold the rights to Square Enix who rebranded the game as 'Sleeping Dogs'. So yes it's 'new', but it comes with the benefits and years of experience built up from the previous True Crime games - perfect!
The game is an Open-World Sandbox game - think Grand Theft Auto x Saints Row.

Sleeping Dogs takes what I liked about GTA and what I liked about Saints Row and manages to meld them together into a game that has it's own unique qualities too. This perfect blend comes together to form a really unique and fun sandbox experience. The story is dark, based around an undercover police officer who is trying to destablise and expose the Triad groups in Hong Kong (think Infernal Affairs); the action is fast and frantic, like a John Woo movie; while there is a very refreshing melee element thrown in. It's the melee/Martial Arts element of the game that really allows Sleeping Dogs to stand tall on it's own merits, and not avoids being labeled as 'just another GTA clone'.

In fact the combat not allows this game to stand on it's own feet, but manages to propel it above GTA and Saints Row. The gunplay has refreshing, as it's not thrown down your throat at every turn and mission. Your mean weapons are fists and your fury, and melee weapons - yes melee weapons! Meat Cleavers, Swords, Batons, etc are all at your disposal, but it's the environment that will be your biggest weapon. Sure you can kick and punch through the Triad Forces like a young Bruce Lee, but it's when you turn your attentions to the walls, the fuse boxes and other nasty everyday objects that are in the world that you become a bad ♥♥♥ Jackie Chan. Grab the enemy and run towards the wall? Ram the guy's head into the wall. Run towards a dumpster? Throw that guy into the dumbster!! Run towards meat hooks... well I'll let you find out...

I was honestly surprised at how fun the combat was, it wasn't as mindless as some GTA games where you seemingly have an arsenal of weapons to use at any given time. It wasn't as endless as Saints Row where mobs just keep coming. It had the ideal balance between mobs and user abilities. Sometimes frustratingly you notice that it's always 1v1 in melee combat, despite several other bad guys standing around waiting for you to stop being attacked by their fellow goon - yet this seemed strangely fitting for the Kung Fu/Martial Arts tribute Sleeping Dogs manages to deliver on so many levels. However, if there is a sequal it would be nice to see Square Enix throw in multi-mob counters and combat ala The Batman: Arkham series.
Yet, you shouldn't dismiss the gun battles entirely either, as they're intense and just as fun. There's a nice nod to 'John Woo' with the addition of 'Slow Motion' gunplay when you vault out of cover, which can create some fantastic 'holy ♥♥♥♥' moments within the game as you clear a room with headshots and 'reactions'.

There are a few minor complaints I had about Sleeping Dogs, but none of them are gamebreaking and once you adapt to the game mechanics seem almost trivial. The driving can take some getting used to, and is perhaps the one area of the game that could do with a lot of TLC in any possible sequel. It's not terrible, just at times it feels as if your cars can't turn correctly, and it doesn't distract from some exciting highway chases and car chase/gun fights.
Besides the Radio Stations are immense and contain some fantastic tracks to listen to and select for your driving madness.

Visually the game is immense (if you download the free HD Textures map) and makes you wonder (at time of writing) why Watchdogs can't hit the same heights on PC (hopefully it will). When the rain falls and the city lights reflect on the wet film spread across the road, as you drive through the streets of Hong Kong you realise you're inside a wonderful looking gameworld. This game looks better than any GTA has managed to achieve to date on retail release. There are times when the shadows look a little goofy, and the blood splatters can almost become Splatterhouse-esque, but it doesn't distract too much from what is a wonderful looking game and world.

Overall Sleeping Dogs manages to put together a great Sandbox game that pulls together infleunces from a range of sources - GTA, Saints Row, Asian Cinema. Yet, it seems to have went largely unnoticed, even 2 years after it's release I'm talking to people who haven't played the game or even heard of it. Those who have played seem to love it, and I can't blame them now that I've joined them.
Sleeping Dogs will provide you with ~15 hours of gameplay, with a rich story driven experience that has a very strong combat base to carry the action along. If you're a fan of Asian Cinema then you'll be in fanboy heaven as the nods and tributes appear throughout the game. If you're not a fan of Asian Cinema then I'd like to suggest you watch the following movies either before or after playing the game: Infernal Affairs, Police Story, The Raid.

Sleeping Dogs - A surprisingly good game.

reviewText:
Overview
Back in the days Sleeping Dogs should have been the counterpart to Grand Theft Auto.
Well Grand theft Auto is and will always remain a highlight. Especially in case of graphics, open world etc… but Sleeping Dogs confidents in his very own and special way.

You play an undercover police officer in Hong Kong, who tried to infiltrate the local triad. There you expect to collect tasks such as collect money, to fight other gangs, kidnap some important people, to steal cars etc. Soon you will experience that the Triad seek internal changes in the balance of their leadership.

At the same time you are giving important information to your boss police). You take out some enemies before you can hack some surveillance cameras. With these cams you can watch drugs handovers, viewing the dealer and call the police to arrest him. You can also do some special missions, following some member of the triade, make hidden photos and listen to some discussions about money transfers.

In my opinion, the story is very captivating and exciting. The voice acting is good and look very authentic. Dont forget, ist not america, ist hong kong, different driving sides, freakier cars and everything is like really densely built.

All quest are categorized in three different areas :

- Police Area (after completing a quest you earn xp and can level up)

- Triade Area (after completing a quest you earn xp and can level up)

- Social Area (after completing a quest you earn xp and can level up)

Many contents are comparable to Grand Theft Auto . There is a huge open world , lots of traffic , own cars (stealing, buying) , special clothing for your hero, weapons , several apartments and ancillary tasks. You can find hidden chests with money or clothing. To increase your energy, there are several shrines. To learn new fighting techniques, there are also hidden statues. These statues you can bring to your former teacher of martial arts. Afterwards he teaches you a new technique. You can train it in his fighting school. Focus of the game is the martial arts melee. Several kinds of enemies waiting for you :

- Light opponents

- Serious opponents

- Wrestler

- Enemies with weapons

- Covered Opponents

etc.


In addition to the main tasks that you can solve, there will be also little Quests to raise your Social Status. For example helping a woman to sink her car in the river. With those points you can buy better clothes. The clothes also allow you to earn some extra attributes (for example 5 % more damage on enemies in fights). After some time you will have enough money to buy anything, it just matters how is your current level in each area (police, triade, social). Some things you can only buy if you have a minimum level in one of the areas.


Graphics
I dont want to talk much about the graphics. Check out some screenshots, even if you dont play this game on ultra settings, it looks great. It can not exceed GTA, but it still looks good enough in my opinion.


Controls
You can play it with both controller or keyboard. I prefer Keyboard, somehow I play most of those kind of games with mouse and keyboard. At least its much easier for me to hit targets with weapons instead of using the controller.


My conclusion
If you like GTA, then you will like this for sure. You can feel the intensity of the main character. I really like his way he speaks, the way he acts. He fits totally for this job.

If you love martial arts fightings with a mix of grand theft auto flavour, an open world, undercover action, a great story, then go and get it. I can only recommend the game.

Enjoy it

Greetz
MajorKing


PS: this was my first review of a game, who finds spelling errors in the text, can keep them xD

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs,

What more can i say, 10/10 this open world, crime driven drama is an amazing experience I have not come across before. You play as Wei-shen, an undercover cop whom has the role of bringing down the infamous and well know Sun On Yee Triad affiliates. Through glorious and violent car-chases to all out blazing gunfights, and even lockpicking, hacking and the more suttle of detective work you experience the breadth and height of Hong Kong's underworld. reviewText:
A truly fantastic open world action game set in the refreshingly colorful city of Hong Kong. You play the role of an undercover cop trying to take down a notorious group of Triads.

The story is something to take note as there is no simple good cop / bad criminal side to it. The game does a fantastic job of showing you the side of what it means to be part of a Triad family and that the police isn't necessarily the enemy here, nor are the Triads. Doing missions and assignments for both sides will test your moral standings and alignment. The story is good enough and has enough twists and turns to make you stay interested in finding out what happens at the end.

Gameplay wise, you will primarily be falcon punching your enemies or killing them with your horrible karaoke singing skills. The game does include guns but is primarily fighting focused. As per open world style, you can drive around the city looking for stuff to do. Options include but not limited to: driving for fun, ♥♥♥♥ fighting, dating, looking for shrines of health, delivering vehicles, participating in street races, learning fighting moves, hacking street cameras, karaoke, beating down groups of gangs, eating pork meat, drinking herbal tea, getting an erotic massage, buying clothes, yachting and I've probably missed half of the others.

So if you're in it for fighting, the drama of becoming a Triad gang member, the colorful Hong Kong city lights or just want to listen to some fantastic Chinese radio stations - be sure to pick up Sleeping Dogs, you will not be sorry.

reviewText: This is easily one of the best open world crme game i've played. Cruising through the streets of HK with some hip hop, techno and soothing pop on the radio is truly a pleasure. There isn't a ton of gunplay but the melee combat is where it shines the brightest. It feels a bit like combat in Assassin's Creed but somehow, better. You can use objects in your surrounding to perform 'environmental kills', throw a girl in your trunk and drive them around and even take a human shield! You can also learn combo attacks that are easy to master. Oh there's also the parkouring, jumping over objects, free running, climbing short walls, definetely on of the best delight. There's also the food and drinks that give you temporary boost in different stats. And also lots of collectibles which isn't easy nor hard to find. On vehicles, you can ram enemy vehicles, go into slow motion while shooting enemies, perform action hi-jack. The story is really great but i honestly think that it ended a little too quickly. In the midst of the game, you actually came to care about several characters, for example Jackie for me. To summarise you should really get this game if you don't mind the extensive use of swearing.

reviewText:
What an amazing game!  United Front did not pull any stops in creating a fantastic open world sandbox that incorporates all of the best features from similar games.

The game's portrayal of Hong Kong is very vibrant and believable and the NPCs are fun to interact with.  The game world looks amazing on the PC at full resolution (make sure to install the FREE HD texture pack DLC).

The combat system focuses primarily on melee with some gunplay mixed in at times.  The combat system plays similar in nature to the Arkham series of games and allows for cool environmental finishers in addition to some time-slowing bullet-time" when leaping from cover.  Vehicle combat is also fun with action hijacking and time-slowing effects when firing your sidearm from your vehicle.

The main campaign story is very good and gripping
date:
but also very predictable at some points.  As an undercover cop trying to infiltrate the Triad organization the game keeps making you think about your duties as a cop versus your loyalty to your "family".  The skill system reflects this conflict in rewarding experience as both a cop and a Triad gang member with experience being portioned based on your actions.  A very nice design feature in linking the advancement of the character to the moral implications of the story and how the player decides to play it out.

And any game that uses voice acting from the legendary James Hong is great in my book!

Overall if you enjoy similar games like Saints Row or the GTA series then you should love this game.  It is a very big open city with lots of activities to keep the player busy.  A very well thought out and designed game that made me feel that I was actually playing in a classic Hong Kong action film!  Sleeping Dogs is definitely among the top games I have ever played and I highly recommend."

reviewText:
Amazing game, absolutely worth both your time and money, and the only thing I regret is not buying the full DLC pack right away.

I started out with some missions and had some conversations with a pig mask on my head that made me laugh more than it should. Then I discovered the game isn't just for laughs, although it has that in spades - the story is excellent too. I also had the pleasure of experiencing the awesome Batman: Arkham Asylum style combat in the game, including putting a guy through aquarium glass in a night club, breaking legs and arms, and just generally being a wrecking machine of a fighter. Good times, really good times. But there is more.

Because there are times in the game that are not only good, they're almost transcendental.

One evening, I woke up after a hard day/night before. I had some texts waiting on my phone, from both police investigators and thugs, and said to myself it was going to be alright, even though I was playing both sides. I got out of my apartment, picked up a car and started driving to my next mission. And then...

I found myself just keeping on driving around the city.

Time had stopped.

I no longer sensed the room where my sorry gamer butt was actually sitting because I was no longer there.

I'm in Hong Kong - for real. I can't stop driving. It's raining and the reflection from the neon lights in my car, the fan-♥♥♥♥ing-tastic music from the radio, the streets and back alleys, the people, the crowds - I'm completely immersed.

And like throwing game money on pimped up outfits (that actually gives you bonuses sometimes, so they're more worth than just for show")
hoursPlayed: expensive cars
voteText: I'm looking forward to throw a little bit of real money on United Front again - this time to buy the whole DLC pack to continue my stay in Hong Kong. It's been a journey like nothing else and it has been the best digital vacation ever.\n\nRecommended with all my heart - it rivals some of the best games I have ever played in my life."

reviewText:
Game:  Sleeping Dogs
Genre:  Action/Open World
Developer:  Squareenix
System:  Steam (PC)
Total Score: 90/100
Value Score: 9/10

• Story:  9/10
• Characters: 8/10
• GamePlay:  9/10
• Graphics:  10/10
• Sound: 10/10
• Music:  8/10
• Length: 7/10
• Replay Value: 9/10
• Player Value: 10/10

Pros
+Plays similar to other open world action games like GTA, Saints Row, etc
+Driving mechanics are well done and more smoother than other Open world games that came out recently
+Visuals are amazing in both lighting and the depth of the environment
+Fighting mechanics are well done and focused on combos, counters, and environment attacks giving you different ways to defeat enemies
+Gun mechanics are well done and play like a decent TPS game.
+Be able to buy food which gives you buffs such as increased damage, vitality, etc
+Play as a Gang member or a Police officer to play different missions and to experience different Point of views on the storyline
+Radio stations have a great variety of music choices
+A lot of side quests in both the main storyline and DLC storylines - allows you to get money and other items
+DLC allows you to get more vehicles, weapons, costumes and even power ups
+Ability to replay missions
+Two storyline DLCs Nightmare in North Point and Year of the Snake extend the game's length with about 20 missions total.

Cons
-Navigation system for cars may lead you in circles or to the wrong location
-Some NPCs act crazy and ruin missions in the first few seconds (this is a bug more than likely - experienced this at least 8 times)
-DLC storylines do not let you use DLC items, weapons, etc
-No flying missions or vehicles
-Some graphical glitches could be seen but very rarely.
-Some NPCs do not interact with you at first try (mainly shops and vendors - more likely a bug)

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs has you play as Wei Shen, an undercover cop with a dark past, trying to crack the Sun On Yee, a powerful triad force controlling the underground of Hong Kong.

Sleeping Dogs is beautiful and awesome. The story is superb and entertaining, with hugely comedic elements, but drawing brilliantly on dramatic storytelling where appropriate. The journey of Wei Shen is a tumultuous one, and it's awesome to be there at every step.

Along with completing missions for the Triads, you have the Police case sub-missions, carjacking missions, extortion missions, drug busts, hacking and tonnes of random world events to keep you entertained.

It took me 31 hours to 100% the game (Cheif Inspector achievement, including all other achievements (except 30/30 Silver/Gold stats)) and I enjoyed every minute of it.

Keep in mind: play with the HD texture pack if you can (check DLC, it's free), makes the game look so much better. And, play with a controller. So nice. Brilliant game.

-Nilesy

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs isn't a game that does one thing perfect, but it's a game that does a lot of things incredibly well. The amount of effort that United Front Games put into development is shown from start to finish and the overall charm outshines that of any other sandbox game currently on the market. To help explain, the team spent weeks in Hong Kong taking pictures (20,000+) and recording audio to help their efforts in recreating the city. The world feels realistic and everything you encounter has personality. There was also extra work put into making it fully optimized for PC, fluid keyboard and mouse controls, specialized hardware support, and a day one high resolution texture pack to accommodate players with better machines are some of the few.

The game offers a nice mix of cop and Triad missions that help the pace of the overarching story, but there are plenty of things to keep you busy for the collector and completionist mind. Featuring a surprisingly well-driven narrative (... for a video game) centered around melee combat and parkour, there are also racing events, random jobs, fighting rings, hidden lockboxes, car deliveries, cockfights, gambling dens, dates (lol), and enough cars and clothes to collect to feel satisfied. Every character is fleshed out and feels real, the city is beautiful, and the soundtrack complements the themes and overall immersion very well.

After having owned the game since launch, it remains of one of the few that I still like to revisit every now and again. It's fun, it's cheap, and it deserves a spot in everyone's Steam library. Give it a shot if it's still sitting there with zero hours played and get hyped for Triad Wars.

Word of caution: You might be better off without the DLC for the first playthrough, as it gives you in-game experience that will unlock upgrades early on. It takes away most progression and is something to be wary of.

reviewText:
Wonderful game. Looks like GTA and Yakuza had a child and it’s turned out to be awesome.
Sleeping dogs owns GTA4 in every way. I was forcing myself to finish GTA4 and enjoyed Sleeping dogs twice (on PS3 and after couple of years on Steam) and even collected all the achievements.
Firstly the graphics are much better, GTA4 looks like crap and sleeping dogs looks great and when it’s start to rain it looks amazing. Sleeping dogs runs much MUCH better too while GTA4 is barely playable and bad looking even on high end machines.
The gameplay is much more fun than broken GTA4, where controls are pathetic, shooting is frustrating, cars are bouncing, etc. This is not existent in Sleeping dogs. Controls are really good except for some rare camera issues. Driving is fun, especially shooting while driving and hijacking. And shooting mechanics is great, it’s easy to target the enemy, shoot him in the head, hide behind cover or disarm the enemy.
The fighting system, is something like Yakuza. There are some combos which you learn by levelling up, you can use environment and knives, cleavers or even umbrellas, purses and my favourite – a fish to kill people.
Side missions are not boring unlike in some other games, most of them are different every time. Catching the thieves, throwing out the drunks from the shop, collecting debts, stealing cars or find the lady in a car’s trunk and free her only to find out that it’s some sexual game and she was waiting for her husband to find her, not you.
The story is good too. As undercover cop you must infiltrate the triad and bring them down. So you play as a cop and as a gangster depending on the mission. Sometimes it’s just driving, sometimes fighting or some bloody shootout.
Oh and the game have radio with a different genre of music. My favourite is roadrunner records station. It has such bands like Machine head, Dream theatre, Soulfly and Trivium. It’s really fun to kick some teeth while Fear factory’s edgecrusher is playing :)
The only downside of this game for me is that it lacks activities. After playing Yakuza games which has a bunch of activities I want more of them in other games too. The only activities are ♥♥♥♥ fights, races and mah-jong. Because of this I’m giving this game 9/10 :)

reviewText:
Gameplay:

Similar to the styles of Grand Theft Auto and the Saints Row series, this game is a visual impact of what gang life would be like on the streets if there was an exaggeration on the realism. Allegedly being trained in a kung-fu training school at your home town of Old Prosperity in Hong Kong, you’re equipped with martial arts and the ability to smoothly defeat any enemy you come across with ease. As much as this fighting style is fun and easily playable, it does leave little challenge and it would be better if enemies were faster or even if more bunched on you at the same time – similar to that of the Batman: Arkham series. The whole customization scheme is great for your player, buying clothes and the DLC packs that allow more custom outfits. However, I would love it if Square Enix put emphasis on the customization on the character himself (Wei Shen) and allow you to maybe change his looks a little bit e.g. his hairstyle. In addition, a positive feature would to allow vehicle customization, not to the extent of Saints Row where it almost seems tacky, but maybe the addition of NOS or bulletproof windows etc (seeing as you are an undercover cop). The map is easily explorable but can feel a bit repetitive or leave you with the feeling that more could be added.

Graphics:

I actually love the graphics on this game, even though some improvement could be made. The graphics do seem quite decent in my opinion; although the problem I seem to find with them is that everything seems to be a little too reflective or edgy. Although this seems really picky, these factors are highly noticeable and can become a little bit of a nuisance – especially to those struck with OCD! I think for a sequel the graphics should definitely be improved to the quality of more recent games to make it seem like a more scrutinised game: if that’s even the correct term for it.

Controls & Movement:

As previously mentioned, the combat style is really playable with this game with the only problem being that the techniques – although look rather good  - are really simple to complete; this leaves the game drought of challenge at times. Staying positive however, this game’s combat is definitely more advanced than games such as Grand Theft Auto, Saints Row and the most similar game style is the Batman: Arkham series however that has a little more complexity: with combos at a more developed stage. If the next Sleeping Dogs (or True Crime) took a shining to this then they could make the game a percentage better than it already is. The main fixture they should improve though is the gun system, as much as I love the slow-motion action scheme sometimes, I would like it if you could store guns and/or aim with a bit more ease.

Storyline:

The storyline to this game is actually very, very good. I find that it’s more intellectual than most games these days and has had a lot of thought built into it. The game makes your character experience a series of feelings and emotions and different thoughts such as revenge or anger. Although you’re an undercover cop cooped into the life of a gang called the Sun-on-Yee, you actually become sucked into their life more than your police life; you’d consider yourself as one of them before calling yourself a cop. You rise through the ranks and earn your place through hard work and unthinkable tasks to have your mind played and traumatic experiences – for the character, not us. With side stories and missions you are able to take a break from all the action and lay low as a racer or simply as a civilian hanging out with some girls *cough* the girlfriend experience needs improving *cough*.

Conclusion:

To conclude, this game is brilliant in most aspects, not too much thought put into anything but not too little. Even if more thought could be put into some factors of the game such as combat and miscellaneous additions for example vehicle and character customization, it still seems to be intuitive with its ideas. Although being similar to other games of its genre, it manages to remain original for a sandbox game because of its great storyline and renewed gameplay style. Moreover, the game is really playable – especially with a controller – which makes it quick to learn, leaving the rest of your time to enjoy the aesthetics and unique style of play.

Rating:

Gameplay: [9/10]
Graphics: [9/10]
Controls & Movement: [9/10]
Storyline: [10/10]
Overall: [9/10]

reviewText:
If this game is still sitting unplayed in your backlog, please give it a try. It rot in mine for over two years until I launched it and now it's probably in my Top 5 games of all time.

I had a problem of the game crashing every 10 to 20 minutes along with the graphics driver whenever the GPU got to around 70 degrees or something, so I lowered few graphical settings that did not make it uglier in any way really, and haven't had it crash for the next 23+ hours.

Both driving and fighting is really fun and easy even with mouse and keyboard after you get used to its control scheme, which took me about 30 minutes after which it was smooth sailing till the end. Only thing I did rebind is action hijack from Q to mouse wheel press. I heard the Definitive edition's default control scheme is closer to standard.

The environmental finishers are some of the most brutal things I've seen in games.

Wei Shen is cooler than all the GTA protagonist muppets combined. (Haven't played GTA V yet)

Night time in Hong Kong during the rain is one of the most beautiful environments I've seen, with the neon lights reflecting on wet streets and stuff.

Hot dog vendors in GTAs pale in comparison to the superior pork bun dealer.


Damn, this game is SO GOOD.


My professional rating: 5 golden sloths

reviewText: A genre that isn't really thought of as a genre but is still one of the most immensely popular genres out there is what I call the 'open world crime game'. Saints Row 4 and GTA 5 were some of 2013s most anticipated games which shows how popular the genre is. Another classic genre is the old school fighting game. As in, fighting with fists not guns. Sleeping Dogs combines these two to form an absolutely amazing game. The story is fantastic, the combat is far more interesting than in games such as GTA or Saints Row, the city (Hong Kong) is really nicely detailed, and the driving is at least as good as that of those two games.\nIn my opinion this is the best game of the 'open world crime' genre and is among my favourite games of all time.

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs in many ways is just your average GTA clone. It does nothing much groundbreaking or new but manages to provide a decent open world experience that will entertain for as long as it should.

You start of as Wei, an undercover police detective that's working his way into the power structure of a local triad. Of course he has a number of personal connections and vendettas that he is secretly trying to solve however the lack of choice often means you won't really get to care about his developing identity crisis.

Unlike most games in this genre guns are fairly rare and you will only really use them in the missions that require it, the rest of the time you will be depending on your martial arts skills.

Although the developers did quite a lot of talking up the fighting system in this game, even going as far as comparing it to the Arkham games, it doesn't quite meet that standard, you got your heavy attack and your light attack as well as a grapple and can use those in a variety of combos. Unfortunately Sleeping Dogs also takes a page from the first Assassins Creed game and gives you an end all counter button. You can win almost any fight by just standing still and countering the enemy attacks without much effort.

The driving feels pretty good, not quite the cartoon style of Saints Row but not the annoying wannabe realistic style of later GTAIV either it manages to strike a nice balance where cars are still fun but it doesn't get too silly. For some bizarre reason though motorcycles have much greater road grip than even the best of cars.

Instead of multi-player Sleeping Dogs have a social hub feature wherein you can compete with your friends for high scores on missions and races as well as a number of challenges but it is a feature easily forgotten or ignored.

What separates Sleeping Dogs from the pack is the location. Instead of being situation in yet another differently named version of New York City the game takes place in Hong Kong and everything about the game, from the mini games to the radio stations and the street vendors create a different feel than we're used to in this sort of game. When was the last time you bet on cockfighting in a video game?

Although the Hong Kong vibe manages to make Sleeping Dogs rise somewhat above the pack it is still a fairly unimpressive game underneath, not much new and not much improved over the many other games in the same genre out there now. Also it is much lighter on content than is normal for a game in this genre and 100% the game, achievements and DLC shouldn't take much more than 25-30 hours of game time.

Still, it's a game I had quite a bit of fun with and the Hong Kong vibe was interesting to play around with, it's a pretty game despite originating on the consoles and although I would probably feel a little cheated if I had gotten it at it's original 50$ price tag with the current sales and discounts it's an enjoyable experience.

reviewText: This is one of my favorite games for sure.  I love asian culture, so thats what got me interested.  This is an open-world game with racing, clothing stores, kareoke bars, fight clubs, apartments, and much more.  The music choice in the game is interesting.  There is a selection of cantonese and mandarin songs, but there are also songs from Killswitch Engage, Queen, Pat Benatar, Blood Red Shoes, Machine Head, Mozart, and plenty more.  Hand to hand combat just feels right.  Shooting an enemy may make you feel good about yourself, but there is nothing like a flying dragon kick to the face!  As you progress through the game you will learn more moves to use.  Fight clubs are a great place to try out all the moves you know, while taking on 1, 5, or even 10 enemies at once.  If that isn't enough, the story just makes it that much sweeter.  It is very easy to feel connected to characters in the game.  This is just a portion of what this game has to offer.

reviewText:
From the developers who brought you ModNation Racers, a kart racing game that makes Mario Kart seem unsuitably violent for children, comes Sleeping Dogs; the brutal, ultraviolent action game you've always anticipated would rise up gallantly, to try to compete with the popular GTA franchise, only to fall short by an unsurprising stretch.

Not to say it's not an entertaining game, Sleeping Dogs reaches certain standards, most of all when it comes to innovating the field of satisfying your homicidal urges. After all, its progressive skill system is based on 'Face points’ that are awarded accordingly by how creative you are on your quest: to reduce the bodies of your enemies to the least identifiable shape possible (the important thing to know about evidence is that it’s best if there is none). You get the option to use the vibrant urban environment to your advantage, being given difficult choices like whether to crush all the bones in your opponents’ bodies with easily accessible car engines, or the equally effective maneuver of putting them gently down in a trash container.

The story is set in the metropolitan jungle of Hong Kong, and you have the privilege of following Wei Shen: the spiritual successor to every character Jackie Chan has ever played in films. He is an undercover cop and a master of martial arts before he even enrolls in the in-game martial arts class, and an unrelenting champion of doing the right thing. Like spending blood money on fancy clothes.

Throughout Wei Shen’s journey, you will face difficult moral choices, encountering moments where you’ll have to decide whether a character or scene is merely stereotypical, inappropriately prejudice or straight up racist (for example: why it seems like every fighting individual seem to possess knowledge of, and skillfully demonstrates, advanced martial arts just because it’s set in Hong Kong).

You will be taken on an adventure where, as a servant of the law, you will rise in the ranks of organized crime through vicious acts, lie to near everyone you come across, and enthusiastically murder almost every ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ person that stands in your way, be it suspects, gang members or policemen, and still getting to keep your job as a cop. Oh, and you also get the option of using ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s posing as masseurs for in-game bonuses, tasteful! An excellent social commentary on how the modern execution of justice is flawed and better handled by a single, unstoppable psychopath, who also enjoys karaoke.

Your toughest enemy throughout the game will be the agony of a typical, nightmarish PC port. You will be combating mortal enemies like painfully stiff controls and a swarm of bugs, along with strategically consistent game crashes to ultimately break your resolve. In addition, Square Enix’ support center seems to have lost all the passwords to all of their e-mails. A suitable challenge for only the most hardcore gamers, those who don’t really want to play at all. Final verdict: “it’s alright” out of 10.

reviewText:
What can be said about this game...
Square Enix likes to create new stuff, and most of the time ♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥ up: this is kinda the same thing, but not for everything.
The story is pretty good and original, always full of action and never boring, and really tried to make you forget you're playing something that could looks like a GTA game.
The gameplay is not that bad, pretty much a copy and paste from Batman games but with more then 2 buttons to press.
The ambience is very well designed, and pretty much everything lives around you. But here comes the bad part.
This game is a bucket of bugs. Lot of time I had to spend a few minutes to figure out what the heck was goin on, even in the first 10 minutes of the game. The AI is pretty stupid sometimes, and the physics is terrible, everyone looks like a robot when they falls, even the protagonist.
In conclusion, Square Enix did a good job, but probably should have waited just 4-5 month before releasing it for fixing lot of bugs and not make one hundred updates about cars 'n ♥♥♥♥.
Final score: 7/10

reviewText:
This game is an intense thrill ride following Wei Shen an undercover cop in Hong Kong who is inflitrating the Sun On Yee a Triad member gang. You must choose between the honor of your gang and your duty to the badge. A great plot with many shocks indeed. It is a very gruesome story that has some cringing moments.

This is not like a GTA game you focus less on shoot everyone and drive away fast. You mainly use your martial arts skills to defeat foes while attempting to not put innocents in harms way. Driving recklessly will negatively affect your police skills and take away points. The game utilizes parkour in many ways such as combat, running missions, and exploration.

The only real downside is that if you fail a check point your buffs just vanish and you must go through the city and get them again later. Also there were several instances of NPC clipping errors. In which during a cutscene an enemy would get stuck behind a door or circle their vechile endlessly meaning the cutscene would not end and I would have to restart from the checkpoint. Another instance is when you enter a shop and the keeper will randomly not be active for interaction, though when you walk away they are ready until you approach them again. The only way to cure that is to go around the block then try again.

Overall it is a great game an open world that is not a shoot up everyone game.

Also if you want to have some fun try leaving your car 1/2 in the garage then talk to the attendie your car will be damaged.

reviewText:
I never bought this game on release because I don't like action/fighting titles - or any game that requires gamepad gymnastics, but having read about the game's Hong Kong open-world, I picked it up in the summer sales, and wow, what a game!

Combat is mostly martial arts and is fairly easy going for controllerphobes like me.  The Hong Kong world is fantastic, very atmospheric and way too vast to explore!  There are many optional side missions and two story strands to play (a gangland member and an under-cover cop) that are played side by side.  Some of the minor NPCs are a bit cliched and stereo-typed (to the point I cringe) but stronger characters are developed well.

A very enjoyable game for anyone who enjoys mission-based antics in a highly detailed and atmospheric world, with a good story to go with it.  The only negative is that all the accompanying DLC levels you up almost to max so there's nothing to work up towards (I learnt this too late), but otherwise it's a fantastic experience.

reviewText:
It's not everyone's type of game. There's no multiplayer and to be honest you'd be better off playing it with an xbox 360 controller or similar controller with the emulator mod (ask if you need the link). I've met and have heard from others in the forums that using keyboard and mouse, you eventually get used to it and the only difficulty is in the driving. I actually used both, shooting with keyboard/mouse and fighting and driving the xbox controller.
Regardless of price (I did buy it discounted through some key re-seller friends, but it wasn't at this price nor were the dlc I got with it) I totally enjoyed this great game. It's like every John Woo film and a lot of Bruce Lee and Jackie Chan films put into story mode. There's even a dlc called Zodiac Tornament that is pretty much the movie Enter the Dragon where you go to an island tournament with all the different stlyed fighters and of course have to beat the evil organiser of the tournament, classic Hong Kong movie stuff to be had all round.
Story wise, you are an ex Triad gang member gone to the States and returns to Hong Kong assigned the task of getting into a gang that you have ties to from your youth and a score to settle with one of the leaders of another faction of the Triad gang Sun On Yee. You have to deal with all the politics and oblivious Police dept. issues as well as the gut wrenching ethical dilemas of being a cop posing as gangster to people you eventually end up respecting and caring for as almost family.
If you are time poor and just want to experience the story and action unabated you can get this game complete with all the upgrades and rip through the game almost too quickly but have all the bling and weapons at the game start. Remember though a lot of the unlocks are earnt through the game progress, not all but a lot are and it's usually stated on the dlc page itself if that's the case so have a look before you buy and save some cash if you need to.

reviewText:
My score: 9/10Playthrough time: 26 hours (main story + side missions)

Pros:+Stands out from similar games in a good way
+Fun hand to hand combat (main combat method for 85% or so of the game)
+Easy to follow and fairly engaging plot
+The Hong Kong setting is different and looks great

Cons:-Not much to do besides of main story and a few shallow side missions
-Non immersive vehicle handling/damage (probably a pro for some players)
-The story, while still being enjoyable, is a bit cliché

Performance notes:Xbox 360 controller recommended!
Graphics performance R9 280X, 1080P max settings: 60 FPS (V-sync) most of the time, slightly less some times, can dip down to 40-ish.

Main review:If you enjoy open world action games, Sleeping Dogs has quite a lot going for it, and it does a few things differently than for example the GTA series.

For most of the game, the combat is hand-to-hand based. The controls feel great (I played using a gamepad), and are easy to pick up. There are weapons available, but they appear later in the game.

Driving is more arcade-oriented than GTA IV. I prefer when vehicles behave more realistically, and especially when it comes to taking damage, the vehicles that you control in Sleeping Dogs are far, far from realistic. For some people, this is probably an advantage, since a few crashes doesn't slow you down/force you to get in another car to continue.

The story gets a thumbs up from me. It revolves around a small amount of recognizable characters, so for someone playing the games a few hours a week, it's easy to know who everyone is, which I couldn't say for GTA IV. It's a bit cliché, but good enough to keep the main story interesting.

One of the best things with the game is the setting. The version of Hong Kong in the game is a great place for the story, and after 26 hours, when I was done with the main game and all side missions, I felt a bit sad that it was over.

There is not a lot to do besides the main and side missions, and just going around causing chaos doesn't have the same feel as in the GTA series, so most of the time you spend with the game will probably be the main and side missions.

Still a great game, and well worth picking up at a sale.
