reviewText:
If you're looking for something reminiscent of Grand Theft Auto but unique in its own right, look no further than Sleeping Dogs.  I was extremely pleased with this game.  I had expected a good time but what I ended up getting was far more bang for my buck than I had initially expected.

Sleeping Dogs has gameplay similar to Grand Theft Auto in that it takes place in an open world city where you acquire missions from contacts to progress the story but you can generally do whatever your heart desires.  However, whereas Grand Theft Auto is very gunplay oriented, the majority of Sleeping Dogs' combat is melee in a way that reminds me of a kung fu action movie.  The combat is much deeper and more complex than I had anticipated (similar in a sense to the Arkham games) and the parkour movement was a nice surprise as well.

The story, I must say, is absolutely incredible.  It has its twists and turns as you play the role of an undercover police officer navigating both the criminal underworld and the police hierarchy of Hong Kong.  If I had to choose one of the aspects of that game that was the absolute best and most standout, I would go with the story.  I highly recommend this game to all fans of modern open world games, action games, and especially to anyone who's looking to scratch that Bruce Lee itch.

reviewText:
Presentation
Originally developed under the title of True Crime: Hong Kong, what is now Sleeping Dogs is an open world action-adventure with the action set in modern city of Hong Kong, in the middle of a conflict between two different parts of the controlling Triad, Sun On Yee. You play as Detective Wei Shen, an officer sent deep undercover to work for one side of the conflicted Triad Sun On Yee, controlled by the Red Pole Winston Chu. As you get the know the main cast, information about your past will be unveiled, revealing important information about Wei Shen's previous Triad encounters, as he grew up in Hong Kong alongside Jackie Ma, another one of Winston's soldiers. As an undercover cop you will spend most of your time working for different members of the Sun On Yee, constantly meeting new characters and increasing your reputation in the eyes of the Triad leaders. Apart from infiltrating the Triad gangs and doing missions for them, you can also spend your time in Hong Kong as a cop solving different cases that require a man on the inside to gather the information. There are only a few cases to solve and most of them are easily forgettable, but they're fun to do, plus they offer a whole new perspective of the game, allowing you to easily shift between the bad guy and the good guy. The story takes around 18 hours to complete, a journey filled with memorable characters and a plot worth following with a payoff that might be unexpected, yet surprising and satisfying, concluding with an ending that is open to interpretation, giving you the final verdict and decide what to do next in Hong Kong after completing the story. There is no doubt that the story is amazing in its own way, but believe it or not that isn't even half of the greatness this game brings, as you'll probably spend even more hours wandering around Hong Kong, completing favors, taking part in street races or looking for lockboxes and health shrines. Sleeping Dogs isn't the ultimate open world experience, but it certainly amazes in its own way, offering multiple ways to spend your time between missions, from playing games like Mahjong Poker to betting on cockfights or participating in fighting tournaments.
Rating: 9.5

Gameplay
To whoever said there can be no further innovation on the current hardware, Sleeping Dogs is set to prove them wrong, big time; the amount of new and innovating mechanisms packed into Sleeping Dogs is quite surprising, introducing new ways to do things apparently simple, like picking a door or hacking a camera, creating a world in which almost every action in game requires a certain action on your side. There is so much to mention here, so only a few of the examples would be the bug calibration system that requires both analog sticks to be perfectly aligned with the environmental sound before plating the bug, or the camera hacking system that requires you to match the four digit code in order to access that camera. What is even more fantastic however, is the combat system, limiting shooting sequences to a few missions only, allowing you to concentrate on pure Kung-Fu melee combat; there are so many moves and combinations that make each encounter feel different, encouraging you to use every manoeuvre in your arsenal in order to defeat your enemies efficiently. The combat system allows you to interact with the environment too, as you can push your enemies towards a wall, smash their heads on the hood of a car or doing all sorts of things using the environment around you. In addition to your Kung-Fu moves, you can also use melee weapons like knives or hammers in combat, and disabling enemies using those to later use them yourself to your advantage. The shooting sequences are limited to only a few, yet they're satisfying and perfectly balanced with more Kung-Fu combats, creating an amazing and unique experience that no game could deliver before. There is also an experience system, which rewards you after each and every mission with experience points that will add up to a certain category, in which when you level up you can choose a new ability; completing missions for the Triads will award you Triad experience, while completing missions as a cop will award you cop experience, unlocking upgrades in a different category. In addition to Triad and Cop upgrades, you also earn Face experience for completing certain favours for random people you meet on the street, unlocking face upgrades that are this time more social oriented, offering things like reduced prices for cars or clothing.
Rating: 8.5

Graphics
Sleeping Dogs isn't the most advanced game out there graphically speaking, but it's decent and it does a visual impression in its own way. The city of Hong Kong might not be as detailed as it could have been, but it's full of life and action, and that is what really matters. There is always something new to do in Hong Kong, and exploring the map is certainly one of them, as you'll sometimes be amazed of what you can find on the top of an unexplored building. The characters are beautiful and detailed, delivering that drop of personality they need in order to create an amazing and emerging story; the animations are amazingly done on the main cast, but even the secondary characters take advantage of some decent facial animations. There are some visual bugs however, like pedestrians walking inside the concrete, but it's easy to ignore those if you look a moment at how large and detailed the city of Hong Kong really is.
Rating: 8

Audio
Surprising enough, the mixture of Chinese and English in the dialogue works better than expected, delivering great and memorable lines that never cease to amaze. The cast of Sleeping Dogs includes some major names from Hollywood like Emma Stone in the role of Amanda Cartwright, James Hong as Uncle Po or Lucy Liu as Vivienne Lu. Will Yun Lee has been cast as Wei Shen, and needless to say, he delivered the lines with that special touch that made Wei Shen an instant classic character in video games. There are some lip sync issues that are hard not to observe, since they'll appear in the most important cutscenes in the game, but not in all of them. The soundtrack is simply amazing, always in the mood with the action, while keeping the atmosphere of Hong Kong with some classic songs that will make you shuffle through the radio channels just to listen to your favorite track one more time.
Rating: 9

Extras
You're looking at more than 25 hours of content, considering that the game doesn't end with the story, since there is an enormous world to explore and hundreds of items to collect. In addition to that, you can spend your time doing races, fighting in tournaments or replaying missions; it's like the game never gets boring as you always find something else to do, especially if you enjoy completing achievements/trophies, as some of them present quite a challenge.
Rating: 10

Verdict
Sleeping Dogs is without doubt one of the best releases of 2012 and a must have for any open world adventures fans, delivering a great story, innovating gameplay and an astonishing number of additional collectibles and extras. The game offers a superb experience worth playing, but most of all it proves that there are a lot of things that haven't been done with the current hardware before, finding its way into the top of the most innovating gameplay mechanics on the current generation.
Rating Overall: 9

Check out the full review and a lot more about Sleeping Dogs at http://gamedragons.net/viewtopic.php?f=7&t=385

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs is easily one of the best open world crime sandboxes I've played in a long time. It is a nice blend of the later GTA's grittiness and realism, showing the deep dark underbelly of corruption and crime, while maintaining a slight sense of humor about it, a la Saint's Row.
The gameplay isn't exactly that different from any other games of this genere, save for the combat. The melee combat (which you use a lot) is very fluid, making stringing together combos a very rewarding challenge. The somewhat limited gunplay (lampshaded in-game by saying that guns are rare in Hong Kong) is nothing to write home about, yet I still found myself enjoying the occasional gun battle.
There are two things which got to me in this game: The story and the graphics. For a game two years old, the graphics blow me away, even on a medium-high setting. The story is the thing that had me hooked on the game the most. As a sufferer of gaming ADD, I found myself unable to pull away from the game!
I highly recommend Sleeping Dogs, regardless of the price.

reviewText:
GTA Hong Kong. I believe this is the easiest way to sum up Sleeping Dogs. But it would also be incorrect as it gives you the impression that the game you are going to play will be exactly a GTA game but its setting will be a different city. That is why you should try Sleeping Dogs as it is so much more!

Gameplay-wise it is exactly what the newer GTA games are: you have an open world game where you go wherever you want and you can do whatever you want. Of course, doing some hit-and-runs will only anger local police so they'll be after you pretty quickly. You can approach icons scattered throughout the game that launch missions - those that are essential to the main story progress are indicated by a different icon than those who serve to be side missions only.

There are TONS of things to do in Hong Kong: you can participate in racing games, sing at karaoke parties, date girls, bet on cockfights, join a fight club. You also have hundreds of collectable items. It's worth participating in all these activities as the game rewards you with experience points that let you level up only to learn new abilities.

In GTA you you had an assortment of firearms available for you to use. Here, emphasis is on hand-to-hand combat. Learning new abilities makes martials arts even better. Carjacking is also available but can happen much faster than in GTA - you can jump into vehicles and there are also car chase sequences in the game.

Story-wise you play Wei Shen, an undercover cop, who climbs the criminal corporate ladder only to get closer to the bad guys he needs to expose. There are some nice surprises here and there and just like GTA this game can also steal around 40 to 50 hours from your life.

A highly recommended game if you liked GTA IV or any of its third-person shooter predecessors.

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs is definitely one of the best gems on my steam account. The story is very cinematic and gripping. You follow Wei Shen who returns to Hong Kong as undercover cop to take out the triads. A bit of a cliche story line, but the animation, the characters' development and the output of the story are done really well. The only bits that were a bit weird were the scenes where Wei flirts with girls. He doesn't seem as smooth as Square Enix would have liked him to be, and instead comes across awkward and cheesy.

Gameplay wise, it's a treat. Combat system is like Batman Arkham Asylum (which is always a good thing), nice shooting controls and free roaming world would definitely put many GTA games to second best. Yes, this game is a lot better than most GTA games, as it's not overly long or has many unnecessary missions as I've felt with some GTA games.


Graphics are amazing, I put it on low because of my laptop power and I was still impressed.

The DLC isn't a highlight, but if you can get it for cheap you might as well. But the main story is the gem. Get this game!

8.75/10, would have been 9 or 10 if it wasn't for some bugs e.g. the radio playing the same song no matter which car you stole. Also the DLCs aren't amazing

reviewText:
Probably one of the most underrated games of 2012, Sleeping Dogs brings to the table an unique experience. From the interesting story, to the refreshing Kung Fu combat, every single bit of it is really enjoyable, but as every other games, it has it shortcomings.

Story & Setting
Sleeping Dogs is a third-person, open world, action game set in modern Hong Kong. The story revolves around Wei Shen, an undercover cop from San Francisco that left Hong Kong with his family when he was young, and his journey to infiltrate in Sun On Yee , a criminal organization who is both feared and respected. The main plot line is focused on Wei`s struggle between the two worlds, between what is right and what is wrong, between law or emotions. The second plot line is focused solely on his    work in Sun On Yee, where family and respect are the most important thigs, leading to some really intense moments.

Gameplay
The Gameplay is the best part of the game, and what you are gonna by doing most of the time. Inspired from Batman Arkham Asylum ,but with a twist of Kung Fu, the combat is one of the most enjoyable when it comes to Open World Action Games.
The mechanics are simple : You have an attack button, a counter button, a run button and a grapple button.
The basic combo consist in pressing the attack button a certain amount of times, and sometimes you have to hold it to increase the power of the attack. Also, you can combine the attack with either run or grapple in order to performa even more combos. But beware, most of those will have to be bought with statues that you find in missions from the dojo.
You main defence will be the counter button. Just as in Batman, when an enemy is about to attack he will flash red. If you hit the button at the right time, you will stop the attack and initiate a counterattack. Of course this does not work on all enemies, some will have to be disarmed in order to be able to counterattack
Of course, as in every action game, there are gonna be guns but they are very rare, and only certain missions will have it. The gunplay is cover-based, from which you can also blind fire or jump over in slow-motion. Some of the cover is destructible, but most of it is not. Be careful though, because the enemy will come after you if you don't kill them. When in a car chase, the gunplay consists either in shooting the bad guys or in shooting their tires, resulting in an awesome slowmo scene.
The biggest flaw that the combat has is that it can become a little repetitive after a while.

Graphics & Sound
Sleeping Dogs has THE best rainy scenes and the most detailed city I have ever seen in a game. The models are very nicely detailed and textured, the city is full of things hanging or flying. The detail put in this game is absolutely amazing. Even if you can't run it maxed out, you will be able to experience the beauty that this game has.
As for the sound I have to say that it is very immersive. From Traditional Chinese music, to modern club music, to some metal the game provides something for everybody. The voice acting for every single character is top notch and very authentic.

Conclusion
Sleeping Dogs is not a perfect game, not by any stretch of the imagination, but it IS a really good game which offers a great story and characters, but also a really good combat system that is very enjoyable to watch. It is an underrated game that deserve much more than it got.

reviewText: This is truly a hidden gem among the games that were released in 2012. If you are a fan of action cinema, asian cinema and those old 80s/90s films about crooked cops in urban areas that had fight sequences, or Jackie Chan movies like Rumble in the Bronx" I highly recommend this game. The story plays out exactly like those movies and the focus on hand to hand combat and martial arts and not gunplay also elevates this game to another level and separates it from games like Grand Theft Auto and Saints Row. Although there are gun sequences in the game they are only last resort time scenarios where the protagnist has no other choice but to use weapons as a means to get out of trouble. I also have to say that certain car sequences in the game feel and play out exactly like those in action films and it is a treat to engage in them. Highly Recommend this game."

reviewText:
Whoever came up with the title “Sleeping Dogs” must’ve had the biggest grin on their face when the name was approved. The game was originally pitched as a completely new IP, then rebranded as a reboot of the True Crime series, then pulled back into the series as True Crime: Hong Kong, and then canceled, only to be picked up by a different publisher for another rebranding and an actual release – the sleeping dog that nobody would let lie. Given that its initial announcement was in 2009, not to mention its ties to a less-than-revered franchise (does the True Crime name really move units?), it’s easy to understand why Sleeping Dogs simply isn’t showing up on many radars – we’re practically at a micro-Duke-Nukem-Forever at this stage. However, Sleeping Dogs shouldn’t be ignored. In fact, taking its rocky road to release into account, it’s an awesome surprise.

Open-world crime games aping movies are nothing new, but Sleeping Dogs nails it better than practically any other. As undercover cop Wei Shen, players will dive deep into Hong Kong’s criminal underworld, assuming the role of a Sun On Yee soldier with the intent of climbing the gang’s hierarchy and crippling it from the inside. Wei Shen has a personal vendetta against the gang, but it’s not long until his hands are as dirty as the rest of them. His loyalties to both the police and the Sun On Yee will be tried and tried again over the course of the increasingly violent story.

Does it sound corny? It is, and it’s frankly the game’s most interesting aspect. Plenty of video games attempt to place a conflicted main character at their core, criminals with hearts of gold who are just doing what they have to, waxing poetic about life and death in a maudlin cutscene before the actual gameplay starts, in which the player is far more likely to see how long they can drive on the sidewalk before getting shot than they are to sit and ponder deep questions about killing, honor and redemption. Sleeping Dogs does all of that, but it’s dressed up in the wonderful melodramatic styling of a classic Hong Kong crime film. Wei Shen is angry and unhinged, the Sun On Yee are violent and feudalistic, and the police are cold-hearted and shifty. The game’s script embraces cheese and contradiction, lampshading the disconnect between story and gameplay far better than most crime games with a serious tone. Sleeping Dogs isn’t a comedy or a satire, but it knows that it’s pulpy.

The action movie influence seeps into the gameplay itself, too. Sleeping Dogs focuses mainly on hand-to-hand brawling, employing a combat system that feels like a less refined version of Arkham Asylum or The Warriors. There isn’t a prominent combo counter, but there are counter moves that can be triggered as soon as an enemy flashes red – a slightly jarring visual – and some truly brutal punch-kick strings activated by tapping or holding the attack button in certain orders. It’s slightly jerky and robotic feeling, mostly due to a lack of transition animations, but it can be very satisfying. More interesting are the throws and grabs that make use of environmental hazards, which usually involve Wei Shen shoving a goon’s head into something sharp or spinning (or both). All of these attacks are straight out of Hong Kong crime films, and they are all awesome. Heck, even when there aren’t any interesting objects around to push people into, Wei Shen can still sprint full-tilt towards the nearest wall and smash the person he’s holding into the hard surface head-first.

Then there’s the driving, which feels very tight and arcade-y. Cars and bikes go incredibly fast and are almost all very nimble, save for a few trucks and mopeds. The streets of Hong Kong are lots of fun to speed through when you can turn on a dime, and car chases are pretty thrilling because of it. There are a few control issues once action-hijacking and shooting are introduced, though – even though the pace slows down time a tad to help you keep track of everything, it’s often very easy to jump onto the wrong car, or pile straight into a wall while trying to shoot something behind you. However, the fact that these are all things you can do is undeniably cool, and actually jumping onto the right car, clambering across the roof, and kicking the driver out of their seat is immensely satisfying.

The third major section of the action is shooting, which mostly plays out like you’d expect. There are guns, there are chest-high-walls, dudes pop out and you shoot them. It’s definitely the least remarkable pillar of the game, although there are a couple of interesting mechanics that save it from being too dull – namely, the way the game encourages you to vault over cover at enemies, rather than sticking around in one spot shooting people as they peek over their hiding spot. Sleeping Dogs employs a heavy dose of slow-mo when you complete certain actions – leaping over cover, disarming a foe – which makes clearing large groups of enemies really easy. Thankfully, on-foot shooting missions are in the minority, although there are some straightforward run-and-gun sections towards the end of the game that can get pretty dull.

If only the PC version let you assign separate keys for some actions, rather than using the obviously console-oriented “press-then-release-then-press-again-really-fast” setup – I imagine a lot of the control issues would be nonexistent. With a mouse and keyboard, some of Sleeping Dogs can be a bit of a headache. Sprinting and jumping over objects requires timed presses of the same sprint key – likewise, getting ready to jump out of your car and actually jumping out of your car are two actions tied to the same key, which just feels odd with all of the options available on a keyboard. Moving Wei around can feel a little stiff, as well – thankfully, the game supports controllers without a hitch. I’d strongly recommend a gamepad.

The overall package of Sleeping Dogs is helped immensely by its presentation and atmosphere. While the character models and animation aren’t great, the Hong Kong they inhabit is gorgeous. There are moments where the game practically bleeds cool – rain-soaked streets, gaudy neon lights and the bright metropolitan skyline. The voice acting is appropriately over-the-top, and the character designs get more and more sleazy-looking as Wei makes his way up the Sun On Yee. There are some great missions, too, one-offs that feel like they belong in cult crime films. One sees you sneaking into a superstitious man’s house and messing with his furniture to screw up his feng shui. There are some truly horrifying revenge killings. You can also date Emma Stone.

I wonder how Sleeping Dogs would have been if it had been released in 2010 as True Crime, or 2011 as True Crime: Hong Kong. The game is a tad unpolished as it is in 2012, so clearly there were reasons to push it back. However, if the game was as charming and interesting as it is now, I have no idea why anyone would cancel the project. Sleeping Dogs is a great action game with a compellingly melodramatic story and an atmosphere thick enough to cut with a knife. Control issues aside, it’s a great PC port, too – on a beefy gaming PC, Sleeping Dogs looks far better than its console counterparts. For fans of Hong Kong cinema and/or open-world games, it’s a must.

My Rating: 8.7/10

reviewText: If you want an outstanding open world action game with gorgeous graphics, thrilling story and a great melee combat system, then look no further. reviewText:
I rather enjoyed my playthrough of Sleeping Dogs, a Hong Kong set entry into the open-world crime genre.  The story follows Wei Shen, an undercover cop, as he attempts to infiltrate and undermine the local Triads.  I found the story engaging and the various characters memorable, and while the plot doesn’t offer too much in the way of surprises for those familiar with organized crime and undercover police stories, it does tell its tale with panache and style.

The undercover angle to the story also makes its way into the gameplay, encouraging you to balance violence and brutality to please the Triads with an adherence to law and order and minimized collateral damage to appease Wei’s police handlers.  It’s a great idea, but it really only comes into play during story missions.  Personally, I would have liked to see it expanded into other aspects of gameplay, especially the game’s side missions.

Further differentiating Sleeping Dogs from its neighbors is a focus on brawling over gunplay, which given the setting and story seems quite appropriate.  The fighting mechanics are accessible and I enjoyed opportunities to thrash hordes of thugs with little more than fists and whatever was around at the time.

Sleeping Dogs gets my thumbs up.  According to my Steam clock, I put about 25 hours into the game.  Time well spent, in my opinion.  My only caveat is that I found the game to play much better with a controller instead of mouse and keyboard, though that may be a matter of taste more than anything else.

reviewText: You play as Rover, the friendly and intelligent family dog. You are the biggest corgi the world has ever seen, and you must eat all the sausages in the kitchen, until you can fight no longer, and you become the Sleeping Dog. Really now, you play as a Jackie Chan double who is actually a sleeper agent (hence the name, hurr durr) and you want no trabble. You fight your way through several ladder factories while holding several different babies, in your fight against slightly bigger asian people that look like they're straight out of Fast and Furious. You go through several losses, in this trainless society, and sleep with many ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, although it is wisely disguised as if you are getting a massage from a massage parlour. You go through several girlfriends, and lose none of the perks that came with them after you pump and dump through all of them, essentially leaving the world with several Jackie Chan babies. You also learn many secret hidden techniques by picking up some sort of Chinese takeout food, or something along those lines, I don't really recall because it was unmemorable, but that's besides the point. The game has you fighting in a very enticing combat system that allows you to have fun while you steamroll everybody as if you were a train. What this game lacks in trains, it makes up for in witty dialog, enticing story, and fun gameplay. The main character is likeable, and most of the game is played through his eyes where he's constantly at odds of being caught by the criminals he associates with. Overall, if you want a fun, and mindless beat 'em up game, with a karaoke minigame in it that frankly deserves its own review, you should get Sleeping Dogs, because who doesn't want to be an oversized corgi, fighting sausages in the kitchen?

reviewText:
Well, first of all, Sleeping Dogs is one of the greatest and most fascinating games of all the time. Some people would say that it's a copy of GTA Series but i disagree. Yea, I will admit that it looks similar because you complete missions, fight, steal cars, got your own house etc but Sleeping Dogs is totally different from any GTA Game.

Sleeping Dogs is a superb and amusing game FULL of action. At every mission you must fight with thugs, punch their faces, drive with a car and probably escape from the cops. I know it sounds like the gameplay of any other Action game, but to be honest I was impressed from this one.
The game takes place in China, Hong Kong and the atmosphere is really realistic.
The story of the game is an interesting one and if you play the game I'd suggest you not to skip the parts of the dialogues.
The part I like most from Sleeping Dogs, is the fighting system. There is a variety of techniques and combination of buttons in order to perform special moves and punches. There is also the ability to grab an enemy and throw him somewhere in order to make him die with a brutal way.

I actually couldn't notice any remarkable con but I didn't like the driving system and the storyline quests are quite easy I can say. Except these, there are some small glitches in the game but they are not remarkable tho.

+ Interesting Story
+ FULL of Action Game
+ Realistic Atmosphere
+ Fighting/Combat System
+ Brutal Gameplay/Kills
+ Free-running mode

- Driving System
- Easy Storyline Quests
- Small Glitches

Overall Rating: 9.5/10

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs was a great surprise! Yes, it is a GTA clone indeed, but it only takes the best aspects from Rockstar's games and then tries to add something new to it, like a good hand to hand combat system, a big selling point for this title.

You play as an undercover cop with a dark past who infiltrates the dangerous Honk Kong triads, trying in the meantime to solve some intricate cases for the local police department.
This dualism between the good and the bad sides of the main character is well used by the developers, missions are always interesting and fun to play, you want to go ahead and discover what happens next.
Secondary missions are not bad either, even buying vechicles and clothes in order to obtain different bonuses is well implemented and not a mere filler.

Sleeping Dogs is also very easy to play, a bit arcadey if you want, and with some small control glitches, but immediate to master. Technically I really liked the graphics (download the highres textures!) and the voices of the characters, very well interpreted. Honk Kong is a big city with its different districts, not so diversified as any other GTA, but interesting to explore nonetheless. The story is well narrated, nothing breathtaking but good enough to keep you playing for at least 20-30 hours.

In the end I think I can suggest this game to any other GTA fan who wants something a bit different and fresh, while maintaining a well know gameplay infrastructure. If you don't already have Sleeping Dogs maybe this is the right moment to buy it, the Definitive Edition just went live with better graphics and all DLCs included!

reviewText: This game right here may be the game of the year for me. Sleeping Dogs takes the best of the openworld undercover genre and shakes it up with its own style. Instead of run and gunning like GTA or DEM SAINTS you'll be focusing on hand to hand combat throughout much of the game. Alot more guns do eventually come into play when things get a bit crazier and serious and I'm glad that they worked it out that way as it really adds to the feel that triad war is heating up. The story is actually really well done, cutscenes are pretty and the voiceacting is fantastic. Most importantly though they build up characters just right so that you can empathize with them (with the exception of one VERY forced character that you spend the day driving around). You never feel overwhelmed with stuff like in GTA and the story tension keeps you going for completion of main missions. There are a ton of clothes to collect, so you can look stylin' while you do your thing. The game killed someone I liked so 9.9/10
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs, just like Just Cause and Saints Row, was once a pretender to the GTA throne when it was called True Crime but just like those other two game series its easily topped anything the recent GTA games have done. Though in this case its by actually managing to pull off a (mostly) serious crime game with an actual likeable cast of characters and an interesting plot that actually gels with the sandbox gameplay well. (Wei Shen is not a very good cop or nice man.)

The gameplay is a beat-em-up style akin to the Batman Arkham games and while it may take some getting used to once you do it becomes real fun and it can be really brutal, with the ability to break legs, chucking thugs into open furnaces, and sending a guy careening into a table saw.

The game is also not afraid to have some fun and be a bit silly,  you can dress up as a luchador in a tux or play a mission where you have to perform karaoke badly for example. There's also DLC where you fight Jiang-Shi.

Alongside Red Dead Redemption Sleeping Dogs is one of my favorite sandbox games and I heartily recommend it.

reviewText: Sleeping Dogs is a solid GTA style game within a Hong Kong setting. The game world is vibrant and lively and the driving is smooth and easy to handle. Combat places a heavier emphasis on brawling rather than gunplay but both feel spectacular and robust. reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs is a great game and has a lot going for it.

First of is the graphics. The game looks amazing on pc if you download the free HD texture pack. All the settings you would expect to bee in a pc game is there, and im glad to see a publisher that actually give us the full experience thats possible with a pc.

The gameplay is no less then amazing. With the focus being on hand to hand combat, and using the environment to your advantage in spectacularly violent finishing moves, makes the fighting exciting and action packed. The guns are nothing special, the fun is found in the martial art style moves you can pull off. The combos aren't hard to pull off, but still give you that satisfying feeling when you do them. you learn more advanced and damaging moves as you progress through the game, and the pacing feels right.

The story of this game is actually really solid. When i bought this game I expected a mediocre story at best, but when I got when i started playing, i found my self sucked in. I played the whole main story doing every mission back to back, which is really rare for me. The characters are well developed and the missions where really varied, and there was no feeling of doing repetitive tasks.

The world it self looks gorgeous. I love the setting, and the city feels vibrant and alive. You can pretty much go anywhere you like, and there is a lot of little minigames, like participate in illegal fighting tournaments to win cash, collecting the jade-statues for new combos, hacking securety cameras and much more.

The only downside to this game is that the best experience requires a controller. If you have one, this game is a no-brainer.

The overall experience is great. I would reccomend this game at full price to pople who enjoy openworld ''GTA-Like'' games, and at a discount this is a must have for pretty much anyone.

reviewText: Sleeping Dogs provides players with an engrossing narrative set to the atmospheric and richly-detailed backdrop of Hong Kong. An extensive array of additional missions and activities ensure there are always opportunities for further adventure and action to discover while roaming the streets. Along with an impressive presentation for both the visuals and music, Sleeping Dogs is without doubt the sleeper hit of 2012 for open world action games.Square Enix and United Front Games pulled Sleeping Dogs from the brink of death, and what surprised me is just how good it turned out to be.Unlike the previous ‘True Crime’ games, where there was a strict depiction of the city maps, Sleeping Dogs does not portray Hong Kong, inch by inch. United Front Games has implemented GTA’s novelties in way that winks slyly at Rockstar. In essence, what the GTA series has accomplished, Sleeping Dogs has carried out better and more elegantly.This game is a very pleasant surprise that's throwing down the gauntlet to GTA V with its Cantonese oral insult. The game's story along with plenty of gaming mechanics' innovation make Sleeping Dogs a truly remarkable and never-ending joyride with no intention to imitate the original at all costs.Sleeping Dogs is now the example developers should strive to beat when they want to create a game in this genre, because Square Enix's title is now the new leader of the pack.

reviewText:
Looking for a great story driven, immersive open world action RPG?  Look no further.

Sleeping Dogs originally came out to little fanfare. It just sort of was THERE suddenly. I took a chance on it when I originally saw it, and it payed off. This is a good game.

The game itself follows the exploits of Wei Shen, an undercover cop sent in to infiltrate and bring down the Triads in Hong Kong.
And exploits indeed! You'll find yourself doing everything from making deliveries, to burning down rival gang warehouses, carting around women planning their weddings, singing karaoke, racing, and much, much more.

The gameplay itself is great, everything flows smooth, and looks good. If you're familiar with Grand Theft Auto, you'll probably feel right at home here, with a few exceptions.

One of those exceptions is the combat system. In most open world games there's very little melee. Usually a punch or a kick and that's about it. In SD, there's a fully features fighting system that's like a cross between Soul Calibre and Die Hard Arcade. It's fun, though it can be challenging. I found myself rather enjoying when fights came my way.

There's also a shooting aspect, which isn't particularly impressive, though quite functional.
There's also more parkour bits than in games like GTA. You'll find yourself running after suspects (or running away from them) at several points in the game, over rooftops and through back alley markets.

The graphics, as I mentioned, are quite good. The game is a few years old now and even without the high-res textures, Hong Kong has rarely looked more immersive. Tall buildings, bright lights, weather effects, you name it. It's all very convincing.

There are a few things to be cautioned about though. The game is VERY bloody, and there's a TON of language. It's not really surprising, given the subject matter, but the squeemish may want to hold off. Just in fights alone you can slash people with knives and cleavers, break arms and legs, slam faces into ventilations fans, and use a number of other environmental objects to deliver what are very clearly death-blows to your enemies. The majority of which are shown. There's also some even more grisly things which are more implied than shown.
The language would be a definite R rating as well. The characters in the Triad drop F bombs like they're going out of style.

The game lacks multiplayer, though it does allow you to compare scores and records with your friends. Silly things like longest wheelie, highest number of hit and runs in a row, largest amount of money collected from parking meters, etc are all counted, and the game will show you who of your friends has the highest record for you to beat, while you're doing it; so you have a reference.

The story itself is more or less linear, but solid. You do develop attachments to the characters and what happens around them. I would say it stands up a bit better than the GTAV story. The ending though did feel a little bit rushed. (I'll avoid any spoilers) Most all the writing and dialogue is pretty good, though the romance parts of the game fell pretty flat.
(I got yelled at by a girl for cheating on her" with a girl I met all of one time
date:
and I didn't even know I was supposedly dating the first girl.)


TLDR/

All in all
recommended: Sleeping Dogs is a fantastic game. It has some flaws but most of them are small and easy to ignore. It's definitely in my list of all-time great games. I highly recommend it."

reviewText: Each and every game made is a different answer to the question Why play this?" A good answer is an unexpected one and relies not on what is said but how is said. So when Sleeping Dogs tells me that I get to do consequence-free Triad enforcing
date: then buy and buy stuff with the fruit of my labors or succeed in Karaoke it is abundantly clear that sometimes not thinking can be just as fun as thinking.\n\nThe player stars as Wei
recommended: an undercover police officer infiltrating the Sun On Yee criminal organization using all the well-established fictional ways of doing so. Sleeping Dogs' level of realism can only be described as "this makes no damn sense whatsoever." In an early mission Wei and his goofball friend take a shipment from their rivals with force. After Wei beats down two waves of thugs the survivors flee in a car and the friends give pursuit
hoursPlayed: ramming enemy reinforcements off the road along the way. Finally they claim their prize of.... worthless knock-offs of luxury watches. Why on Earth would anyone use so much muscle to guard something with no value? And why are there no repercussions afterwards
voteText: let alone any mention of the event? The answer to A is because the plot demanded comedy and the answer to B is that the game must go on. B also applies to the Hong Kong police who make the Skyrim guards look like unrelenting angels of justice. Should the police pursue Wei he just rams them off the road and the police department immediately forgives and forgets.\n\nSadly the writing does not work on it's own either
helpfulPercent: even if separated from the game mechanics. Wei has enough skill to make Jason Bourne look like a mall cop and people are always telling Wei how awesome he is. The reason the Triads suspect him is that he is too good to be true
votesHelpful: as they say to each other behind Wei's back! The women Wei dates are there to literally say "Oh
votesFunny: you are so resourceful!" and little else. Wei carves a bloody swathe through Hong Kong and when his handler quite reasonably tells him that he is too dangerous Wei uses the "mavericks get results" defence that of course works and Wei gets to continue. In another instance a short questline is ended with Wei being told he just got more done than the entire Drug Division accomplished in the last six months. Even more insufferable are the scenes where Wei is torn between the police and the underworld. In all the scenes Wei gets to be right and ultimately I was relieved when some thug punched his face in a non-scripted event.\n\nBut while the story is best ignored there still are reasons to play. Wei is unsymphatetic due to his inhuman perfection but the city of Hong Kong is symphatetic for the opposite reasons. The vendors are nothing short of hilarious
commentsCount: with a man selling cheap tea reminding that the gods are watching
column16: a clothes booth owner immediately reassuring a new customer that all his merchandise is completely genuine and legal and a junk food seller telling that no man is a man without a pork bun in his hand. It takes no small effort to get a grown man excited about shopping and this is the games biggest triumph. Running around buying everything from awareness bands to canarie cages and luxury sports cars described as being "For the man who has everything and wants everyone to know it" never got old even on my replay. The same smorgasbord philosophy extends to the activities that let you succeed in Karaoke
column17: be the street racer king or beat down a fight club's worth of contenders for money to live out any lingering consumerist fantasy.\n\nBy now the fundaments of criminal sandboxes are so familiar and well-established that they require no descriptive detail apart from saying that they are there and they work as do the meat-and-potatoes sights and sounds. I was happy
column18: however
column19: with placing the emphasis on melee instead of gunplay as well as the close combat system itself. It requires a bit of a learning process as well as stacking bonuses for full effect. You should also know that it is extremely violent
column20: particularly the environmental finishers where you toss thugs into furnaces or impale them on meat hooks
column21: so it is best to consider this before purchase. Wei accumulates XP in three different trees and expands his array of moves and attacks at a steady pace. All in all the game is dangling a juicy carrot worth pursuing quite succesfully. There are many minigames and collectibles along the way
column22: mostly harmless. The DLCs can be split into two categories. All the smaller ones
column24: are the Square Enix assembly line junk we all know and should be skipped. Some of them even force considerable bonuses on a new game that makes it best to disable them manually with some jury rigging -- or not buy them at all in the first place. There are three larger ones
column26: Zodiac Tournament and Year of the Snake. I have yet to play but would recommend Googling first and waiting for a sale. The base game is self-sufficient and expanding it can wait.\n\nSleeping Dogs is ultimately best described in song. The kitschy sleaze-pop of the soundtrack original Yellow Fever sounds like a cheap knock-off that somehow winds up being value for dollar even though it should not. As I played the guilty part of guilty pleasure wore off and I can recommend Sleeping Dogs for anyone in the mood for the digital equivelant of the Chinese all-you-can-eat buffet available anywhere."

reviewText: This game is awesome. The storyline is incredibly gripping and causes the player to really feel some feelz. I also want to make a comment on the quality of the AIs: I could predict who was going to do what in the fights because they behaved like actual humans. This is one of the few games I've ever played where this is the case. The graphics are amazing, even on medium. Not to mention that I can actually run it on my laptop. Although it's no longer the newest game in the franchise, I feel I must make a comparison to Grand Theft Auto 4. The graphics in this are better than GTA 4's graphics, and it freezes and crashes on the first load screen for me. The only complaint I have is the occasional small bug, i.e. in the very first part of the game (the part where you're running from the cops), the guy I was supposed to be following decided that the middle of us being chased by the cops was just the absolute perfect time to stop running, confusing the hell out of me in the process. Anyways, thanks for reading this exteremely long review (assuming that any of you have :/) and to the developer I say keep up the great work! :D

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs is an absolutely outstanding game. This has a spot on my top 10 favorite games of all time.

The fighting mechanic is extremely fun. The gunplay is great too. The cars handle really well; it all just feels great.

The story can go a bit fast at times, but there's great writing here. The dialogue has made me laugh many times, in a good way though.

It is kind of a short game; when I wrote this review, I've beat all the cop and Triad missions, along with the Nightmare in North Point DLC. I really enjoyed my time with it though, and will probably go back for a near 100% run.

Buy it. You won't regret it.

reviewText: Coming into this game, I expected a mediocre GTA clone set in Hong Kong. Now, having played about 12 hours or 30% of the whole game, I feel that I like this more than I liked Dishonored.\n\nThe story is the best I've seen for any open-world action/crime game. Wei Shen is an undercover cop who is tasked with taking down the Triads of Hong Kong from within, attempting to balance loyalty to the law and playing the part of a gang member. As the story progresses, you get to know more about certain characters that would be considered the bad guys" and morality in this game is no longer black and white. Having not finished it yet

reviewText:
United Front Games has certainly created a masterpiece.
The story is amazing, tons of stuff to do, such as street races, karaoke, collecting lockboxes and so on. 30 hours of gameplay guaranteed.
Oh, almost forgot to say that the soundtrack is just superb!
However there were some bugs and things that I didn't like, for example, I met a girl, got her number, went out with her once and then the number would disappear from my phone. That's pretty lame in my opinion.

Despite that, a solid 9.5/10!

P.S. - DLCs that are worth buying in my opinion: Wheels of Fury, Nightmare in North Point, Year of the Snake. They are pretty short, but still really fun!

reviewText:
Open world grand theft auto kung fu madness - The only way I can explain this game in some simple words that all would understand.

Okay.

The graphics are fairly decent with not amazing but certainly not bad but really good to look at.
The controls are really easy to get used too, even hoping from car to car is so easy you cannot complain.
The sound seems like a silly cheap movie rip off I found which is amusing but becomes boring after a while, and I went around playing with no sound listening to music.

The game itself is good fun with a small world but you learn to push past that when you notice you do a few decent stuff in the world, and the DLC in the game is really nice too.

The story I did not play and complete because I was not impressed that much.  It was go here beat this person, go here catch this person, go chase this person, repeat, repeat, repeat and I was bored after only 11hours in this game.  I am sure the story contains some amazing moments but it did not grab me quick enough to keep me entertained.

I did pay £29.99 for this game as a preorder and now the game is £14.99 (Now on sale as we speak for £2.99 which is a STEAL) and the £14.99 is really cheap as it is because of what the game offers.

If you like open world, stealing cars, beating people, kung fu fighting, just cause leaping from cars, then this game will keep you going for way longer than myself.

You really nice feature in the game was the car control.  The sounds on the cars, and the way it dips and dives when turning, specially the bikes was sooooo nice.

Anyway, this game is worth the time and money you want to put into it.

Shame there was no multiplayer and only singleplayer but still. Good fun.

reviewText:
Overall:

-Quick paced, melee oriented combat. (Kung Fu action cop approved)
- Immersive city atmosphere. (Rainstorm + Nighttime + Red lightdistrict = Wow)
-Mediocre undercover cop plot. (The pacing was really wonky, sub-plots felt underdeveloped, story  won't suprise you, much.)
-Unique control scheme, probably recommend a gamepad. (Right click to enter cars)

reviewText:
Awesome game. I think to myself, why I didn't play it sooner. It's better than most of the other sandbox games on the market in terms of quality.

This game takes open world to a new level, Hong Kong Island looks amazing in it. I've lived in Hong Kong and whilst the game is obviously on a a smaller scale to real life, it really captures the feel of Hong Kong very well.

The combat is really fun and this game feels like a combination of GTA, Assassins Creed and Shenmue.

Great combat, interesting plot, brilliantly designed sandbox and some fun and unique gameplay additions. Well done to Square Enix for once too, actually picking up a failed Activision product and getting it released. Maybe you aren't as bad as I thought, you should get United Front Games to do collab work with you on every game.
voteText: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
An excellent entry by Square Enix into the third-person crime genre, alongside more celebrated titles such as Grand Theft Auto and Saints Row. The game revolves around a well-written plot involving the player as an undercover Hong Kong police officer returned from America who has been tasked with infiltrating the local triads to shut them down. An fantastic cast featuring some very distinctive and memorable characters who you grow to sympathise with and love or hate regardless of their faction complements a twisting, turning, and storyline, with an explosive conclusion.

While many games which do not focus on driving have driving issues, the driving in Sleeping Dogs is quite smooth, regardless of the vehicle you may be driving, whether it be a car, van, or motorcycle. This is complemented by the damage you can do in vehicles, and also by the incredibly fun ability to enter moving enemy vehicles... provided you don't fall off, of course!

An incredibly fun open world experience based on the city of Hong Kong, the lack of air vehicles does not actually limit the game, with the ability to get to various places, even some quite high, on foot. The map and city is well-designed, and the game's ability to mix things up with extra side material such as catching criminals, hacking cameras, cracking locks, and singing karaoke only increases the game's allure.

And then, finally. The combat. Despite the ability to slow time, and move over, to and around cover while shooting is quite nice, it is in close quarters hand-to-hand combat that the game shines. With the ability to pick up various items and wield them as weapons, from cleavers to handbags to fish, you can be sure that a fistfight will turn bloody and conclude quite brutally. The visceral nature of hand-to-hand combat is furthered by the implementation of environmental hazards" - objects or locations in the world which you can use to finish off your enemies. Incredibly enjoyable and interesting
recommended: the close combat in this game is truly a standout feature."

reviewText:
I find this game extremely overrated (but I would still buy it again on discount thought, it was good enough). The story feels weak, mediocre at most. It had nice moments, but mostly was really straightforward, without any plot twists whatsoever. The side missions were insanely repetitive and the races were just easy. Fights are button mashings mostly (yes, it's a brawler in open world with missions rather than sneaking or going full loud with bazookas), only collecting jade statues (12 in total, but around half of them obtainable during main missions) can upgrade your moves. You had a weapon during mission? Too bad, it won't be any more after you finish it. You have a knife to butcher through your enemies? Too bad, it will last only a couple if hits. I wonder if it was made of wood or glass it would last longer... When you get accustomed to the notion of brawling with LMB-LMB-hold LMB-LMB and catching enemy from time to time there are guns introduced, but only for a couple of missions (remember above where I said about weapon lasting only until the end of the mission?) and it feels like a really forced addon. Most of the times you would crouch behind something and then vault in from of it, the game would put a huge slo-mo and you'd headshot everyone in the room. Booooring.
What's great is the port of the game itself. The game looks beautifully, uses DX10/11, has a free HD textures pack (additional 4GB to download), the steering/controlling is responsible and I haven't find any problems with camera as well.
Like I said, I would still buy it again, I just wanted to point out the most of the things that were downgrading my experience while playing the game. Of course, there would be achievement-♥♥♥♥♥s, who would play the game until 100% (which includes lots of golden in-game awards), but I play only for the story, and everything else which isn't good enough for me is just distracting me.

GTA4 is still the best :S

reviewText:
Hmm... where do I start with this game? Well for starters, this overlooked title is frequently compared to the GTA franchise. So what does this game have to offer?

What I like about this game:
- The setting of Hong Kong, loosely based off of the real Hong Kong that is...
- The hand-to-hand combat with interactivity of the environment to even the odds a bit (and because it looks fancy).
- The story following an undercover police officer.
- The protagonist Wei Shen and the characters he interacts with.
- The colorful environment making Hong Kong feel active (especially the night market)

Stuff that gave me mixed feelings or have no opinion on:
- The AI: sometimes their behavior get pretty wonky at times, but nothing majorly broken with them
- The side activities: they're okay if not a little underwhelming since there isn't a lot of stuff to do aside from side quests. For me, the two gambling activities are kind of a waste of your time unless you want a method to toss your money away more quickly.
- Environmental glitches: I encountered about one or two bugs, with one of them involving a wire attached to a security camera floating in the middle of a parking lot, but nothing major.
- The protagonist Wei Shen never speaking a single word in Cantonese (he said one word in Cantonese in the wheels of fury dlc, much to my suprise). Honestly it confuses me a little bit, but that's just a minor complaint. I'm just going to assume he just has a preference to strictly speaking english anyway.
- Guns: yes, yes, nothing's fun without gunplay, but obtaining guns is a little different than what you would expect from GTA. While gunplay is pretty fun, there is no way of purchasing firearms or ammunition so the only way you can get them outside of story missions (and occasionally DLC) is to do it the hard way: steal them from the HKPD. Completing the story will get you a golden Desert Eagle for you to use.
- The map size: a bit small for an open world game, but it's tolerable.
- The mini map: most of the time, directions for way points work, but there was one area that partially breaks the GPS and tells you to go around in circles until you disobey it.


What I didn't like:
- The ending: It didn't bother me too much, but I kinda wish you could become a member of the Triads full-time or stay loyal to the Hong Kong Police Department.
- The DLC: personally I think most of them don't really offer much, but I think a few of them are probably worth purchasing, especially if they're on sale.
- The second to last story mission: specifically it is the quick-time event on the scaffolding where button mashing is required. The reason why I hate that sequence is because there is a programing error that if you rapidly button mash, you will fail regardless of how fast you press the spacebar. How to get past it is to find a steady rhythm and keep the rhythm for about 20 - 30 seconds. (Note that it took me 10 minutes to figure out what was going on and go to the forums to look for help. I know, it's really sad to admit that it took me that long for me to figure it out)
- Animation quality: they didn't put a lot of effort into animation outside of the official cutscenes. They put effort into lip-syncing and movement in the cutscenes, but didn't even try to put any effort outside of that, althought when it comes to movement like walking and running, they are just fine. (I should note that they semi-locked" the camera to make sure you don't see Wei's face
date: and when you do see it
recommended: it's very obvious they didn't even bother)\n- Camera angles: my main pet peev comes from driving when you want to go reverse
hoursPlayed:
the camera automatically rotates around the car and I'd rather do it manually because it feels really disorienting to have the game do it for me.

What will kick most people in the teeth:
- The lack of a multiplayer: the game has a social hub for you to compare scores with your friends
voteText: but some people like me will not care about numbers and might be upset that there is no physical multiplayer to play with your friends.\n\nDespite my complaints
helpfulPercent: this game has plenty to offer and is definitely worth the current price tag and deserves more attention that it currently has."

reviewText:
An underrated classic.

Sleeping Dogs is one of those games that while hardly mentioned regularly, most of the times ends in a circle jerk, and rightfully so. While hyped a good bit before release and achieving midly successful sales figures, it still seems to be put on the back-burner when in the midst of contemporary, and decidly lower quality titles.

Originally to be published by Activision under the title True Crime: Hong Kong, Sleeping Dogs seemed like nothing more than a disater waiting to happen, though the perseverance of its development team is truly laudable. Developed by little known United Front games, the end result would've been a tossup with their lack of lack track record.

Story: The Story of Sleeping Dogs is truly one of its shining aspects, settings a strong progression of events and plot twists. The player takes control of Wei Shen, a skilled but troubled police officer, in his assignment to infiltrate one of the many 'Triad' gangs, the 'Sun on Yee', and dismantle it from within. Lines get increasingly blurred as his loyalties waver throughout the plot, added greatly to by the games surpisingly deep back story for our protagonist.

Atmosphere: The setting and feel of Sleeping Dogs are yet more of its strong points, painting a vivid and believable interpretation of Hong Kong. The intricacies of different city districts, the clash between the criminal underground, the old world shops, and modern business all contribute to an enriching and deep experience in the city.

Gameplay: Gameplay is new and exciting, taking the best of other titles, and grinding them down into a polished system. Borrowing from the Arkham series, melee combat takes a free-flow styled system, with a large and varied set of strikes, counters, and combos, allowing fights to stay fresh without becoming stale and repetitive. Parkour is also a highly rewarding feature, letting you slide over cars, mantle buildings, and move around the city in the way you want to. Driving is very well done, even rivaling games where driving is its sole purpose.



Ratings:
Graphics: 9/10
Story: 9.5/10
Gameplay: 9.5/10
Audio: 9/10
Atmosphere: 9.5/10
Overall: 9.3/10

reviewText:
I just finished the game, so all of this is kind of a recent pile of thoughts.

The story:
Wei Shen, an undercover cop has to get into the Sun On Yee, one of the triads in Hong Kong. Old friends, new friends, lovers, enemies, and bitterness is what follows his mission to the very end, which is one of the greates cliamxes in any games I've ever played so far. It's like a really awesome TV series coming to a satisfying end.
The base of the story is a dolig one, which we could see a hundred, maybe a thousand times. But man...they did a wonderful job for making it work better than anything else that follows the same path. You'll feel the friends in the game are truly your friends - and their betrayal will hurt you even more. You'll find yourself cheering when something turns out great, and feel anger you never thought you could ever feel. While you don't have much choices storylinewise, the one you get will be usually the best. You'll kill when you need, but feel guilty for it, when you did not. And what makes it all possible?
The characters. Wei Shen is a really great protagonist for a game like this. A cop, who has lots of friends from his childhood in the triads, but his supervisor gives him the orders. You'll feel the weight of the things he has to go through, and you'll even feel sorry for him some times. And thus, the payoff will be the better because all of this. Then you have people who knew Wei from his childhood. Jackie, who appears to be the comedic sidekick, but he is indeed much more. A loyal friend, a brother in arms who'll be by your side every time. Then there's Winston, the Red Pole (triad rank), who was first a bit skeptical about you, but he'll become a good friend too. You'll understand him, and you'll ultimately feel sorry for him. And that was just two of the many great and memorable characters from the game.
The writing is really good. It's logical, the interactions between the characters are genuine, you know that it was written by someone who can create good characters, and instead of making them do what needs to be done, he or she just creates them, puts them into Hong Kong, and watch what do they do. There are fillers in the discussions between the characters, but they feel anything but forced. They are chatting, enjoying themselves, nothing serious. Just what you'd do if you were roaming the city with your best friend riding shotgun.
Overall the story, characters, game concept, and writing gets a 10/10 - really enjoyable, and I'm sure even folks who are not into the moral dilemmas of being an undercover cop will find the game interesting.

Gameplay:
It follows the road GTA has set up (or at least as far as I know, but it could happen that it wasn't the first game like this), third person view, open world, sandbox feeling, etc. If you played any GTA games, from III to V, you are familiar with the concept. But instead of guns, the emphasis is more on the fistfights. Wei can learn tons of new moves, each associated with a reputation tree"
hoursPlayed: and the third for your old martial arts master

reviewText:
An awesome storyline companied with fluid hand-to-hand combat in an entirely new culture, Chinese mixed with British markets in Hong Kong in an open world environment. Gunplay is standard cover-to-cover with hand-to-hand combat the primary means of combat.

Although the storyline is amazing, the combat is actually extremely easy. In reality, all you have to do is parry every time an enemy attacks you, and you will not take damage. You can even get a little aggresive by punching a few times, and instantly parry an attack while you are mid-swing. Driving combat is the same way because time slows when you are aiming at an enemy, and all you have to do is shoot the wheels of the enemy vehicle to instantly destroy it.

Some cons about the game include the driving camera and drifting. If you find yourself backing up in a vehicle you will find your camera moving in front of you so that you can see behind you. Although it may be useful in some games, the way United Front implemented the driving camera makes the camera jerk all over your screen. The camera will only move when you press W or S, so if you let go of the S key to drive backwards to let the camera settle, it will actually settle facing forward as if you were driving forwards.

Drifting is another problem area that United Front did not implement correctly. At times you will find yourself at high speeds, trying to drift around a corner or burnout 180 to turn around. For some reason, I find myself stopped sideways instead of continuing my drift. At that point, I have to let go of all controls and then drift or turn another 90 degrees to do a full 180. At high speeds, they just stop your drift half-way, almost like you're actually turning the opposite direction than you're pressing.

On the DLC front, both DLCs were simple and can be completed in under an hour. Both follow a very similar path, having to chase someone down, go to three locations before moving on, go to another location to uncover the leader's location, and then defeat the leader. The only difference is that Year of the Snake is mostly gun play while Nightmare in North Point is mostly hand-to-hand.

Regardless of the few cons of the game and the easy combat, the game was very fun to play and I really enjoyed seeing Hong Kong in video game form as that is where I was born. I would suggest this game to anyone who enjoys an open world environment such as Grand Theft Auto or Saints Row and who wants a quick single-player game.

reviewText:
A BRILLIANT GTA-like sandbox. Newly arrived in Hong Kong, Wei Shen starts to work his way up through the Triad, but here's the twist. Wei Shen is an undercover police officer tasked with infilitrating the Triad and could blow his cover at any time...

I was disappointed wtih GTA IV but until GTA V comes to the PC, this is probably the best organized crime sandbox game you could play

Pro's
-----
+ Classic open-world gameplay on the streets of Hong Kong. Besides the normal storyline missions there are  street races, go to a Kareoke bar, play Majong or bet on cockfighting
+ Solid, involving story with some very well known Asian and Asian-American actors providing key voices and facial likeness
+ Great action, from Kung Fu fights, to intense slow-mo gun-battles to high speed shootouts and death defying hijacks of moving vehicles worthy of a good action movie.
+ The rating is well deserved, things get dark, bloody and violent

Con's
------
- Most of the DLC is pretty meh. But if it's cheap, why not...

reviewText:
This game was brilliant. Much better than other titles that Square Enix has made that are not Final Fantasy such as Just Cause which has serious audio syncing problems.
Combat system closely related to that of Batman Arkham Asylum and Arkam City. graphics are quite impressive.

But besides the great fighting mechanics, the endless amount of things that you can do in Hong Kong, the customisation with clothes and the many many cars there are to purchase and show off. What is most impressive about this has to definitely be the storyline. Unlike typical games of this genre such as Grand Theft Auto and Saints Row, the main protagnanist of the game,  Wei Shen, is not just a character that comes off as just the average, out to get money and destroy stuff for the sake of it.

Wei Shen is the heart of the game. He is a well respected polie offica with the San Fransico police department that heads back to his home city, Hong Kong, to try and assist the local PD with taking down the Traids in the citty. It is immediatly obvious that your character has history with a fair amount of the people in the Traids, seeing as they use one of your oldest friends, Jackie to get Wei into the Triads to begin his undercover operation. Though as Shen gets pulled further in to the seedy underground workings of Hong Kong. It becomes more apparent that his motives of ether helping the police take down the Traids, or working with the Triads become extremely blurred.

In conclusion, as I have seen with other reviews of this game, we are all confused as to why people are not paying enough attention to this brilliant title. Yes there are a few bugs in the game, but what game doesn't. Even if you do not like the look of the game, I absolutely recommend this game just for it;s in depth and keep you on the edge of your seat" storyline."

reviewText:
I just finished the game, so all of this is kind of a recent pile of thoughts.

The story:
Wei Shen, an undercover cop has to get into the Sun On Yee, one of the triads in Hong Kong. Old friends, new friends, lovers, enemies, and bitterness is what follows his mission to the very end, which is one of the greates cliamxes in any games I've ever played so far. It's like a really awesome TV series coming to a satisfying end.
The base of the story is a dolig one, which we could see a hundred, maybe a thousand times. But man...they did a wonderful job for making it work better than anything else that follows the same path. You'll feel the friends in the game are truly your friends - and their betrayal will hurt you even more. You'll find yourself cheering when something turns out great, and feel anger you never thought you could ever feel. While you don't have much choices storylinewise, the one you get will be usually the best. You'll kill when you need, but feel guilty for it, when you did not. And what makes it all possible?
The characters. Wei Shen is a really great protagonist for a game like this. A cop, who has lots of friends from his childhood in the triads, but his supervisor gives him the orders. You'll feel the weight of the things he has to go through, and you'll even feel sorry for him some times. And thus, the payoff will be the better because all of this. Then you have people who knew Wei from his childhood. Jackie, who appears to be the comedic sidekick, but he is indeed much more. A loyal friend, a brother in arms who'll be by your side every time. Then there's Winston, the Red Pole (triad rank), who was first a bit skeptical about you, but he'll become a good friend too. You'll understand him, and you'll ultimately feel sorry for him. And that was just two of the many great and memorable characters from the game.
The writing is really good. It's logical, the interactions between the characters are genuine, you know that it was written by someone who can create good characters, and instead of making them do what needs to be done, he or she just creates them, puts them into Hong Kong, and watch what do they do. There are fillers in the discussions between the characters, but they feel anything but forced. They are chatting, enjoying themselves, nothing serious. Just what you'd do if you were roaming the city with your best friend riding shotgun.
Overall the story, characters, game concept, and writing gets a 10/10 - really enjoyable, and I'm sure even folks who are not into the moral dilemmas of being an undercover cop will find the game interesting.

Gameplay:
It follows the road GTA has set up (or at least as far as I know, but it could happen that it wasn't the first game like this), third person view, open world, sandbox feeling, etc. If you played any GTA games, from III to V, you are familiar with the concept. But instead of guns, the emphasis is more on the fistfights. Wei can learn tons of new moves, each associated with a reputation tree"

reviewText:
After 60 hours in this games world.. I can safely say that this game is definitely for me.

Sleeping Dogs is the story of Wei Shen a cop deep within Hong Kong's crime syndicate, so deep he doesn't know who's side he is on any more. All he knows is honour and respect are the most important things and he will keep to those values.

Sleeping Dogs is a fantastic open world sandbox game, its gameplay mechanics and mesmerizing world combined make an experience that is overall rewarding and entertaining from the beginning to when you are finished with it, Whether it be a 20 hour playthrough of only the story or if you're like me and enjoyed the game enough and had the time to collect and unlock everything in the game in a 60+ hour playthrough. No matter what you are going to enjoy Sleeping Dogs if you are a fan of the open world genre.

The game looks and sounds fantastic the best looking the game will get is at night with rain, its one of the most visually appealing sandbox games out there.

A lot of people will probably have problems with the amount of limitations the game has... you can't fly planes or helicopters the driving is almost arcade (which I kind of respect in a world where every open world game is trying to be realistic with its driving ) and there isn't a jump button.. but when you play Sleeping Dogs you will see how those problems don't even matter instead of jumping the game will give you moments while running to jump to another rooftop or vault over and parkour the environment. I didn't really feel like flying a plane or helicopter would benefit the game at all.

The combat is a nice remix of the Batman: Arkham Franchise's free flow combat and its a nice new take on that style of combat. You feel like you are in a Hong Kong action movie, with various environmental and up close takedown moves.
A small but decent range of melee weapons and firearms the combat in Sleeping Dogs is very well done. That being said you will be doing more punching and kicking then shooting.. but that's in the games favour as I feel the melee combat towers of the shooting mechanics which are still pretty fun.

The collectables in this game never really feel like chores because each one gets you closer and closer to unlocking more items or maxing out your health bar so even players who don't normally enjoy collecting will find themselves doing it anyway.. So I thought that was a pretty nice way to do the collecting side of things.

I'm not a fan of DLC I hate the idea of it but I can find my self enjoying DLC whenever I somehow find my self playing it.
Sleeping Dogs has three DLC missions and all three are great, one has Wei Shen return to being a beat cop and in full uniform to take down a cult that has made its way to Hong Kong and bomb certain areas. Another has Wei make his way to a fighting tournament on an island off the coast of Hong Kong.. and if you didn't think it could get anymore ridiculous there is a full on Halloween themed mission involving Wei rescuing his girlfriend from demon's and ghosts in the Northpoint of Kong Kong.

The game looks, plays and sounds fantastically. If you are a fan of the sandbox genre then you would be a fool to miss this gem.

reviewText: GTA: China, or so I Imagined Sleeping Dogs like that when i first heard about it but it's so much more than that. Of course it is like GTA in china in a way, but it doesn't fail in a storytelling like GTA 4 did. The game takes major influence from movies The Departed and Infernal Affairs where the line between friend and foe gets blurred and character loyalties and movies are questioned. The protagonist, Wei Shen is an undercover cop in Hong Kong who sworn uphold the law and bring criminals to justice but by virtue of being undercover which is also a gangster comiting very real acts of of crime. He has a personal vendetta against drug pushing triads for what they did to his sister and he sworn to take them down. It's a game about dealing with conflicting aspects of self. And what is interesting you don't have to chose between those aspects. It's a game about living with and reconsiling the fact that you have theese identities. The best straightforward example of this is you get 2 different EXP bars after each mission, the triad and cop. Triad exp fills with every kill you make, the more brutal the better, headshots, explosions fill up that bar while cop exp punish you for being clumsy or killing hostage etc. it implies that Wei is a good cop at the begining of the mission and going down morally doing his job. It's a game where protagonist doing the triad and cop things and he has to live up with consequences and it's show in game every time Wei goes to sleep.\nI think it's a good game and worth your attention 8/10.
