reviewText:
This game was brilliant. Much better than other titles that Square Enix has made that are not Final Fantasy such as Just Cause which has serious audio syncing problems.
Combat system closely related to that of Batman Arkham Asylum and Arkam City. graphics are quite impressive.

But besides the great fighting mechanics, the endless amount of things that you can do in Hong Kong, the customisation with clothes and the many many cars there are to purchase and show off. What is most impressive about this has to definitely be the storyline. Unlike typical games of this genre such as Grand Theft Auto and Saints Row, the main protagnanist of the game,  Wei Shen, is not just a character that comes off as just the average, out to get money and destroy stuff for the sake of it.

Wei Shen is the heart of the game. He is a well respected polie offica with the San Fransico police department that heads back to his home city, Hong Kong, to try and assist the local PD with taking down the Traids in the citty. It is immediatly obvious that your character has history with a fair amount of the people in the Traids, seeing as they use one of your oldest friends, Jackie to get Wei into the Triads to begin his undercover operation. Though as Shen gets pulled further in to the seedy underground workings of Hong Kong. It becomes more apparent that his motives of ether helping the police take down the Traids, or working with the Triads become extremely blurred.

In conclusion, as I have seen with other reviews of this game, we are all confused as to why people are not paying enough attention to this brilliant title. Yes there are a few bugs in the game, but what game doesn't. Even if you do not like the look of the game, I absolutely recommend this game just for it;s in depth and keep you on the edge of your seat" storyline."

reviewText: Sleeping Dogs questions your sense of duty and belonging throughout the game. For the first 5 hours I didn't get to handle a gun which is not what I expected. Instead I was Kung Fu Fighting. This game had a really nice mixed gameplay of fist to fist combat and gunplay. The graphics were quite horrible in console, but this game on PC highest settings with the high res pack makes this game look a lot more beautiful. In other hands the story was breathtaking, it immersed me from feeling Wei Shen's side of being a cop and a triad. The huge dilemma he faced with his duty or belonging. He had a family and a sense of home with his gang, but he also had a job to bring them down.\nOverall the story was amazing, the graphics were good but the edges of the models are evident but their textures are realistic and the gameplay is quite thrilling especially with the brutal melee kills.

reviewText: If you have ever wished you were a fast talking Chinese-American cop who is less undercover" and more "dangerously unhinged" United Front Games (and about a dozen other studios and publishers over the course of a decade) have finally enabled your fantasy. Walk the streets of Hong Kong and grievously injure innocent pedestrians with your kung-fu while they recite authentic Chinese dialog such as "You like pork-bun
date: yes?" and "...Please help!". Watch protagonist Wei Shen rail against the Triads to his police superiors and then run over 40 fellow officers on the way to his date with real American actress Emma Stone. It is not all fun and games though; your buddies in uniform(who don't have the everyday stress of having to randomly murder civilians for no reason) will kind of try and put a stop to your rampages. But no matter how many of them you kill no one turns you into Human Resources for creating a hostile work enviroment.\n\nSeriously though it is a great game."

reviewText:
Okay so this game is on sale at £4!!

Pros.

-Open World is really good, lots of variety to the missions

Winston's wedding is just tragic!!!

Cons.

For £4 on sale you can thank me later, though it is clearly like GTA I actually enjoyed this a lot more!

I'd pay at least a tenner for a game this good and as long as it is!

reviewText:
In Sleeping Dogs you're playing as Wei Shen, an undercover police whose job is to infiltrate the rank of triads and at the same time operate as informant to police in Hong Kong. Through the game you will find a lot of missions and side missions to hone your skill as martial artist and gunslinger. Some people said sleeping dogs are just imitation to GTA and True Crime. Well, i disagree with them. In my opinion sleeping dogs have something that surpasses them.
A lot of features in sleeping dogs compelled me to said so.. for example :

Combat Aspect
GTA and True Crime doesn't have martial arts to confront their enemies, in Sleeping Dogs you have martial arts as your friend. As Wei Shen, you can learn to do complex moves at dojo. Learn to fight against various enemies, countering attacks from them. You even have a environment to support you while in combat! You can impale enemies to meat hook, dump them in trash bin, smash them to aquarium, and many more.

Car Hijack
Wei Shen have ability to hijack car while driving a car without a need to stop first. In a world where you need to be fast to chase down enemies on the road, this would come handy. GTA should adopt this mechanism for their future release.

Parkour
In sleeping dogs, chasing criminals is one of the most interesting features of the game. Hongkong are well known as crowded city with a lot of market and cramped building, with parkour you will be able to jump over obstacles and climb over the wall easily while chasing targets.

Basically these features are only a few of many best thing in the game. If you like playing GTA or True Crime, this game will easily hook you up with a lot of charming and fresh features. But if you're in for stories you might be a bit disappointed, as the game only tell a common feud between triads and police, nothing new.
That leave you one final question, Are you in for the gameplay or are you in for the stories ? This review might help you answer that.

reviewText: This one is in a similar category to Spec Ops for me. It's a game with AAA production values but a lower level of marketing and sales, which is unfortunate. To me this is pretty clearly a better open world game than GTA4, though the sandbox seems smaller and therefore the game shorter. It's been quite a while since I've played GTA4, so that may not be correct. With that exception, Sleeping Dogs does everything better than GTA4. The graphics are better, the driving is better, the combat is better (though my personal preference would be to have more gunfights and less fist fights), the hidden objects are handled better, etc. I enjoyed the story as well, though it was somewhat predictable. However, had it not been, it wouldn't have been as satisfying as there weren't a lot of ways the loose ends could have been wrapped up. Hopefully Rockstar borrows" some of the gameplay elements for GTAV

reviewText:
A buddy of mine recommended the game, and I managed to catch it for five bucks on Steam sale. He really liked this game, and I was curious to find out why.

This game is really good and I thouroughly enjoyed my time playing it. The open world is great, and the atmosphere that the game provides, even from the first mission, is fantastic. Hong Kong is a great place to have a game like this. The combat may be ripped straight our of Batman: Arkham Asylum, but that doesn't mean it's bad. You can get upgrades by collecting various statues around the city, and they only serve to make the already-brutal comabt way more brutal.

The story is great, and there are plenty of side missions to run around to do. There are also a ton of collectibles (such as the health shrines, or lockboxes), races, and various other things you can do to waste time in Hong Kong.

I do have two complaints, however. This game was apparently a long time in the making, so there are some noticeable things that feel incomplete or missing. The dating sim in the game is weird: Wei takes a girl out, they have a sexual encounter, and her number disappears from your phone. At one point, one of the side missions involves you finding out your then girlfriend (whom I didn't even KNOW she was my girlfriend!) is cheating on you. Totally weird.

There's also a weird karaoke simulator in the game that they make you play twice. I didn't really enjoy that (though I did get the Karaoke Superstar achievement because ♥♥♥♥ you), but it is funny to hear Wei sing Girls Wanna Have Fun".

Overall
date: I got the game for a steal of five bucks. If you're here looking at reviews during the Steam sale
hoursPlayed: highly recommend this title for the money. If not
voteText: I'd still probably pay twenty bucks for it (that's the price at the time of writing). I sunk a good twenty-six hours in
helpfulPercent: and I do not regret any of it. A great game."
votesHelpful: April 23, 2014

reviewText:
This is one good open world game.

It's set in a beautifully designed city,with lots of interesting places.It is worth it for just exploring this city.

The game is centered around melee fighting and not so much around guns.The fighting system is similiar to Assassin's Creed games but far superior in my opinion.The guns are boring and during the sections of the game that you must use guns,I felt bored and I wished It would end just so I could kick someone with my bare fists.

The main story is good and you will surely focus on it because it is interesting and has some nice twists.But the world does not lack side quests and other activities which can keep you occupied during or after finishing the story.

Driving feels weird at first but you just need to get used to it.

This is a solid game that should be on everyone's list.

reviewText:
Num momento onde os jogos sandbox já são carne de vaca e senso comum, Sleeping Dogs tenta injentar mecânicas novas no gênero e se tornar um dos melhores jogos do gênero. Será que consegue?

No jogo, Wei Shen, policial infiltrado, trabalha para as tríades de Hong Kong. A dualidade tríade e polícia que o personagem vive é tratada muito pouco na trama.

Há mecânicas de aprimoramento da habilidade do personagem relacionado a isso; upgrades que vão sendo desbloqueados na medida que vai jogando. Dois medidores, nas quest principais, que possiblitam essa evolução das habilidades.

O medidor de pontos de tríade e outro de policial. Se você é sanguinário, violento e até ás vezes criativo com a forma de lidar com os inimigos você recebe pontos nesse medidor. Por outro lado,  caso você seja imprudente, destruidor, assassino de inocentes, ladrão e até atrapalhado você perde pontos de policial. Essa dualidade é interessantíssima. Pena que é só aplicada nas missões principais. Deveria ser aplicada em todas as missões.

A questão da dualidade de ser policial e gangster, ao mesmo tempo,  nem é desenvolvida plenamente na trama. O jogo seria muito mais interessante caso a história principal fosse guiada por suas escolhas, para que lado o jogador fosse. E um final da mesma forma. Infelizmente a trama não é das melhores. Ainda bem que o jogo tem outros elementos positivos.

Os colecionáveis do jogo são todos relacionados ao jogo e não são gratuitos. Pegá-los pode ajudar mais tarde. E eles ficam visíveis conforme você vai progredindo no jogo. Dessa forma toda aquele parte de ficar vagando a esmo perdido e sem saber o que fazer não acontece quase nunca. A sinalizaçao do jogo é outro ponto forte, dificilmente você vai errar o caminho.

Outro ponto positivo são as batalhas. O jogo é todo baseado em lutas. Seja com armas de fogo ou sem, a ação é bem feita e bem executada, resultando numa mecânica de batalha simplificada e intuitiva. O único porém fica pela câmera que atrapalha ás vezes.

Sleeping Dogs não é o sandbox do ano. Não é o melhor sandbox de todos os tempos. Talvez nem seja o melhor jogo do mês do seu lançamento. Mas há um caminho de evolução que o jogo pode criar. Lembre-se, ninguém admira GTA I, mas sim o GTA III. Será que veremos acontecer com Sleeping Dogs?

reviewText:
This game is honestly very underated by a lot of people. It was one of a select few games compelling enough I did a second play through almost immediatly after beating it for the first time. The other reason I did a second playthrough was because I wanted to finish off the achievments for the game and it was a more fun way to do it compared to running around farming stats rewards.

That however is against the point this game has a host of extremely talented voice actors who make the characters that much more believable and relateable. These voice actors also further the story and push you to spend the time and help them out.

The DLC for this game though mostly cosmetic has a few gems that give you more missions to complete around the map and a few kinda stand alone storylines.

At the end of the day this is a game I tell all my friends they should buy because it is quite simply amazing.

Definetelly the best open-world game in my opinion !
The idea of Sleeping Dogs is very excited and well executed.
You are playing as an undercover cop and your mission is to infiltrate Triad and make some friends among their leaders.
In the same time you can not forget that you're a cop and you have to arrange secret meetings with your police fellows ,
make some phonecalls or send text message when you need to.

The graphics is amazing ,and so is the game phisique ,especially seen during a street fights which occur very often.
I have never seen well executed fight scenes as here in Sleeping Dogs .It's not about blind clicking your mouse .
(of course you need to use it ) .
To become a supreme street brawler you will need need to use counter strikes ,blocks ,throws ,and a lot of combinations
to tackle your opponent down ,brake his legs or arm ,or crack hes jaw:) eventually throwing him in to a phone booth :)

But it is not all about street fights...you will need to track and eliminate other gangs that are a treating Triad
you're in .
Pursue competition by car,motorbike ,bus ,or just by using your legs ,go to kung fu school to improve your fighting skills ,
eliminating in the same time Triad members silently and without any suspicions.
I forgot to mention that while playing Sleeping Dogs you're gaining experience which is converted to skill points.
Basicly what you got here is: 2 skill trees :one for doing work for Triad ,and another skill tree for co operarting with cops.
Amazing isn't it???:)

You can use almost anything to steal the car ,or boat ,hack the CCTV cameras ,harrass Triad competition and even do
petty jobs such as destroying sports car or collecting money from shops for so called protection"

reviewText:
I find this game extremely overrated (but I would still buy it again on discount thought, it was good enough). The story feels weak, mediocre at most. It had nice moments, but mostly was really straightforward, without any plot twists whatsoever. The side missions were insanely repetitive and the races were just easy. Fights are button mashings mostly (yes, it's a brawler in open world with missions rather than sneaking or going full loud with bazookas), only collecting jade statues (12 in total, but around half of them obtainable during main missions) can upgrade your moves. You had a weapon during mission? Too bad, it won't be any more after you finish it. You have a knife to butcher through your enemies? Too bad, it will last only a couple if hits. I wonder if it was made of wood or glass it would last longer... When you get accustomed to the notion of brawling with LMB-LMB-hold LMB-LMB and catching enemy from time to time there are guns introduced, but only for a couple of missions (remember above where I said about weapon lasting only until the end of the mission?) and it feels like a really forced addon. Most of the times you would crouch behind something and then vault in from of it, the game would put a huge slo-mo and you'd headshot everyone in the room. Booooring.
What's great is the port of the game itself. The game looks beautifully, uses DX10/11, has a free HD textures pack (additional 4GB to download), the steering/controlling is responsible and I haven't find any problems with camera as well.
Like I said, I would still buy it again, I just wanted to point out the most of the things that were downgrading my experience while playing the game. Of course, there would be achievement-♥♥♥♥♥s, who would play the game until 100% (which includes lots of golden in-game awards), but I play only for the story, and everything else which isn't good enough for me is just distracting me.

GTA4 is still the best :S

reviewText:
I bought this game at the last summer steam sale and I must say, I'm kicking myself for waiting this long to play it.  This game is basically everything grand theft auto wished it could be.  The gameplay, story, graphics are all top notch.

Speaking on the gameplay, I was expecting a GTAish game with an interesting plot twist(where you are actually in fact an undercover cop),  What I wasn't expecting was the very well thought out and executed melee combat system instead of the usual bland cover based shooting mechanics you see in these games(there are still times in the game where you use a gun, but very few and far between)  It makes the game feel like a Chinese action flick.  Controls are tight, side quests and missions constantly mix up gameplay from racing, to hacking, free running chases of dead beats who owe your gang money and so much more.

Graphics are very good indeed(make sure you download the high resolution texture pack), from the textures to the brilliant lighting and shadowing effects.  The only thing that breaks the immersion is the less than steller character animations. (it amazes me how many games STILL haven't caught up to Half-life 2 in that regard.)

As far as story goes, I don't want to spoil anything but expect a very gritty, well written, and emotionally scarring thrill ride.

TLDR, Great GTA style sandbox with excellent melee combat, amazing graphics(download the high texture pack off the steam store) and a story that will absorb you and possibly scar you for life.

reviewText:
The main character aint no Jeeba Jop, but Wei Shen is a badass for sure, and this game has a ton of throw backs to old school(and new school) martial artist movies.  You'll get clothing that Jackie Chan wore in Rumble in the Bronx, Tony Jaa donned from Ong-Bak, and of course numerous Bruce Lee outfits. That alone, is pretty awesome in my book.

The melee combat is reminiscent of Batman Arkham Asylum/City, the open world gameplay is your tried and true GTA formula, and it takes place in a beautifully rendered Hong Kong. What's not to like there? It's well optimized, and it definitely isn't a console port with the numerous different options you can fool with both in-game and out via text editing.

Can't wait for the prequel Jumping Frogs.

reviewText:
Rating: 10/10
Story review: Realistic, breath-taking view of Hong Kong mirrored into the game creates an excellent open-world experience that is yet to be chalenged by the likes of GTA.
The choreographed fighting, acting, driving and cut scenes are above average, showcasing what is possible when developers take game mechanics seriously and invest in it.
The game has a short learning path, even for new comers. You'll get thrown right into action from the first scene, and the nostalgic storyline will keep begging you for a repeat of the story once you're done.

Visuals and system requirements: The visuals are stellar, and you will not need to break a bank to build a rig that can play this game. Simply put, if you can play Tomb Raider on Medium settings with DirectX11 features turned on, you'll blaze through this game without breaking a sweat.

Stereoscopic 3D via AMD HD3D works out of the box if you have an AMD HD 5000+ GPU connected to a 3D capable monitor via HDMI 1.4a. Depending on your setup, you may need a 3D driver such as Tridef 3D to play it in 3D mode.

Personally, I had a blast playing the game and would recommend it highly.

reviewText:
To start of, the keyboard/mouse controls were really poorly done and it takes a lot away from a game that could have come close to the old GTA games. The fact that you can't double map and you can't map certain keys at all like the arrow keys which I use in every other game inc. GTA for main driving is ridiculous.
Mouse camera movement could also use some refining.

Once you get used to the controls the game is not bad and definitely would recomend it when it's on a good offer, it also has some nice features like slow mo when shooting from a car, so you can focus on aiming and not worry about driving as much.
So despite the issues not a bad game for the discount price I got it for.

Oh yeah, and forget about gun play, the whole weapons system is completely crap, and does not even come close to GTA; but for those who prefer hand combat and remembering endless number of key combo combinations, this is the game for you.


*Recommend, but not at full retail price, wait for a good offer.

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs is a realistic look at the undercover life in the Hong Kong Triads (organized crime) played as a third person open world game. I guess you can compare it to the Grand Theft Auto games or Saints Row games in terms of actual gameplay.

In Sleeping Dogs you’ll find yourself driving in cars for large portions of the game since the game world is actually very large. There’s a fast travel option that I didn’t even know existed until I replayed the game a couple of months ago. The combat in the game is very similar to the Batman Arkham games (strike & counter), but with no gadgets. There are also sections where you’ll use guns, but it’s about 90% hand to hand fighting.

Where the game really shines is in story. You’re an undercover cop trying to worm your way into the Triad and slowly get pulled in more and more into the life. It’s how I imagine real undercover cops experience their jobs.

Overall I give the game a thumbs up. It seems like every game I review gets a thumbs up, but that’s because if I don’t like a game, I stop playing. Steam offers a free HD textures DLC so everything looks good with the graphics turned way up.

reviewText: I think Sleeping Dogs is a really fun game.  The story is fast-paced, intense, and intriguing.  The graphics are wonderful, the atmosphere wonderful with some humor thrown in.  The music that plays when you're driving around, for the most part, is great.  Beyond stealing cars and completing missions, the combat elements are excellently done--that goes for firearms and ESPECIALLY for melee combat.  Great DLC as well.  Different outfits aren't just for vanity, but add either a challenging element (like added heat from the police) or additional combat options based off of real martial arts schools.... from drunken master, to wing chun, tai chi chuan, mui tai, mma, etc....  There are some classy and fun automobiles and the races range from easy to very challenging difficulty.  The side activities can be as fun as the main story.  You can learn how to swear in Chinese as well.\n\nThe only thing that could make this game better is actual nudity for all the hot chix you can date--and even Wei Chen... he's got a hot bod too.  Anyone make those mods yet?  If so, hit me up!  Ha.....

reviewText:
Num momento onde os jogos sandbox já são carne de vaca e senso comum, Sleeping Dogs tenta injentar mecânicas novas no gênero e se tornar um dos melhores jogos do gênero. Será que consegue?

No jogo, Wei Shen, policial infiltrado, trabalha para as tríades de Hong Kong. A dualidade tríade e polícia que o personagem vive é tratada muito pouco na trama.

Há mecânicas de aprimoramento da habilidade do personagem relacionado a isso; upgrades que vão sendo desbloqueados na medida que vai jogando. Dois medidores, nas quest principais, que possiblitam essa evolução das habilidades.

O medidor de pontos de tríade e outro de policial. Se você é sanguinário, violento e até ás vezes criativo com a forma de lidar com os inimigos você recebe pontos nesse medidor. Por outro lado,  caso você seja imprudente, destruidor, assassino de inocentes, ladrão e até atrapalhado você perde pontos de policial. Essa dualidade é interessantíssima. Pena que é só aplicada nas missões principais. Deveria ser aplicada em todas as missões.

A questão da dualidade de ser policial e gangster, ao mesmo tempo,  nem é desenvolvida plenamente na trama. O jogo seria muito mais interessante caso a história principal fosse guiada por suas escolhas, para que lado o jogador fosse. E um final da mesma forma. Infelizmente a trama não é das melhores. Ainda bem que o jogo tem outros elementos positivos.

Os colecionáveis do jogo são todos relacionados ao jogo e não são gratuitos. Pegá-los pode ajudar mais tarde. E eles ficam visíveis conforme você vai progredindo no jogo. Dessa forma toda aquele parte de ficar vagando a esmo perdido e sem saber o que fazer não acontece quase nunca. A sinalizaçao do jogo é outro ponto forte, dificilmente você vai errar o caminho.

Outro ponto positivo são as batalhas. O jogo é todo baseado em lutas. Seja com armas de fogo ou sem, a ação é bem feita e bem executada, resultando numa mecânica de batalha simplificada e intuitiva. O único porém fica pela câmera que atrapalha ás vezes.

Sleeping Dogs não é o sandbox do ano. Não é o melhor sandbox de todos os tempos. Talvez nem seja o melhor jogo do mês do seu lançamento. Mas há um caminho de evolução que o jogo pode criar. Lembre-se, ninguém admira GTA I, mas sim o GTA III. Será que veremos acontecer com Sleeping Dogs?

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs - another GTA like game. At first glance, everything is as usual: shooting, chase, mission, gangsters, police patrol, sex, drugs and rock and roll =).
But after 2 hours of the game, we find ourselves in the real Hong Kong with his daily events and people. City shows quite clearly. Victoria Peak - the beauty of which burn out like a snake. Beauty.
Beauty yacht in the Night.
Beautiful yachts, nightclubs, classical Chinese markets. All this is done really well and is exactly what if you find yourself in Hong Kong at present.
Honestly - I like many was not in China, except in Japan. I'm a fighter - karate.
And as a fighter, I can say that the fight scenes, strikes, movements are done very thoroughly. Thanks to the developers for the respect for the martial arts. Thank you also for respect for religion! Ceremonial urn, Buddha Temple, the monks - all in the game. And the plot of the game dramatically and exciting! Good cop bad.
Unfortunately events in the game are very real. War and bloodshed triad goes every day. Control of the territory, drugs, weapons. This game shows us both sides of the coin."
10 out of 10. Best game of martial arts."
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
To start of, the keyboard/mouse controls were really poorly done and it takes a lot away from a game that could have come close to the old GTA games. The fact that you can't double map and you can't map certain keys at all like the arrow keys which I use in every other game inc. GTA for main driving is ridiculous.
Mouse camera movement could also use some refining.

Once you get used to the controls the game is not bad and definitely would recomend it when it's on a good offer, it also has some nice features like slow mo when shooting from a car, so you can focus on aiming and not worry about driving as much.
So despite the issues not a bad game for the discount price I got it for.

Oh yeah, and forget about gun play, the whole weapons system is completely crap, and does not even come close to GTA; but for those who prefer hand combat and remembering endless number of key combo combinations, this is the game for you.


*Recommend, but not at full retail price, wait for a good offer.

reviewText: I think Sleeping Dogs is a really fun game.  The story is fast-paced, intense, and intriguing.  The graphics are wonderful, the atmosphere wonderful with some humor thrown in.  The music that plays when you're driving around, for the most part, is great.  Beyond stealing cars and completing missions, the combat elements are excellently done--that goes for firearms and ESPECIALLY for melee combat.  Great DLC as well.  Different outfits aren't just for vanity, but add either a challenging element (like added heat from the police) or additional combat options based off of real martial arts schools.... from drunken master, to wing chun, tai chi chuan, mui tai, mma, etc....  There are some classy and fun automobiles and the races range from easy to very challenging difficulty.  The side activities can be as fun as the main story.  You can learn how to swear in Chinese as well.\n\nThe only thing that could make this game better is actual nudity for all the hot chix you can date--and even Wei Chen... he's got a hot bod too.  Anyone make those mods yet?  If so, hit me up!  Ha.....

reviewText:
I felt compelled to write a review for Sleeping Dogs, as it is a game that gave me more bang for my buck than most ever have.  I'm a huge fan of open-world games with driving (GTA, Saints Row, Far Cry).  With that said, I 100%'d Sleeping Dogs at about 30 hours in, and my current playtime is now nearing the 118 mark.  I can count the number of games I've 100%'d on less than two hands.  So, I think the important question is, why do I still keep playing?  What caused me to learn this game inside and out, to the point where I know all the mechanics, glitches, and how to mess with every piece of AI?

The answer lies in that to me, Sleeping Dogs is just pure fun.  The melee combat is something that almost no other game has done as well, and really the only one that comes to mind is the Arkham series.  Even with Arkham, I find the combat takes too long, whereas in Sleeping Dogs it gets things just right.  It's visceral while remaining simple.  Enemies react in momentary fear to bone-crushing martial arts moves, and the protagonist Wei Shen can masterfully counter and take out hordes of gangsters.  Wei also moves around Hong Kong with basic parkour moves, as he can survive falls of impressive heights and slide over all manner of objects smoothly, if timed right.

The other aspect is driving.  Let me preface this section with two things: one, that I vastly prefer arcade style driving (if I want real driving, I'll go take my real car out), and two, the weapon-based DLC car singlehandedly has given me hours upon hours of extra time with the game.  I'll put this bluntly; if you want realistic driving, go play another game.  Ramming cars at high speeds, tearing through the Financial District with a nearly indestructible bus, and blowing out the tires that sends cars flying like a Hollywood movie... all of its is insanely fun.  Add in the DLC car that pretty much breaks the game, and it just gets hilarious how awesomely you can dominate Hong Kong.

Sleeping Dogs is far from perfect, however.  Some of the things the game does are laughably bad, like how the police are handled.  I'm not going to mince words here, the police are just terrible.  They're so bad that they're funny, like with how awful horror movies work.  The biggest issue I have is that they literally pop into an area.  You could be in a desolate alley and shoot someone, or beat up a bunch of people in a quiet street with no police anywhere nearby.. and they will literally pop in like they used a portal gun or stepped through a dimensional rift.  If they weren't so easy to shake off and mess with, this would have ruined any sense of immersion the game had.

While I thoroughly enjoyed the story with a satisfying ending, which took me about 15-20 hours with exploration and side missions, you could tell that in some sections, the developers did not have the time to implement other features they wanted.  It's pretty obvious that they wanted to include deeper connections to Hong Kong with Wei with how much exploration and collection there were, along with Wei's serial hit-it-and-quit-it attitude with women.  Wei's struggle with his identity and corruption, both in the Triads and the police force, was a compelling reason for me to finish the story, however.

Finally, don't let the DLC scare you.  The DLC mostly adds things in to make the game a little more fun, and none of it is necessary whatsoever.  I know some people who wouldn't sneeze at Sleeping Dogs for the amount of DLC it has, but I doubt they ever actually took a look at what it does.

I really believe that Sleeping Dogs is a game that every fan of this genre should play.  Hong Kong's a relatively fresh setting from similar games, and Sleeping Dogs finds its identity in mechanics that are just fun.  Not crazy whacked up purple ♥♥♥♥♥ bat fun like Saints Row, and not maniacal, realistic Trevor fun as in GTA, but just super tight, simple, attractive combat with good pacing and a pretty beautiful world.

reviewText:
Has the seedy Hong Kong underworld ever called to you? Probably not, but still if you want to imagine being a Triad whilst working for the law then this is the game for you

This is a pretty awesome open world GTA style game. It is beautiful to look at and just great fun to walk around and explore. The missions are diverse and plentiful. The story is compelling and very well written. I really felt connected to the characters and invested in what happened to them. And the entire immense story was topped off by a pretty awesome finale.

Pretty much every aspect of the gameplay is solid. The driving and combat are robust and feel great. Some of my favourite memories of this game were just driving around the city at full tilt with the cops chasing me shooting out tires and running people off the road. There are a lot of vehicles and each one drives very differently.

The combat is great, so much variety and with many ways to beat the hell out of people you won’t get bored. Plus with the ability to learn more skills you will find the fighting even better the further you go. The game also feature contextual take downs, want to slam some guys face into a fan or a window? You can do that and it feels immensely satisfying

There are also tons of side missions to do such as street racing, gambling and a fight club that you will be busy for hours before even delving into the story itself. Plus with all the available DLC and now the definitive edition you will be able to delve even deeper into what Hong Kong has to offer

This version is no longer available but if I would recommend the definitive edition as it contains even more stuff. If you play this game you will have a great time, it is far superior to its spiritual predecessors and a great intro to a new series.

Have fun ^_^

reviewText:
I've never played GTA. But the thought of a GTA-like game set in Asia was awesome, not enough games like this are set here.

The game world is fairly vibrant, and the art style is interesting. The gameplay is fun too, except I hated all the shooting sequences - I had to switch to the keyboard and mouse for them.

There's also a slight issue I run into if my joystick is connected as well; Sleeping Dogs for some reason ends up switching partially to the joystick and ignores the 360 controller and partly ignores the kb/mouse. I asked Square Enix support, they said it wont be fixed.

Story wise it's okay, the only slight issue I had was the number of women Wei gets to sleep with for no obvious reason at all. Reminded me a bit of The Witcher's card game.

Anyway, I had quite a bit of fun in the game.

reviewText:
I finally finished Sleeping Dogs yesterday and I have to say I really like the game. Nice story mode (watch Hong-Kong movie Infernal Affairs for more in-depth look on Triad) which was pretty intense, interesting side missions (still didn't finish them all), amazing graphics (especially on rainy nights), excellent sound and soundtrack. United Front Games and Square Enix didn't dissapoint.

Combat system is interesting and takes some time to used to, but when you master all kung-fu moves you'll be unstoppable (gather Jade statues as soon as you can cause it will greatly boost your performance in combat). Well, throughout the game, no matter how good you are, patience will be your biggest friend when fighting a group of mobs. :)

Don't forget to download High Resolution Texture Pack (free DLC) which will really bring the game to higher level.
Also, if you're lazy, you can purchase Top Dog Silver Pack (1,49€) and Top Dog Gold Pack (2,49€) for a quick XP boost, which will instantly give you many skillpoints to enhance your abilities and access to many wardrobe options.

Do I recommend this game? Yes, I do. It's a fun open world third person action game in the asian setting which does have some weaknesses (missions are sometimes repetative; chase enemy - kill enemy) but, all in all, it a fun game and I don't think you'll regret it.

It should be available on Steam sales for a nice price (I got it for cca 6€ a few months ago) so keep it on radar.

reviewText: I was very pleasantly surprised with Sleeping Dogs.  From the screenshots and videos I had previously seen, I expected the game to be a lot like Grand Theft Auto (Which I never really have cared for).  However, The storyline was surprisingly well built.  the game follows Wei Shen as an undercover cop infiltrating the Triads.  It deals with his conflict of wanting to stay in the gang with his new position of power and his close friend vs. his mission as a cop.  The story is intense and emotional and not at all what I expected.

reviewText:
Warning: This is NOT a GTA clone, proceed with caution

Pros
-Deep and emotional story
-Relatable Characters
-You can choose to go from Cop Missions then to Triad Missions or just roam the streets
-The Graphics
-Doesn't encourage too much gunning around
-Imaginative Executions (Meat hook, Toilet, Aquarium)
-Open World
-Parkour
-Emma Stone is in it
-Really good atmosphere
-World brought to life through Cantonese dialogue, chinese themes and traditional content
-Combat
-Voice acting is pretty good
-Its set in Hong Kong
-The amount of costumes for Wei Shen

Cons
-Graphics look ugly at some parts
-Girlfriend parts, seemed unnecessary
-Camera can be annoying at times

Overall, this game is good. Deep atmosphere, intriguing story, fun gameplay, what's not to like about it? I have to mention the driving since its been awhile since i've played this game, I honestly can't remember if it had clunky controls or smooth controls. All I can say is that the other parts of the game is amazing alone so its worth picking this game up either on full price or on sale (like a cheapie like me).

Final Verdict: 9/10
Score: Go get it!

reviewText: Sleeping Dogs experienced anything but a sleepy development cycle. Originally set to be a title in the True Crime franchise, the project was cancelled by publisher Activision when almost being ready, much to the disappointment of developers United Front Games. However, in stepped Square Enix and with their assistance and a small re-branding, the game was back on track. Despite these dramatic events, players will be happy to know that Sleeping Dogs is a fun and diverse open world experience with tons to do, an engaging and serious story, and a memorable and authentic setting. Small gameplay issues and potential lack of variety aside, this is an enjoyable and respectably lengthy outing that can hold its ground against the leaders of the genre.\n\nRead the full review[www.newgamenetwork.com]

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs was a game I bought in Steam's 2013 Autumn Sales, after being curious about this game for a long time and being aware that looking up YouTube footage might have spoiled the story for me, this sale was a good opportunity for me to just gamble on this one.

And it was jackpot for me. Having played Just Cause 2, GTA 1 to 4, Saints Row 3, L.A. Noire and countless other free roaming games, I was completely overwhelmed by how convincing Hong Kong was portrayed in Sleeping Dogs. Hong Kong, which in this review refers to the map in Sleeping Dogs, is a graphically pleasing platform that carries the player through a gritty storyline revolving around Chinese gangsters. Even though the city is small compared to most of the aforementioned free roaming city games, there is a healthy amount of detail put in every square foot of Hong Kong, making the city feel as big as it would have felt in real life. The city dynamics are downright convincing, you will encounter a large amount of variation among the residents, each with their own reason for being on the street. This, and the amounts of interaction provided for the player, is something that at the time of writing is not appreciated enough in the industry.

Sleeping Dogs features oriental themed music to reinforce that atmosphere. The genre of the background music as well as the radio stations vary from hip-hop to classic, all with Chinese roots. Luckily, a great majority of the used vocabulary is English, although you may encounter a Chinese swearword here and there. This is translated in the subtitles and may seem a bit forced, if not out of place. Personally I find it understandable considering a full English or Chinese transcript would've alienated the player from the casting in this context, or otherwise not being able to follow the story at all.

It's important that this appeals to the player as the emphasis of the game heavily lies on the implied Chinese gangster culture. This means that gunplay and car-craze is reduced to a minimum when compared to other games in this genre. Rather than mowing down your enemies it's more common to have to fight people barehanded, the use of several martial arts and enemies with different specialities makes this less linear than it may sound. I wouldn't go as far as calling this game less violent either, if anything, this game deserves its 18+ rating more than the others in its genre.

Having that said, the mechanics of the game definitely require getting used to, luckily this is achieved through a clever tutorial that gradually increases the freedom you have while playing.

To progress through the game there are countless of missions and events to participate in, and not all of these are fun to do. In fact, there's some dreadful shooter-on-rails included. Luckily this wasn't so common that it started to bother me more than I could take but these are things that make Sleeping Dogs far from perfect. It's a missed opportunity to go down in history as a classic, though looking back on what Sleeping Dogs did manage to achieve, it would be greedy to ask for much more. I already feel like a cheapskate having paid so little for what I got.

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs is probably going to be my favourite game this year. It’s hard to imagine why Activision wanted to scrap this game as it really excels well as a sandbox game and has refined how we see the genre altogether.

The story is amazing and can hold its own compared to Mafia 2 / GTA4. The combat is great, as well as movement; it’s very responsive compared to GTA4. Car’s are slightly arcade-ish to handle - but considering you can hijack cars and do slow motion shoot-outs it works out pretty well.

Overall Sleeping Dogs is a love letter to Hong Kong cinema; I’ve been mesmerized by its tiny immaculate detail which gives this game so much charisma and charm. Truly one the great gems of this generation.

On a last note, the PC version is just amazing, advance PC options and day 1 HD textures really show that United Front is committed to the PC. Listening to Ninja Tune radio while driving a motorbike down a wet and rainy neon lit sky is just pure bliss.

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs adds its name to the ever growing list of genuinely good open-world action adventure games. The melee combat focus threw me off at first, but after switching to a gaming controller, the gameplay felt significantly more intuitive over a mouse & keyboard. The intertwined story of undercover cop and bad ♥♥♥ Triad Sun On Yee Red Pole is impressively put together. Sleeping Dogs comes off every bit as an AAA title with superb graphics, voice acting, and gameplay. Plus the amazing assortment of radio stations and musical flavors is extraordinary.

Even though most of the side missions felt underwhelming, repetitive, and in many cases downright boring, I found myself continuously getting distracted trying to complete them, or stopping to seek out that next health upgrade or lockbox. I realize now it was the reward element that made them so addicting--always granting some new unlock or item reward. The taxi service is a nice feature if you want to get somewhere fast, although the car handling feels very similar to GTA San Andreas which makes driving good fun. Also the DLC adds a good variety of worthwhile content as well.

Two thumbs up.

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs is a third-person open-world game set in Hong Kong where you play as Wei Shen, an undercover cop tasked with infiltrating the Triads from his hometown from the inside. You start as a street-level enforcer and work your way into the confidences of the upper reaches of the Triads, while doing other undercover police work along the way, along with the normal extraneous missions which the game provides.

What Sleeping Dogs does, it does VERY well. It's got one of the best core stories of any open-world game that I've ever played. Its combat is top-notch (although I found it initially a little difficult to get into), at least for the hand-to-hand portion - shooting is more middle of the road. Unfortunately, the extras outside of the main storyline and the main cop assignments felt more like additions after the fact to make it an open-world game when it otherwise wouldn't really have needed to be. Car controls never felt quite /right/, but was good enough to be workable - it's only annoying in races.

All in all, the game is excellent. When the story really got going, I couldn't put it down, and it was HIGHLY satisfying. There were even one or two moments where I expected the plotline to be mildly hypocritical in favor of the protagonist and it ended up flipping my expectations on their head, which is ALWAYS appreciated.

Highly recommended.

reviewText: This game makes no attempt to hide its influences...  The open-world criminality of GTA.  Batman's 1-vs-many melee combat.  Mirror's Edge style free-running.  Acrobatic hijackings straight out of Just Cause 2.  Cover shooting, a la Gears of War.  Innumerable cop movies and Bruce Lee movies get huge nods.  And it works.\n\nEvery idea Sleeping Dogs borrows is done less well than in the game or film that inspired it, but its success lies in the blend.  The fistfights are much better than in GTA, you go on kill-crazy rampages undreamed of in Batman, and one of the side missions is basically Enter The Dragon"
date: complete with cheesy '70s film grain effects.  What more could you want?"
hoursPlayed: true

reviewText:
I spent actual money to buy DLC for this game, that is how much I love it.

The story takes place in Hong Kong and it's your undercover cop who infiltrates a triad well known to him, and the love for his friends and his duty will be in conflict throughout the game. What elevates this story from the rest is the excellent voice acting and compelling characters that are both believeable and relateable.

The game is an open-world third-person action shooter. The combat is an improved version of the Batman: Arkham games formula, with the introduction of combos, melee weapons (like cleavers, batons and even fish!!), environmental executions and guns that, at first, feel kind of awkward, but I got used to them.
There is a lot of side activities in the world to complete: doing favors to increase fame, take part in illegal races, wipe out hidden triad gangs and sing karaoke.

The graphics are impressive, and the game really shines at night time. The city does feel alive, even though most of the pedestrians are walking or talking on a phone. The soundtrack is full of both chinese and english songs, with plenty of radio stations to choose from.

However, this game is far from perfect: the biggest complaint I have is that, when you have beaten all the story missions and favours and races, there is nothing to do. Trying to get involved in car chases with the police doesn't help since you will have upgrades that reduce heat faster than ever.

Overall, it's a fun game to spend time to, with a compelling story and many side activities, even though at the end there is nothing else to do.

SCORE: 89/100

reviewText:
Welcome to Hong Kong , a vibrant city but with dark secrects.

You're wei shen, an undercover cop working for SFPD and HKPD , with ties to the Sun on Yee , a criminal triad organisation.

Now wei must rely on his martial art and police skills to reach the top and bring the triads down, but it won't be easy since the triad is torn apart with constant wars for succession.

This game is easily in my top 10 open world games and is really unique in it's genre.

Pros :
Epic fighting system with unique hand-to-hand and gun system.
Thrilling story-line and non linear level system.
Upgrades and new martial arts skills.
NFS like driviing.
Hundreds of side missions and activities.
Amazing graphics.

Cons :
Game's too cliched at some points.

9.5/10 - Worth it.

reviewText:
I really enjoyed Sleeping Dogs, I spent a good hundred hours or so on it on my xbox before purchasing it on steam.

The Basics
Sleeping Dogs is an open world, third person sandbox game, set in Hong Kong. I really liked the setting of the game, as it's something different than the ususal, small things like, driving on the left side of the road made the game a bit more interesting than it would've been, should they have left details like this out. The story revolves around Wei, an undercover cop sent to take down the mafia that operates in Hong Kong.

The Gameplay
Sleeping Dogs has amazing fighting mechanics, it mostly revolves around melee combat, and guns are only used when absolutely neccesary. Because of this, Sleeping Dogs stands out from it's rivals, the melee combat is fluent, fun and never gets old. The gun mechanics are good, but nothing special or exceptional, just plain old shooting. The Melle however has a LOT of combos, and that makes for good variation, you can also execute enemies using the enviroment, giving you bonus points while finishing off an enemy in style. Driving mechanics is the only thing I dislike about this game and while you get used to them after an hour or so, they still bug me. The cars handle extremely unrealistic and I would consider that this games major flaw.

I do really like how well-optimised the game is for PC, it's an exceptional port with settings like 'world densitiy', which will determine how many pedestrians, cars etc there will be in the world.

The Graphics
Sleeping Dogs looks good, and the world feels alive and immersive, especially at night. The game's true beauty comes out when you're driving through the city at night, with all the neon lighting and advertising creating a beautiful lit up picture. So yes, this game looks good and I'm sure it'll age well.

To Summarize
+Great fighting mechanics, very refreshing melee combat.
+Good gunplay, though nothing exceptional.
+Amazing setting.
+Attention to detail.
+Graphics are really nice looking.
+Great PC-port.
-Driving mechanics leave something to be desired.

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs takes place 69 years before Watch Dogs and is supposed to be the first chinese simulator.
You play as Wei Shen, son of Fu'k-Yu Shen and Kil-Yu Shen.

Gameplay consists of doing simple tasks that chinese people have to do every day (it is, after all, a simulator): Drive badly, eat dogs, hack cameras, eat pork bun, do kung fu and plan weddings.
Your boss lives in a noodle soup kitchen and you do most of the stuff just to impress him: DON'T DISHONOL YOUR FAMIRY!

You also try to chase women but fail to get into a decent relationship.
But don't worry because there are plenty of girls who want to massage you in back alleys. - Just like real Hong Kong!

So what are you waiting for, pok gai ?! It's the best (and only) chinese simulator out there! Buy it!

reviewText:
Gameplay: 10/10
Graphics: 10/10
Voice Acting: 10/10
Campaign: 10/10

Read on for my opinion on Sleeping Dogs

Sleeping Dogs was a game I wasn't sure about at first. It looked too linear, not enough weapons or vehicles, possibly a garbage campaign. But I bought this game when it was on sale to try it anyways. Needless to say im blown away. This Game has an immense focus on fighting and hand to hand combat whichy is suprising given the GTA style free roaming. Another great thing is the wide diversity of vehicles at your expense to use. With multiple races and side missions to play in game, having different vehicles to test out and play around with sure is a blast. Manuvering the city is also a fun little challenge due to the crowded streets of Honk Kong, it makes it sometimes hard to get away fromm the cops as easily as you'd like. Another thing is the campagin. I figured it would be like GTA, or Saints row, where you're part of a gang and you go do illegal things over and over. But nope, your character is Wei Shen, and undercover cop! Thats something I really loved about this game. The Campaign was so fresh and different. And massive credit to the voice actors of the game! The interactions between Wei shen and the Honk Kong PD as well as fellow Gangs was superb! You will definetly get your moneys worth out of this game AND the DLC. If you havn't picked up Sleeping Dogs already, do your game library a solid and add it to your collection!

reviewText:
It doesn't offer a great deal that can't be found in other open-world games, but the flipside is that it's also almost entirely free of the guff that drags many of its competitors down. Sleeping Dogs is a lean, refined GTA clone with an emphasis on putting as much of the game at your fingertips as early and often as possible.

Gameplay boils down to melee, gunplay and driving sections. Melee fights are the most prevalent part of the game and anyone who's played the Arkham games will feel right at home with the counter-driven one-button fighting here. Melee weapons and environmental kills are offered for some variety but don't add much complexity or depth. Shootouts can be conducted as either an exercise in cover-based pop-and-shoot mechanics (if you're boring), or a more arcadey system where stylish kills can be chained together to rack up continuous bullet time. It's very reminiscent of John Woo's Stranglehold and handily my favourite part of the game, although it errs on the side of being a bit too easy. Driving is fairly standard; cars handle well with the right amount of weight and chases are enlivened somewhat by the presence of that same chained bullet-time mechanic as well as the ability to freely hop from one car to another a la Just Cause.

The game's simulated Hong Kong is wonderfully detailed and always lovely to look at, but you'll find that it's not hiding a great deal of interesting content to be discovered. Aside from stores dotted around the place, you'll only ever really find yourself heading from map marker to map marker for story missions or sidequests. The obvious debt the game owes to classic Hong Kong action/martial arts cinema aesthetically will probably make it more interesting to genre fans (like myself).

reviewText: This is a great open world fighting/shooting game. The story is even better. I could play this all day.

reviewText:
A very enjoyable open world action game. One of my absolute favourite mechanics of the game is the easy interchangeability between keyboard+mouse and gamepad which is damn handy for a person who has not played shooters on console all that much. I used my X360 gamepad for the driving and martial arts parts of the game and switched to keyboard+mouse for the shooting parts. It is also surprising how easy one gets used to driving on the left (wrong side!) of the road.

The story itself isn't spectacular, but is it entertaining and I'd personally say does an admirable job at telling an undercover police story. The voice acting is also very good and surprisingly there are a good number of famous people lending their voice.

This game though has VERY many DLCs. Some of them though are free, but others are mainly cosmetic where they add some outfits or vehicles or weapons. There are also others like the Police Protection Pack which just added a single mission and that was it, although later made the stuff in that mission available in the rest of the game. You also have two content DLC which add a few hours of gameplay with missions tied to Halloween (Nightmare at North Point) and Chinese New Year (Year of the Snake). There is also the SWAT pack, where you do random police missions disguised as a SWAT member. These DLC are entirely optional so might be worth picking up at a discount.

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs Review
Before purchasing this game, I highly recommend a good graphics card in order to furthermore enjoy the bloody scenery of this game. At first, Sleeping Dogs is joyful to play, the combat system is great, the story is adequate, the side missions are satisfactory although quite repetitive and the exploration throughout this map is wonderful.

Although,  after completing the story and the dlc's, the player feels as if he has nothing else to do, and everything else becomes quite tedious. This game is fun throughout, until the point where you have nothing to do. I highly recommend this game if you have time to kill.

reviewText:
As a fan of Hong Kong cinema, the way Sleeping Dogs depicts its story had me attached to the plot, characters and setting from start to finish. Every character has personality, and while there isn’t a stand out individual, each one feels developed enough for you to care about their associations with Wei and it helps that the voice acting is fantastic. The game’s length is about 15-hours with side missions extending to double that.

The first three hours of Sleeping Dogs demonstrate a lot of the improvements to the GTA gameplay with the traversal free running and hand-to-hand combat. Hand-to-hand combat is heavily inspired by the Batman: Arkham series of video games, with Wei being able to punch, grapple and counter to victory. Grappling is a rather good move in Sleeping Dogs. Not only is it used to throw people over edges or pound them to the ground, but it allows Wei to interact with environmental objects as a way to deal extreme damage.

Story missions are mainly great. Side missions are a different story. Most are fillers where you are chasing people, racing cars, beating people up, singing Karaoke, hacking, nothing all that exciting compared to the main plot. The cars handle well with their super arcade-like feel, and the gun combat is mostly solid, with Wei able to pull off bullet time when jumping over cover, helping with aiming headshots.

Having seen all the versions on display, there is no denying that the PC version of Sleeping Dogs is well above the graphics of the console version. I had all settings set to the highest (PC Specs: i5, GeForce 660ti, 8GB RAM) and the framerate kept above 60 throughout the whole game. It’s the world that makes Sleeping Dogs’ graphics stand out, with the city looking stunning with the downloaded high resolution pack, showcasing the neon lights blasting their rays across the road and glowing up the night of Hong Kong.

Voice acting is outstanding, story is outstanding and graphics is outstanding, especially the water, thats all the outstanding stuff and it doesnt include gameplay!!

reviewText:
A very enjoyable open world action game. One of my absolute favourite mechanics of the game is the easy interchangeability between keyboard+mouse and gamepad which is damn handy for a person who has not played shooters on console all that much. I used my X360 gamepad for the driving and martial arts parts of the game and switched to keyboard+mouse for the shooting parts. It is also surprising how easy one gets used to driving on the left (wrong side!) of the road.

The story itself isn't spectacular, but is it entertaining and I'd personally say does an admirable job at telling an undercover police story. The voice acting is also very good and surprisingly there are a good number of famous people lending their voice.

This game though has VERY many DLCs. Some of them though are free, but others are mainly cosmetic where they add some outfits or vehicles or weapons. There are also others like the Police Protection Pack which just added a single mission and that was it, although later made the stuff in that mission available in the rest of the game. You also have two content DLC which add a few hours of gameplay with missions tied to Halloween (Nightmare at North Point) and Chinese New Year (Year of the Snake). There is also the SWAT pack, where you do random police missions disguised as a SWAT member. These DLC are entirely optional so might be worth picking up at a discount.

reviewText: I had heard quite a bit of pleasantly-surprised hype about this game. Apparently everyone expected something that sucked, due to the game's storied past - it was originally a True Crime game? So when it went on sale I decided to pick it up for myself. You've probably played this game in one form or another, it's a GTA-alike sandbox game, only this time, it's heavily Chinese-influenced, set in Hong Kong. The setting is probably the best part of this game, it's both well-fleshed out and novel, and the game seems to sport more of a living" environment than the sometimes sterile underpopulated cities of other GTAlikes. reviewText:
Grand Theft Auto: China.

That's almost a dead accurate representation of what this game is. Although you play a cop and not just some vigilante going home or starting out a crime bid. Other than that it's pretty much Grand Theft Auto.

You run can around the City scape looking for Cars, Money Boxes, Red Envolopes, Statues, and occationally Call up some chicks so you can have dates with them.

The Main Weapon of this game is your Fists, there is no weapon cycling, you either have a weapon or you don't and chances are you will not have a weapon on you when an enemy pulls one out so you have to rely on your own disarming abilities to get the upper hand and thankfully the game gives you power ups to improve your abilities in hand to hand combat making fighting much easier and fun.

Also the Fighting mechanics are pretty much ripped straight off of The Arkham Games, so if you're pretty keen on that you're pretty much set with this game.

Overall Sleeping Dogs is a great experience. I really like the atmosphere of this game and it gets really easy to get lost in this game just by driving around or walking around and just taking in the whole Chiniese experience.

This is worth a buy.

reviewText: Sleeping Dogs, i.e. True Crime Hong Kong"
date: is a third-person GTA style free-roamer set in Hong Kong. You play an undercover cop infiltrating the triad known as Song On Yee
recommended: and you will swear blood oaths with various triad members
hoursPlayed: as you understand they are just people like you
voteText: yet you will need to bring them to justic at some point. As the story progresses
helpfulPercent: you will do whatever needs to be done to stay undercover
votesHelpful: even if it means eliminating witnessses
votesFunny: all for the greater good
commentsCount: perhaps. As the dividing line between good and evil blur
column16: you will find out perhaps not all is as simple as you thought things to be.\n\nThe various areas of Hong Kong have been simplified but the flavor had been retained. It is big enough to hold races
column17: and various races are already available in the game (with more available via DLC). There are dozens of different vehicles in various classes
column18: plus motorcycles
column19: and if you don't want to run around all day taxis are always avaialble. And there are always tons of things to do (until you manage to do all of them). There are food stands that gives you a boost in various areas
column20: clothing stores to buy outfits (some gives you bonus)
column22: as well as missions such as clean up a gang near a certain hotspot by beating them up
column24: then call in the cops when a mastermind come along. There are also special crime solving missions that have you chase down leads or car stealing missions where the "dealer" want a particular model of car "obtained". Add that to "collectibles" (found all around town
column26: and over a dozen DLCs that adds more outfits
column30: and you have a total experience.\n\nThe game doesn't skimp on combat either. Most combat is melee involving various forms of kung fu
column31: and you will either fight barehand or with weapon (from cleaver to knife
column32: tire iron to lead pipe) There are a few improvised weapon as well (ever tried... fish?)  There are guns avaiable for certain missions
column33: but they are NOT that popular. in HK. You will learn more moves as you go along.\n\nAll in all
column34: Sleeping Dogs is GTA in Hong Kong with a TON of options
column35: and it will take you dozens of hours to complete
column36: and you can even challenge other players on the Rockstar "social" web to establish records and such. And the makers are still pumping out the occasional DLC. Just buy them while they're on sale

reviewText:
Sleeping Dags is a misleading game that plays on the duality of sleeping dags. What begins as a adventure into the backyard of your neighbor named Trie Ahd, a grouchy Arab American turns into a dilemma of choice. The baseball remains at the sleeping dag's side but how does one even know if the dag is sleeping. This sole question leads you on a journey to discover yourself and where dag's loyalties lie.

The game features a well developed open world sandbox gameplay but all the textures of the neighbors backyard outside of his sandbox are very low res for a PC release. I was also disapointed that the sleeping dag conflict was resolved early and replaced with a generic normal dag style that felt like it was put in to appeal to mainstream crowds that don't prefer their dags sleeping. This is the same crowd I assume that likes getting bit in the balls.

Aside from that my only other gripe was that the only song on the soundtrack was Goonies R Good Enough" by Cyndi Lauper played on loop. Would've liked to seen some other tracks like some recent hits like "Platinum Disco" or Oppa Gangnam Style.

I give this game 5 dogs biting balls out of 5 cats."
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Fantastic game! I really enjoyed the Square Enix take on an open world sandbox game. The driving is much better then any GTA game I've played yet, besides the fact that you can hijack a vehicle from the one you're driving which is awesome. The fighting style is pretty much what makes this game, simple and easy to remember combos that you can string together once you get your timing down. I was expecting a lot more gunplay in this game but it does just fine without it. If you enjoy GTA and want something a little different you should give this a shot.

reviewText:
Ahh sleeping dogs how i love this game. Since i love it so much i am gonna get the stuff i hate about it over and done with first of all. Im gonna cut the bull and get right into it.

First of all if it wasnt free on xbox live gold i wouldn't have played it beacuse it didn't work on my pc, Wich apparently i wasn't the only one who had that problem.

The second thing i hated was that when you finished the game the open world offerd nothing extra to do but a few side missions wich lacked creativity. And also the driving was a bit hard to control, Not being racist here... ok i am about to be, But why would they make a game were you are asian and you can't drive properly, please dont hate me.

The combat is my first thing i wanna talk about, It controls smoother than an asian kid doing homework (Wich if you didn't know is really smooth like spreading peanutbutter on your genatles). Take the batman combat and you have sleeping dogs combat. Amazing, Quick, Intense, Fun and Fluent combat really makes a game like sleeping dogs.

Next thing i want to talk about is the parkour. Its all right not like assins creed parkour but still can be fairly fun. One of my favourite features with it was when you jump from a building to a building and it goes in slow motion. Another neat thing to it is having to run and tap a to jump over things, It makes it feel more fluent.

Now on to the open world. As i said before there isn't much to do in it but stare at it like that old creepy guy does down the road at you. But like the old creepy guy staring at you it's enjoyable for someone. It really depends if you like to stop sometimes and enjoy the scene. The hong kong setting was really special to me.

Now my last point of the review and by fair the best point...

The story line. The story line is...is....♥♥♥♥ING AMAZING I DON'T CARE IF STEAM DOSN'T LET ME SWEAR IT IS ♥♥♥♥ING AMAZING! You play as an under cover cop and you have to infiltrate a triad (A chinese gang). At the begining you don't feel sorry for anyone in the gang beacuse they're crimanals. But the further the story goes the more and more you get attatched to everyone, And the more you get attatched to everyone the more the game reminds you that you are a under cover cop. You know you shouldn't feel for them but you do and it is so amazing!

I rate this game....

a 8.5 out of 10 For console

For pc i would give it a 0 beacuse it dosn't work for alot of people.

reviewText: Sleeping Dogs is a gem by Square Enix.  It has all of the elements needed for a great action/drama game with fighting, driving/racing and FPS elements.  The gameplay is extemely fun and intuitive.  The storyline is very engaging with complex characters and A-list voice acting (by a few well know movie actors nonetheless).  Be sure to use the high-resloution DLC (free on Steam).  For me, it was better to use a controller for the driving and fighting aspects alone.  This game also supports wide-screen resolutions.  I am very glad to have experienced this title and applaud Square Enix on thier continued line of quality games.

reviewText: I love martial arts and open world games, so I played around with Sleeping Dogs. I can say I have had a ton of fun, the combat system isn't something as great at Arkham City, but it's still really enjoyable to execute a perfect fighting move on different enemies or citizens.  The story is not very memorable, I do think there should have been some kind of choice for the player so there could be multiple endings. The DLC I purchased, made the game much more entertaining once I finished the main story. The game has great replayability, and if you enjoy old chinese movies, Bruce Lee, or Jackie Chan then you can find clothes that match their look and create your own adventure in the game using your imagination. I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys open world, gta, martial arts in a game.

reviewText:
First off I want to say that I was a bit skeptical of this game. I'm usually a bit picky when it comes to open world games. I have been disappointed in the past with games that claim to be open world but are actually just bigger world games with a relatively linear path.

With that said, this game IS open world similar to GTA but not as robust or in depth as GTA gets with the side missions weapons, cars, missions, etc but it does get pretty linear at times.

Don't let that scare you away though.

This game is incredibly fun and has a lot of great elements to it. The Asian atmosphere it brings is  awesome. I don't think it really captures the true Asian organized crime background that much but it does a good job in its own way.

If you're a fan of Bruce Lee/Jackie Chan/Jet Li martial arts movies you will like this game. They stuck a lot of cliche situations in this game that resemble many of those movies. I don't want to get too in depth and spoil anything but there are some outright mimics of the movies and their plots in certain parts of the game.

General game play is fun and satisfying. The graphics are pretty decent once you get the high res xpac. Driving is OK at best.  I use a controller with this game as it feels more comfortable to me when anything driving is involved. I would say that it has its good and bad moments. The drifting mechanic in the game feels a bit weak and makes me want more out of the vehicles.

The environments are nice and laid out. I do think that it becomes bland after a while with the same cars, same scenery etc. The towns all look the same for the most part. I dislike the fact that when you put on an outfit you don't get to use its perks in the various missions during the game.

One thing I don't like and this is no fault of the game at all it's the nature of being set in the asian country is getting used to driving on the left side of the road. Being a veteran of all the past GTA games and well, living in the US it makes for some difficult reactions. I find myself driving on the right side of the road frequently zoning out on the highways then running head on while trying to avoid traffic. This brings me to my next issue.

When you run into ANYTHING it takes away from the police points during your missions. Sometimes this is incredibly difficult and takes away from the game a bit. It could be anything from running into a sidewalk fence to running over a pedestrian. I understand the bigger stuff but even so much as a knick on the fence will cause a negative point towards your police faction score.

Anyway, the game is well worth the 6 bucks I spent for the game + all DLC. I really really enjoy it and feel I can get a lot of replay value out of it. I would recommend it to anybody looking for a good solid game to play similar to GTA mixed with the foreign martial arts movies.

reviewText: Solid GTA style game in a Hong Kong triad setting. Melee combat is nicely responsive and fluid. Shooting is not anything super interesting but isn't a let down either. Driving is probably one of the weakest links of the game. Feels like the physics really aren't there and driving feels a little junky and floating at times.\n\nBut if you can catch this game for a low price it's totally worth picking up due to it's interesting story line, solid combat and beautiful, lush and vivid Hong Kong setting. You easily spend 10+ hours on this game and if you are a completionist and what to complete all the side missions and activities you'll easily spent more than 20+ hours playing this game and you'll enjoy it. That is if you enjoy a GTA style open world third person action game.

reviewText:
Being a renegade kung-fu fighter, a rogue undercover cop avenging his dead sister, in a well depicted Hong-Kong, is a lot of fun in Sleeping Dogs. Cook a guy's face on hot plates, stab his heart with a swordfish; there are tons of way to kill a poor soul that are way more fun than using guns. The story is pretty good and pretty often, you feel like you're in a movie. When you're not killing triad members or out shopping for new clothes and bracelets, you can do pretty much everything you want: bet on ♥♥♥♥ fights, race cars and bikes in the docks, play mahjong...

By the end of the game, Wei Shen will be your new definition of a real Badass with sick tats.


Also you can sing Take On Me by a-ha, try finding that in a kungfu fighting game!

reviewText:

Fun to play around in.

reviewText: Sleeping Dogs is a gem by Square Enix.  It has all of the elements needed for a great action/drama game with fighting, driving/racing and FPS elements.  The gameplay is extemely fun and intuitive.  The storyline is very engaging with complex characters and A-list voice acting (by a few well know movie actors nonetheless).  Be sure to use the high-resloution DLC (free on Steam).  For me, it was better to use a controller for the driving and fighting aspects alone.  This game also supports wide-screen resolutions.  I am very glad to have experienced this title and applaud Square Enix on thier continued line of quality games.

reviewText: Sleeping Dogs is an open world action-adventure video game developed by United Front Games and Square Enix London. The game has you infiltrating the ranks of the Triads as undercover cop Wei Shen on an island off the mainland of Hong Kong.\n\nSleeping Dogs places a strong emphasis on hand to hand combat giving you the opportunity to unlock a wide range of different combos to be used while fighting. The combat very closely resembles that of Batman: Arkham City however doesn't feel as smooth, regardless anyone who enjoyed that series will probably enjoy this.

reviewText: This is actually really good.  There are elements of the old True Crime: LA that it used to be a sequel to, but it's also kept up with the times.  I normally get somewhat paralyzed by choice overload in these open world games, but the story in this is actually really involving, so there's always reason to keep progressing it.   There's a lot to like here, especially if you appreciate the subtle details about how as the game progresses and you are forced to go further and further past the line of the law, your actions start to reflect that.  Good ♥♥♥♥.  Would recommend.

reviewText: Holy Jesus this game was so much fun. I just finished the story, and it was fantastic. I would compare the feeling I'm having right now to a roller coaster. The game was non-stop fun througout the whole game, and now I have this sudden calmness. The story was THAT great, but there was one thing I loved about it. It never bored me. I could go one mission to the next without wanting to do something else. In fact, I found the story so interesting that I have almost every secondary mission to do now that the game is over. The combat in this game is spectacular is almost exactly like Batman. The combos and way you learn them are almost identical to the game Bully however, which I noticed immediately. The driving is good for an open-world game, and smashing through everything that gets in your way is a blast. This game has been on my backlog for a while now and I highly regret it. This is the most fun I've had in a game in months. As an open-world game, I enjoyed it even more than GTA 4. 10/10.

Pros:

Solid Combat
Cons:
