reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs provides the player to be a part of undercover cop with strong and engrossing narrative set in open-world. Once again, it is always compared to GTA-like games, but Sleeping Dogs has proved itself to be high potential sandbox. The production is easily noticeable; plot, voice acting, and environment are simply amazing. The cities are highly detailed and full of NPCs walking around and perform their activities based on situation. If Kane and Lynch: Dog Days takes player to the darkest side of China, then Sleeping Dogs will bring player to richly-detailed and diverse environment in Hong Kong from the old slums and night market to the business districts.

The gameplay is another strong point. The main missions are pretty diverse and well connect to the storyline. The game offers you many types of mini-game like plant a bug, picklock, cracking safe which give you feeling of being undercover cop. Martial arts is easy to learn and achieve as you proceed through the game, you will unlock more fighting style to beat different types of enemy; knock, stun, combo, and environment kills give a very satisfied outcome and well entertained. The gunplay has simple mechanics; fire behind cover or slide on object to activate slow-motion (like a John Woo’s films). Both running chase scenes and driving are well-made for badass feeling like shooting tires to take down enemy vehicles or hijack vehicle and continue your road carnage. Moreover, the ramming mechanics during driving is simply useful as you can use it to lose the cops or even boost your speed in race. Sleeping Dogs also rewards player in every mission and collectables which keep on player engagement and provide meaningful collectable. However, the side mission is quite less creative and combat is quite sluggish. Still, there is a lot of detail and things to do even you complete the game.

Lastly, the radio music is memorable with old Chinese song and some are from famous singer. The mixture of voice between pure Cantonese and English dub create the feel of player’s presence and preserve what Hong Kong should be.
Sleeping Dogs is unique and diverse as I said. The developers care in most details and know what keep on player engagement. It gives me very great experience to be part of Hong Kong and triad life. I never regret for every buck I spend on this game. Like it or not, you have to taste once.

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs is the only open world free roaming game I've finished so far.
Perhaps I am Asian and have never really liked the GTA series. And I've always wanted to be an undercover cop working for the triads after watching multiple 90s cops & triads movies that Hong Kong is famous for.

IMO its the way the quests are structured that made me want to continue. The characters call/message you before you click on the accept quest icon, making the world feel rather real. It makes you feel needed by the characters. Thus the quests flow smoothly. As I stated above, the storyline intrigued me and I felt attached to Wei Shen, the undercover officer, wanting to find out if he survives.

I've got the game at 50% off, finished the game and felt satisfied with it. I highly recommend it.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs was a game with a lot of promise in the first few missions.  Fun, Arkham Asylum style combat with a suitable open world and some of the more fun game mechanics that follow. (i.e. stealing cars, buying clothes, side missions to pass time, etc.)  Where it falls short, shockingly, is it's desire to make itself stand out.  It wanted to focus so much on melee combat that it made play styles go out the window.

Anyone can enjoy this combat, but what really caught me off gaurd was the gunplay.  For a game based off fist fighting, the gun combat was actually pretty amazing.  Simple, yes, and only with 3 or 4 guns to offer, but satisfying.  You can take cover, take hostages, the guns have a heavy, stomping power to them, and the 3rd person over the shoulder camera angle is actually better placed than some games that focus solely on it.  But then...

You can't use guns.  There are scripted moments where you can, sure.  But only scripted moments.  You find or get a gun in the open world, don't expect any ammo.  Fine, guns are rare and strong.  That's fair.  But there is more.  There are mission checks at the start and end of every mission that take away your guns!  WHAT?  It makes logic go right out the window!  Not just because you lose your gun, but because it punishes the player who is smart enough to try and save ammo for later.  I raided a drug lab and got a machine gun and handgun.  Was SOOOO happy.  Messed around a bit, started the next mission, and to my surprise, Harry Potter and friends decided it would be fun to make my guns disappear in to thin air.  Oh, okay.  Yeah, that's fair.  I risk my life to get a gun, succeed, try to save the ammo to make the next boss fight or level easier on me, then get punished by having my gun stolen.  That defeats the entire purpose of having ammo rare.  When something good is hard to get, you want to save it.  The world and all other games have taught us that.  Make it last.  This is the only game I've ever played that actually smacks you in the head for trying to play smart.

On top of that, anyone who has played saints row 2 or gta will laugh at this games attempt at cops.  When you go and cause some trouble, even if a cop doesn't see you or isn't there, one will spawn within 10 feet of you.  I'm not joking at all.  Then let's say you decide to run and take a car...  another cop will spawn 20 feet behind you in a car of their very own.  AND, no matter what car you are in, even cop vans can keep up with you.  Want that shiny sports car that costs so much?  No point in bothering, trust me.  If they were in a damn paddy-wagon they would still catch up to you.

Now, the game isn't all bad.  It really isn't.  It does some things really great and the combat is fun enough to warrent giving it a shot if you like kung-fu movies.  But, do not come here looking for your ultimate open world game, even if it tries to pretend like it is.  There isn't much to find in the world itself, and like I said before, there are some very intentional game design choices that prevent this game from being as good as it could have been.

reviewText:
A spiritual successor to the 'True Crimes' series, Sleeping Dogs is a rebirth of what the True Crimes game SHOULD have been like. An open world game of this genre that takes place outside of the United States (or an implied) is a fresh and nice change of scenery. Sleeping Dogs takes place in Hong Kong, the home base of the Chinese Triads. You play as Wei Shen, an undercover cop that walks a very thin line between loyalites. Sleeping Dogs takes on the Hong Kong cop genre and does a fantastic job of telling you a story backed with fun gameplay.

The visuals of the game is solid and it is to be expected out of any game with Square Enix label on it. Especially in cutscenes, everything is crisp. Which is important for a story driven game such as this one. In game graphics shows the enviroment very well. When it rains, the clothing on Wei does get wet and it shows. Little details, like blood and bruises after getting into a brawl shows up on Wei's face and on his clothing as well.  Damage to cars is admittedly, pretty standard in these games. Paint will be scratched up if you brush up too closely to another car and bullet holes will show up if shot at. Visuals are at its finest at the most important aspects of the game, while some little details could have used a little more work.

Gameplay might be a little different from what people expect from an open world game of this type of genre. While you can go on shooting rampages and crime spree when you are free roaming, it isn't anything like the calibur of GTA. You don't start out with a gun or have any places to buy weapons, melee combat is the name of the game in Sleeping Dogs. You'll be punching, kicking and slamming your enemies down on the ground alot. The melee combat is fairly firmilar to the Arkham games, but isn't as stylish. They mix it up a bit by throwing different types of enemies, like certain enemies cannot be grabbed and certain enemies dish out more damage than others. Enemies could have used more work and variations. You can upgrade your melee skins by collecting Jade Statues, which unlocks new melee combo strings or get triad upgrades which you get buffs and more combo strings. Combat is passable in this game and you shouldn't be detered by the fact it isn't just like the Arkham games.

Sleeping Dogs is a very story driven game. You play as Wei Shen, an undercover cop on a mission to infiltrate the ranks of the Triad. Wei throughout the game is faced with conflicting loyalities, he has a personal vendetta to settle with one of the members and has to deal with his growing attachment towards the triads. The story and setting really does feel like a hong kong cop drama.

Overall, Sleeping Dogs is a solid buy. It has enough side missions to extend gameplay. Some of the best side missions are the street races. It is a nice change of pace from triple A titles. Its definitely a cult hit. Definitely worth putting in your library of games. Sleeping Dogs is an experience that won't disappoint you.

Sleeping Dogs has quite a few DLCs with it, here is a list of DLCs that is worth getting.

1. Year of the Snake. A post game DLC that gives Wei a police mission to stop something big going down in the Chinese New Years.

2. Nightmare on North Point. A stand alone DLC that has Wei fighting Chinese vampires and a vengeful spirit of a dead and forgotten triad leader.

3. Zodiac Tournament. A DLC that is intergrated with the main game. A throwback to the 70s with corny Kung Fu action that pits Wei with some of the worlds finest martial artist and a corny plot. (Story has nothing to do with the main story)

4. Street Racer Pack. Adds 3 more challenging races to the game. (Not worth getting at full price, wait for a sale on this one)

The rest of the DLC are almost all cosmetic, unless you really want more outfits and access to certain guns for Wei, its better to buy them when there is a sale. Not worth getting at full price.

reviewText: On the plus side, the story is excellent, the scenery is lovely (I'm tempted to say I now understand why Vancouver looks the way it does ;) and the driving is pretty confident. On the uneven to negative side, the missions, while imaginatively framed, aren't very hard, and there's too much of the rather routine melee fighting. By the back third of the game I was feeling a bit bored, although I saw it through. A shame: a missed opportunity to really go to town in an excellent environment. But it's a little too polite.

reviewText:
This totally surprised me. Honk Kong is great place for sandbox game, and map is quite damn large. Game is mostly based on melee combat, but you'll also have weapons later in game. Melee system is great, it has lots of different moves to learn.

Game has lots of vehicles, motorcycles and cars. You can steal any car from street as you should, or you can pay taxidriver to take you where you want if you're too lazy to drive yourself, and then rob his car. Most cars are fast, and pretty easy to control. You can buy yourself cars, which will be added to garage.

Storyline is about undercover cop, if someone did not know that, it is interesting, but nothing spectacular. Sound acting is in  English, and some Chinese phrases are part of it.

Game has about 20 hours of gameplay, which also includes some of collectibles.

I was interested in this game, and decided to buy it when it was on sale.

I do not regret buying it, it is great game, one of my favorites in 2012.

reviewText:
8.5/10

Excellent game. If you're looking for a fresh new experience in gaming, definitely pick this game up. The open-world is extremely polished and detailed, giving a truly immersive experience. The volumetric lighting, food vendors, soda machines, rusty air conditioners, high density vehicles and NPCs, real-time weather change, and local radio are all present as if you were actually in Hong Kong. The story is strongly focused and engaging as you control an undercover cop to reveal the dark world of the Triads. The gameplay is solid. The shooting mechanics are fluid and action-packed. The guns are big and satisfying to use. As for the driving component, you'll feel like a true asian ricer blazing through the night life. When you have to fight, the combos are easy to memorize and satisfying to execute. Unlike the original True Crime, there's actually strategy involved than just mindless button mashing.

However, the game is intended to be played linearly (which I prefer actually) and not like a sandbox. So, the replay value is limited if you're concerned.

reviewText:
Gameplay: 10/10
Graphics: 10/10
Voice Acting: 10/10
Campaign: 10/10

Read on for my opinion on Sleeping Dogs

Sleeping Dogs was a game I wasn't sure about at first. It looked too linear, not enough weapons or vehicles, possibly a garbage campaign. But I bought this game when it was on sale to try it anyways. Needless to say im blown away. This Game has an immense focus on fighting and hand to hand combat whichy is suprising given the GTA style free roaming. Another great thing is the wide diversity of vehicles at your expense to use. With multiple races and side missions to play in game, having different vehicles to test out and play around with sure is a blast. Manuvering the city is also a fun little challenge due to the crowded streets of Honk Kong, it makes it sometimes hard to get away fromm the cops as easily as you'd like. Another thing is the campagin. I figured it would be like GTA, or Saints row, where you're part of a gang and you go do illegal things over and over. But nope, your character is Wei Shen, and undercover cop! Thats something I really loved about this game. The Campaign was so fresh and different. And massive credit to the voice actors of the game! The interactions between Wei shen and the Honk Kong PD as well as fellow Gangs was superb! You will definetly get your moneys worth out of this game AND the DLC. If you havn't picked up Sleeping Dogs already, do your game library a solid and add it to your collection!

reviewText:
So i'm sitting here with my plate of noodles, thinking what to say about Sleeping Dogs. Since it is one of those games that i'm two minds about. On one hand, it delivers a well crafted and realised Hong Kong cop-drama, but on the other hand, it feels like a very lackluster open-world game.

A bit of history, this game started off as a continuation to the True Crime series, but for reasons i cannot remember at this point, the development stopped. And  i think the game was saved in part by that decision. True Crime was not considered to be the best of series and if Sleeping Dogs (At time of original development True Crime:Hong Kong) it would have just fallen into obscurity with the rest, only to be remembered by the fans of the series. But does Sleeping Dogs survive on its own Or does it deserve the long sleep ?


STORY:

The story follows Wei Shen, an undercover cop sent to covertly infiltrate one of Hong Kongs famous triad gangs. And since i try my best to avoid spoilers, i will only summarize. That the story is heavily influensed by many of the famous Hong Kong cop-movies. And it is interesting enough to warrant playing through more than once.


GAMEPLAY:

Unfortunately for the game, the open-world nature really does it no favours. On the other hand it offers a very lively representation of Hong Kong and on the other it feels useless. There really is not enough content to warrant an open world, no random flippentry to perform besides some of the social challenges things and annoying the police. And that is about it. One oddity, that i believe also alienated some of the playerbase. Is the scarce amount of firearms, the game is mostly centered around melee combat and the system they used is so similiar to the Arkham-series that it feels almost like it was ripped off. But what there is, is functional enough. There are enviromental attacks that are flashy but a tad lengthy and a few other minor issues with the combat system.

The game has a great number of glitches and bugs, some are funny and some are absolutely infuriating. Most of theese bugs are centered around the freerunning system, i feel like it should have been polished a little more for the pc-version. Since  the game was designed for consoles, there are also some annoying problems with the camera. Overall, the porting could have been done much better.


SOUND DESIGN:

Like GTA, theres a decent amount of copyrighted music. Nothing to be annoyed about, but nothing to remember neither. The only funny thing is, that there is a karaoke-bar, with actual karaoke. A pattern minigame, but worth it to listen Weis voice actors vo over the song. Yes, they went there...


CONCLUSION:

Considering the problems that Sleeping Dogs, could i recoommend it ? Short answer, YES. Long answer, the game feels padded out lengthwise, several minor problems deteriorate the gameplay experince, optional activities feel like diversions, experience leveling is questionable and the rewards they give are minor to say the least. The story is the only thing that is supposed to carry the game, but does it ? Not really...

I would give this game a C+. It feels a little low, but as i have tried to explain, the only thing worth something in this game is the story it tells and really nothing else. What there is on the activities side, is forgettable and getting a 100% feels like a wasted effort.

reviewText:
Short Version: Buy this game, it deserves your money.

Long Version: An open-world game set to a Hong Kong crime movie.
The gameplay is great, Combat is similar to the Batman games where thugs will surround you and take turns trying to punch you in the back of the face, you can attack, counter and grapple. Attacks look awesome, counters can interrupt any of your actions and grapples let you use the environment, like throwing a dude into a dumpster or jamming his face through a fish tank. You also have a Face meter, which when full(fills by kicking the crap out of dudes and not getting punched in the face) enemies will flinch and even run away sometimes.

reviewText:
Very nice open world game and pretty polished. Some aspects do come off as gimmicky, like the face-meter. When you complete a couple of side-missions and you're wearing stuff that's giving you a bonus face percentage when completing these missions, your face-meter is already at max halfway through the game.
Graphics are very nice, espcecially when it's raining (and it's raining a lot!) the roadreflections look really cool.
Story is okay, but I tended to get out of the flow when doing all the other stuff that there's to do.
Side-missions can get pretty repetitive or tedious even, but I still got the urge to do every one of them, because there actually is a lot of gameplay on offer. For instance hi-jacking moneytrucks was a really cool thing to do (actually hi-jacking any car was), where the races actually could be kind of frustrating and hacking camera's was just addicting (and there's a lot more to do!).
Combat in this game felt reminiscent of that in the Batman games although not done as well imo. This was mainly because of the not-too-good camera-work. Being able to make use of the environment while in combat made up for this. It's really satisfactory slamming some bad-guy's head into a car door while seeing the glass shatter all around.
All in all if you like open-world games like GTA this is definitely for you. For 4 bucks or euro's you can't go wrong. It's sure to keep you interested for a couple of dozens of hours.

reviewText:
Expected a 'cheap thrill gta-clone. Was pleasantly suprised. Sleeping Dogs offers an interesting storyline that explores the moral gaps between the archetypical 'good' and 'bad'. The inevitable climax was satisfying in its execution (pun intended) but left me with a terrible aftertaste from what happened. Ultimately, the pacing was good and the delivery often excellent, although characters didn't always get the chance to fully develop beyond what was required in order to act as a development 'tool' for the protagonist.
In regards to gameplay, i was very satisfied. Sleeping Dogs borrows many elements from other franchises. Free-running through the city had an AC-touch to it. Shootouts were heavily inspired by Max Payne and driving reminded me of NFS. Most of the gameplay revolving action (shooting, driving) felt fluent and leaned heavily towards an arcade style. Meaning fast and destructive action had precedence over 'realism'. This can sway some people away from the game, but in my opinion it is a proper design choice - it stands in nice contrast with the ever-looming shadow that is the GTA franchise.

Overall, this game is quite good. The world is fleshed out with a lot of content; missions, jobs, favors, events, minigames; a lot of things are present to ensure that there is enough to do besides playing out the storyline which, because it's an open world crime game, felt relatively short clocking in at ~15 hours.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I fell in love with this game the first time I played it. I'd been on the fence regarding buying it since I'd heard a few detractors saying it wasn't as good as GTA.
I love the GTA series, but this tops them. Why? Because not only the story is good, but also the fighting mechanic - GTA was never good at fighting, it was all about driving and shooting. Sleeping Dogs brings in the Arkham series' style of freeflow fighting (though not as good as the Arkham games, it's not far off) as well as cool things like being able to jump from one car to another to hijack vehicles, take hostages, have bullet time vault shootings and much more.

The game is 2 years old but still looks as good, if not better (at times), than Watch Dogs. It runs really well, too. I was able to run it at ultra settings the day it came out, even with the hi-res PC-only texture pack that was released. Nowadays, I can run it at 2880x1620 (and would expect to run it at 4k, if my monitor supported it).

If you've been disappointed by Watch Dogs, then give this a try - I personally find it's more fun than Watch Dogs, allows you to interact with the other people in the environment more and has a great fighting system. It doesn't have all the hacking stuff, and is more action-orientated than stealth based, but that's not always a bad thing in the open world genre.

reviewText: Imagine, if you will, a world in which Square Enix put Grand Theft Auto, Batman: Arkham City, and Jackie Chan into a blender. That's what this game is.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs started out life as the third game in the critically-panned True Crime series. The first game was an underrated open-world game featuring a somewhat unlikeable protagonist. True Crime: Streets of L.A. boasted a realistically-mapped Los Angeles, a variety of side activities, a decent melee and shooting system, and a memorable soundtrack. The sequel, set in New York, fared even worse with critics and was known mostly for the presence of the artist then known as Snoop Dogg as a playable character. Because I was a fan of the first game, I’d been keeping tabs on the development of this title and was somewhat dismayed by the name change. Fortunately, Square Enix, having picked up the property from Activision, improved on almost every aspect of the original, making a terrific action game that plays like a John Woo film.

The player takes the role of Wei Shen, a young man who was raised in Hong Kong but whose family moved to America after the tragic death of a sister resulting from a drug overdose. Shen has returned to his birthplace and is recruited by the police superintendent for a deep cover assignment with the triads. Shen’s initial assignment is to collect evidence against the Sun On Yee lieutenant Winston Chu, but he soon finds himself embroiled in a nascent gang war that threatens the stability of the city. The story is interesting even if many of the beats are telegraphed well in advance (like a certain tragic occurrence that takes place near the end of the game) or are simply so obvious as to border on the cliche (it wouldn’t really be Hong Kong police story if Wei didn’t end up getting in over his head and defying his superiors in the police force).

Sleeping Dogs is primarily a martial arts combat game. The melee mechanics were heavily influenced by the Arkham games. You will usually face multiple opponents, enemy combatants signal impending attacks by flashing so that you have an opportunity to counter, and you can make use of combos to quickly take down large numbers of foes. By returning stolen statues to your former martial arts instructor, you will unlock new moves for Shen to use.

The game also incorporates two other upgrade systems: cop/triad experience and “face” experience. As you complete police missions, such as busting street racers that have turned to murder, and triad missions, such as intimidating shopkeepers into paying protection money, you gain cop and triad experience respectively. On most story missions, there is a chance to acquire both, depending on how you play (running over or shooting civilians hurts your cop rating and performing poorly in combat hurts your triad rating).  Completing “favor” missions gains you face experience, which unlocks performance boosts for Shen; these include things like increased duration of food and drink effects and increased durability when the face meter is filled in combat. Shen can purchase items like pork buns to give increased health regeneration and energy drinks to enhance his melee damage. Further bonuses accrue to Shen by the use of various articles of clothing that are either purchased as DLC or at in-game stores.

In addition to the story missions, Shen has access to a variety of side activities, including street races in cars and motorcycles, cockfights, mahjong poker, karaoke, and fight clubs. While the story races are deliberately not too challenging, the other in-game races can be very tricky. The cockfights and poker games seem to have somewhat random outcomes. Karaoke is amusing because it’s controlled by a Rock Band-like interface using the controller or keyboard and the vocal tracks are actually the Shen voice actor singing the songs in question. The fight clubs are pretty much what they sound like and are a great way to earn face experience.

There are a number of interesting mission DLCs available for Sleeping Dogs. “Wheels of Fury” has Shen safeguarding Dr. Tang’s new prototype DZS-90 supercar. After Shen has secured it across the DLC’s five missions–over the course of which it gains incredible abilities such as twin machine guns and a vehicle-stunning EMP device–he unlocks it for use in the main game. “The Zodiac Tournament” has Shen entering a suspicious martial arts tournament on an offshore island controlled by a madman. The setup and atmosphere deliberately invoke Bruce Lee’s Enter the Dragon, although the story ventures somewhat far afield from that film. The cutscenes alone are practically worth the price of admission for this one. Both of these packs integrate seamlessly into the main game.

On the cheapassgamer.com site, I’ve read that others feel that having mission DLCs outside of the main game and accessible directly from the main menu is a superior approach. I’m not convinced, especially after having played “Nightmare in North Point” and “Year of the Snake.” In the former, Shen must save one of his romantic conquests from an undead gangster known as Smiley Cat (for amusing reasons I won’t reveal here) and his army of restless souls. Most of Shen’s opponents in this DLC are jiang shi, a kind of hopping Chinese vampire, and yaoguai demons. The extended fights with jiang shi, especially the final encounter, have a certain artificial level of difficulty because the need to bodily toss the vampires into a gateway in order to seal it leaves Shen vulnerable to being grabbed and drained of his lifeforce (the vampires’ grip is preternaturally difficult to loosen, probably due to wonky controls more than anything else). In “Year of the Snake,” which is set after the main story, Shen has been busted down to a beat cop, and you have access to none of the unlocks and equipment that you gained during your playthrough of the main game. While the story is interesting enough on its own, the fact that you go from being a supercop to Joe Uniform in the blink of an eye tends to drain the experience of much of its color.

The latter two DLCs and the main story each have a number of collectibles to find and minigames to play. In addition to the statues previously mentioned, there are Buddhist shrines which give Shen a health boost, CCTV cameras (some of which are used in cop missions and some of which are just there) that must be hacked, and lockboxes containing clothing or money (some of which must be hacked and some of which can just be opened) that are usually guarded by hostile enemies. The hacking minigame involves guessing a four-digit sequence in six tries. The game provides you with clues by telling you when you have a digit that is correct and whether it is in the right location or not.

This is first and foremost, like the second game in the series, a console game. However the developer has created a fantastic PC port that controls very well by-and-large. However, the melee combat and most other aspects of the game control much more smoothly with some kind of gamepad and the shooting is (as one might expect) much easier with the precision of a mouse-and-keyboard setup. Fortunately, the game supports essentially on-the-fly switching between the two, making it easy to choose your control scheme of choice even for specific parts of individual missions.

Pretty much every aspect of the game is great, which is why the weak soundtrack is all the more disappointing. I’ve played a lot of these open-world action games and most of them have at least a few catchy tunes on the radio stations you listen to in vehicles while you’re driving around. Shen’s choice of stations is woefully limited and most of the music is neither memorable nor even very interesting. I actually found myself playing my own MP3s instead of listening to the game’s music during several play sessions. Nevertheless, if this is the worst aspect of your game, then you’re doing a hell of a lot of things right, and you should definitely wake this dog

reviewText:
Buggy and serious design flaws aside, is Sleeping Dogs fun?  The short answer is yes.  The story is predictable but satisfying -- several characters that I expected to die, did -- with the exception of one.  The fact that the bugs result in ridiculous behaviour only makes the fact that the game plays itself straight all the more hilarious and adding to the entertainmnet value.

Cover-combat is nicely broken up with movie-style stunts, favouring bold, aggressive play that is movie-like, entertaining and rewarding both visually and tactically but is otherwise pretty standard.  The Free-Running is perhaps too down-to-earth considering the rest of the game isn't and while a nice attempt is probably one of the weaker game elements.  The fighting has some serious design flaws that really keep it from being as good as it could be; enemy classes weaken what could have been entertaining free-flow combat by giving them uninterruptable attacks or grapple immunity which bogs down the combat flow in a forced way.  The driving seems fine, but the catch-up logic is irritating as it only applies to the computer-controlled cars making racing rely more on luck than it should.  Said driving is not keyboard friendly.

Finally, the bugs.  Oh the bugs.  Bugs were the first things I encountered because during the initial chase, the person I was supposed to follow quit running halfway through and in order to continue I had to dash ahead while the game nagged me that I was leaving him behind before he promptly teleported ahead.  Sometimes key events won't fire if you are genre-savvy and plan ahead.  NPC's will get stuck frequently and occasionally have amusing pathfinding difficulties.  One time the security camera wouldn't let me exit.  And the fact that many critical actions are crippled after completing a mission will mean occasionally thugs will steal your car trying to escape you because you couldn't do anything useful until the summary finished summarizing and you dismissed it.

Overall  the mechanics work with the general feel, and while fans of GTA or Saints Row will probably prefer those games to this one, it's still fun and its own unique quirks made me feel it was a enjoyable romp.

reviewText:
Dear Reader,
Sleeping Dogs is a spectactular game.
With a lovely story where everyone is happy and they gets what they want, it makes for a truely realistic experience of what it is like being a man living in Hong Kong. In Sleeping Dogs, there is no violence or drama, but it makes up for that with lots of heartfelt, family-friendly humor. I have personally put almost 24 hours worth of my time into this game, and I do intend to put more. So, if you do get bored with your mindless slaughter of innocent NPC's, purchase and enjoy Sleeping Dogs today.

Love,
Fossor_

reviewText: This game is by farm the best open world crime game I have ever played. Grand theft auto and saints row sagas are repetitive and normal to the genre, the hong kong setting, the story-line, the different stuff you can do, it leaves u screaming for more. The fighting gameplay is immersive and real. The story line is incredible and feels like an hong kong movie. And the graphic style is stunning. The hong kong bright lights and colours (and chop-shops) are the perfect place to set a game like this and it brings a twist to the normal grey of the LA or detroit scene. Amazing game well worth the money.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Not gonna lie, Sleeping Dogs is pure violent badass. The game's fighting system is evocative of many fan-favorite kung fu movies, the writing is good, the story is intense and there's always something to do in Hong Kong!  Everyone drives on the left side of the road and the city looks amazing.

Upsides: Great melee combat, nice arcade-style car handling, great selection of clothes and cars (although don't expect to find many nice cars on the streets), some cool free-running options, memorable characters, interesting missions, interesting side-missions and such, racing is an option.

Downsides: Limited choice in guns, average camera control on foot, bad camera control in cars, only 3 types of enemies + bosses, it's impossible to drive without smacking into things, charachter has very little life and no armor, (almost) no way to access guns out of missions

Overall, I'm left with a very good impression of this game and had a good time playing even if the main campaign was done in only 20 hours.

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs started out life as the third game in the critically-panned True Crime series. The first game was an underrated open-world game featuring a somewhat unlikeable protagonist. True Crime: Streets of L.A. boasted a realistically-mapped Los Angeles, a variety of side activities, a decent melee and shooting system, and a memorable soundtrack. The sequel, set in New York, fared even worse with critics and was known mostly for the presence of the artist then known as Snoop Dogg as a playable character. Because I was a fan of the first game, I’d been keeping tabs on the development of this title and was somewhat dismayed by the name change. Fortunately, Square Enix, having picked up the property from Activision, improved on almost every aspect of the original, making a terrific action game that plays like a John Woo film.

The player takes the role of Wei Shen, a young man who was raised in Hong Kong but whose family moved to America after the tragic death of a sister resulting from a drug overdose. Shen has returned to his birthplace and is recruited by the police superintendent for a deep cover assignment with the triads. Shen’s initial assignment is to collect evidence against the Sun On Yee lieutenant Winston Chu, but he soon finds himself embroiled in a nascent gang war that threatens the stability of the city. The story is interesting even if many of the beats are telegraphed well in advance (like a certain tragic occurrence that takes place near the end of the game) or are simply so obvious as to border on the cliche (it wouldn’t really be Hong Kong police story if Wei didn’t end up getting in over his head and defying his superiors in the police force).

Sleeping Dogs is primarily a martial arts combat game. The melee mechanics were heavily influenced by the Arkham games. You will usually face multiple opponents, enemy combatants signal impending attacks by flashing so that you have an opportunity to counter, and you can make use of combos to quickly take down large numbers of foes. By returning stolen statues to your former martial arts instructor, you will unlock new moves for Shen to use.

The game also incorporates two other upgrade systems: cop/triad experience and “face” experience. As you complete police missions, such as busting street racers that have turned to murder, and triad missions, such as intimidating shopkeepers into paying protection money, you gain cop and triad experience respectively. On most story missions, there is a chance to acquire both, depending on how you play (running over or shooting civilians hurts your cop rating and performing poorly in combat hurts your triad rating).  Completing “favor” missions gains you face experience, which unlocks performance boosts for Shen; these include things like increased duration of food and drink effects and increased durability when the face meter is filled in combat. Shen can purchase items like pork buns to give increased health regeneration and energy drinks to enhance his melee damage. Further bonuses accrue to Shen by the use of various articles of clothing that are either purchased as DLC or at in-game stores.

In addition to the story missions, Shen has access to a variety of side activities, including street races in cars and motorcycles, cockfights, mahjong poker, karaoke, and fight clubs. While the story races are deliberately not too challenging, the other in-game races can be very tricky. The cockfights and poker games seem to have somewhat random outcomes. Karaoke is amusing because it’s controlled by a Rock Band-like interface using the controller or keyboard and the vocal tracks are actually the Shen voice actor singing the songs in question. The fight clubs are pretty much what they sound like and are a great way to earn face experience.

There are a number of interesting mission DLCs available for Sleeping Dogs. “Wheels of Fury” has Shen safeguarding Dr. Tang’s new prototype DZS-90 supercar. After Shen has secured it across the DLC’s five missions–over the course of which it gains incredible abilities such as twin machine guns and a vehicle-stunning EMP device–he unlocks it for use in the main game. “The Zodiac Tournament” has Shen entering a suspicious martial arts tournament on an offshore island controlled by a madman. The setup and atmosphere deliberately invoke Bruce Lee’s Enter the Dragon, although the story ventures somewhat far afield from that film. The cutscenes alone are practically worth the price of admission for this one. Both of these packs integrate seamlessly into the main game.

On the cheapassgamer.com site, I’ve read that others feel that having mission DLCs outside of the main game and accessible directly from the main menu is a superior approach. I’m not convinced, especially after having played “Nightmare in North Point” and “Year of the Snake.” In the former, Shen must save one of his romantic conquests from an undead gangster known as Smiley Cat (for amusing reasons I won’t reveal here) and his army of restless souls. Most of Shen’s opponents in this DLC are jiang shi, a kind of hopping Chinese vampire, and yaoguai demons. The extended fights with jiang shi, especially the final encounter, have a certain artificial level of difficulty because the need to bodily toss the vampires into a gateway in order to seal it leaves Shen vulnerable to being grabbed and drained of his lifeforce (the vampires’ grip is preternaturally difficult to loosen, probably due to wonky controls more than anything else). In “Year of the Snake,” which is set after the main story, Shen has been busted down to a beat cop, and you have access to none of the unlocks and equipment that you gained during your playthrough of the main game. While the story is interesting enough on its own, the fact that you go from being a supercop to Joe Uniform in the blink of an eye tends to drain the experience of much of its color.

The latter two DLCs and the main story each have a number of collectibles to find and minigames to play. In addition to the statues previously mentioned, there are Buddhist shrines which give Shen a health boost, CCTV cameras (some of which are used in cop missions and some of which are just there) that must be hacked, and lockboxes containing clothing or money (some of which must be hacked and some of which can just be opened) that are usually guarded by hostile enemies. The hacking minigame involves guessing a four-digit sequence in six tries. The game provides you with clues by telling you when you have a digit that is correct and whether it is in the right location or not.

This is first and foremost, like the second game in the series, a console game. However the developer has created a fantastic PC port that controls very well by-and-large. However, the melee combat and most other aspects of the game control much more smoothly with some kind of gamepad and the shooting is (as one might expect) much easier with the precision of a mouse-and-keyboard setup. Fortunately, the game supports essentially on-the-fly switching between the two, making it easy to choose your control scheme of choice even for specific parts of individual missions.

Pretty much every aspect of the game is great, which is why the weak soundtrack is all the more disappointing. I’ve played a lot of these open-world action games and most of them have at least a few catchy tunes on the radio stations you listen to in vehicles while you’re driving around. Shen’s choice of stations is woefully limited and most of the music is neither memorable nor even very interesting. I actually found myself playing my own MP3s instead of listening to the game’s music during several play sessions. Nevertheless, if this is the worst aspect of your game, then you’re doing a hell of a lot of things right, and you should definitely wake this dog

reviewText:
I am eating pork buns and curried fish balls with noodles while I write this review. Bet that doesn't happen every day.

This game is so much better than most of the Metacritic reviews would lead you to believe. Way better than GTA 4 overall. There are a lot of GTA elements in here, like the car jumps, but it is way different. I fianally got this game and have played non-stop for two days. The ablity to be a bad ♥♥♥ martial arts character and beat the fish balls off of bad guys is what puts it over the top. Nothing like this in GTA even comes close.

At first the controls and driving are a bit hard to figure out and get used too. Once you get a few hours into the game it will start to flow and become like an action movie. Reminds me so much of the 80's Hong Kong action movies . Almost perfect in that respect, where you feel like Chow Yun Fat in Triads: The Inside Story.

If you love open-world games like GTA and especially Saints Row 3, then you will love this game. My advice is to get the high-rez pack and the play through once without any of the extra DLC. You get a nice little starter boost with the Digital Edition so you should experience the game without anything else the first time.

I just finished one play-through (all cops and triad missions and favors) so now I am going back and doing it all over with the DLCs included. This game is that good that I am completely addicted to it like I was when GTA San Andreas first hit.

You can easily rack up over 100 hours if you explore the whole city and do all the extra missions and find the collectables. I have seen a lot of people complain that there is only about 20 hours of play, but that is only if you rush through and just do the main story line.

I would have to give this game 9.5 pork buns for my overall score. The only reason I don't give it a ten is the slight difficulty with the controls and interface.
